Text: House of Representatives.

Text: Wednesday, IkMarch, 191,5.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Hon. J. S. Rosevear)

Speaker: NA
Text: took the chair at 3 p.m., and read prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: DEATH OF GENERAL SIR HARRY

Speaker: NA
Text: CHAUVEL, G.C.M.G. , K.C.B .

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: Macquarie - Trea-

Speaker: NA
Text: surer) -Th e news of the death of

Speaker: NA
Text: General Sir Harry Chauvel on Sunday,

Speaker: NA
Text: the 4th March, will have been received

Speaker: NA
Text: by all members of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament with very great sorrow. Sir

Speaker: NA
Text: Harry was a distinguished soldier, and

Speaker: NA
Text: a great Australian. I f his greatness has

Speaker: NA
Text: not been fully appreciated by our genera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, posterity certainly will acclaim him

Speaker: NA
Text: one of our Empire's great men. Born at

Speaker: NA
Text: Tabulan, in northern New South "Wales,

Speaker: NA
Text: on the 16th April, 1865, he obtained, his

Speaker: NA
Text: early education at Toowoomba and

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney Grammar .Schools. Selecting

Speaker: NA
Text: a military career, he applied himself

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout his active soldiering days

Speaker: NA
Text: to mastering the profession of arms.

Speaker: NA
Text: That he was successful, ,is indicated, by

Speaker: NA
Text: the history of his achievements.

Speaker: NA
Text: When our defence force was in embryo,

Speaker: NA
Text: Harry Chauvel joined the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales Cavalry in 1886, the Queen's Own

Speaker: NA
Text: Mounted Infantry i n 1890, and the Per-

Speaker: NA
Text: manent Forces ia 1896. He fought

Speaker: NA
Text: through the South African War from

Speaker: NA
Text: 1899 to 1902 with the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: Mounted Infantry, and later as com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mander of a composite force of English,

Speaker: NA
Text: Canadian, South African and Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: horsemen known as " Chauvel's Mounted

Speaker: NA
Text: Infiantry". For those services he was

Speaker: NA
Text: created a C.M.G., and was granted a

Speaker: NA
Text: brevet rank of Lieutenant-Colonel. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: 1911, he became Adjutant-General of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Military Forces, and was

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian representative on the Imperial

Speaker: NA
Text: General Staff at the War Office in 1914.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the outbreak of the first Great War he

Speaker: NA
Text: was given command of the First Light

Speaker: NA
Text: Horse Brigade in Egypt, and took i t to

Speaker: NA
Text: Gallipoli, dismounted. There, again,

Speaker: NA
Text: Harry Chauvel demonstrated his capacity

Speaker: NA
Text: for leadership. During the most bitter

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting of that campaign, he commanded

Speaker: NA
Text: the centre section of the Anzac defences;

Speaker: NA
Text: the command included his own brigade

Speaker: NA
Text: and the 4th Australian Infantry Brigade.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n September, 1915, he commanded for

Speaker: NA
Text: a time the New Zealand and Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Division, and later the First Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Division, which formation he took back

Speaker: NA
Text: to Egypt. Throughout the Sinai cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: paign, Harry Chauvel led the Anzac

Speaker: NA
Text: Mounted Division, to which was attached

Speaker: NA
Text: the Imperial Gamel Corps, and further

Speaker: NA
Text: distinguished himself in the battles at

Speaker: NA
Text: Romani, Magdhaba and Gasa. Follow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing these battles, he was created a

Speaker: NA
Text: K.C.M.G., as an " immediate" decora-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion- a very rare distinction. His com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mand-th e Desert Column-wa s enlarged

Speaker: NA
Text: into the Desert Mounted Corps, and in

Speaker: NA
Text: August, 1917, he was promoted to the

Speaker: NA
Text: rank of Lieutenant-General, being the

Speaker: NA
Text: first Australian soldier to reach that rank.

Speaker: NA
Text: From among all the cavalry generals of

Speaker: NA
Text: the British Empire, . Sir Harry Chauvel

Speaker: NA
Text: was selected to lead the largest force of

Speaker: NA
Text: mounted troops the modern world had

Speaker: NA
Text: known. His generalship at the battles

Speaker: NA
Text: which followed, which brought about the

Speaker: NA
Text: destruction of the Turkish armies and

Speaker: NA
Text: culminated in the capture of Damascus

Speaker: NA
Text: and Aleppo, and the capitulation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Turks, proclaimed to the world the genius

Speaker: NA
Text: of the man whose passing we now mourn.

Speaker: NA
Text: His awards during the 1914-18 war

Speaker: NA
Text: earned him the O.B., K.C.M.G., K.C.B.,

Speaker: NA
Text: G.C.M.G., Oroix de Guerre (France),

Speaker: NA
Text: Order of the Nile-thir d and second class

Speaker: NA
Text: -an d Mention in Despatches nine times.

Speaker: NA
Text: Following the 1914-18 war, Sir Harry

Speaker: NA
Text: Chauvel became Inspector-'General, and

Speaker: NA
Text: later Chief o£ the General Staff, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Military Forces, and was pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: moted to f u l l General in 1929. During

Speaker: NA
Text: this time, and indeed for some years

Speaker: NA
Text: afterwards, his vision and influence did

Speaker: NA
Text: much to build up the nucleus of the Army

Speaker: NA
Text: of which we are so proud to-day. Retire-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment from the Army in 1930 was not the

Speaker: NA
Text: end of Sir Harry's life work. Right up

Speaker: NA
Text: to the time of his death, he held the

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment of Inspector-in-Chief of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Volunteer Defence Corps. I n addition,

Speaker: NA
Text: he had actively engaged in pursuits of

Speaker: NA
Text: a philanthropic nature, with a view to

Speaker: NA
Text: advancing the well-being of ex-service-

Speaker: NA
Text: men, and promoting worthy objects

Speaker: NA
Text: in various spheres of community

Speaker: NA
Text: life. He pursued these activities

Speaker: NA
Text: until only a few months ago, when his

Speaker: NA
Text: declining health, aggravated :by an injury

Speaker: NA
Text: sustained while riding, prevented his con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinuance of them. The late general was

Speaker: NA
Text: accorded a State military funeral as a

Speaker: NA
Text: tribute to his outstanding public service.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n paying the respects of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: to the memory of this great Australian,

Speaker: NA
Text: whose deeds and service had earned the

Speaker: NA
Text: gratitude of our nation, and indeed, of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Empire, I am sure that every honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member joins with me in extending

Speaker: NA
Text: the deepest sympathy to Lady Chauvel

Speaker: NA
Text: and her family. I move-

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House expresses its deep regret

Speaker: NA
Text: at the death ot General Sir Harry Chauvel,

Speaker: NA
Text: G.C.M.G., K.C.B., places on record its appre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciation of his meritorious public service, and

Speaker: NA
Text: tenders its profound sympathy to his widow

Speaker: NA
Text: ii ud family in their bereavement.

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: Kooyong-Leade r of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition) -M y colleagues and

Speaker: NA
Text: desire to be associated with the motion,

Speaker: NA
Text: and with the words that have fallen

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Treasurer ( Mr 'Chifley), turned

Speaker: NA
Text: who has summarized a military career

Speaker: NA
Text: that must be one of the most res-ervicemen

Speaker: NA
Text: markable of the century. Indeed, i

Speaker: NA
Text: has been said, and said by those comLiberal

Speaker: NA
Text: petent to judge, that, in the military

Speaker: NA
Text: sphere, Sir Harry Chauvel was one

Speaker: NA
Text: the most remarkable cavalry leaders of all organization?

Speaker: NA
Text: history. I n addition, we recall i Sir Harry

Speaker: NA
Text: Chauvel, the man, because, with all the

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity for decision, tlie force of characand

Speaker: NA
Text: ter and the strength of mind that must

Speaker: NA
Text: have informed his military actions, he

Speaker: NA
Text: was in private life a man of the greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: simplicity, of the most exquisite courtesy,

Speaker: NA
Text: and of direct, honest and attractive

Speaker: NA
Text: character. Indeed, although they were

Speaker: NA
Text: not physically similar, I could not

Speaker: NA
Text: him without being reminded 'by his

Speaker: NA
Text: manner, and that which was inside him,

Speaker: NA
Text: of the late General Sir Brudenell White.

Speaker: NA
Text: This country is, indeed, fortunate to

Speaker: NA
Text: have produced out of the turmoil of war,

Speaker: NA
Text: on two or three occasions, such amazing

Speaker: NA
Text: servants of the people.

Speaker: Mr FADDEN
Text: Darling Downsthat

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Australian Country party).

Speaker: NA
Text: - I rise to add my party's tribute to the

Speaker: NA
Text: sentiments already expressed. We

Speaker: NA
Text: called upon this afternoon to pay this

Speaker: NA
Text: respect to the memory of, I supLeader

Speaker: NA
Text: pose, one of the greatest soldiers question

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australia has ever produced. to-morrow.

Speaker: NA
Text: I u Queensland his name is almost a

Speaker: NA
Text: legend. I was privileged to know him

Speaker: NA
Text: intimately, and I feel his passing keenly.

Speaker: NA
Text: I add my -humble quota of appreciation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the services which that great man has

Speaker: NA
Text: rendered to this young nation, and of the

Speaker: NA
Text: example which he -has set to those who

Speaker: NA
Text: shall follow him. I join in the sentiments

Speaker: NA
Text: of sympathy to be conveyed to those left

Speaker: NA
Text: to mourn his loss.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative,

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members standing in their

Speaker: NA
Text: places.

Speaker: NA
Text: LIBERAL PARTY.

Speaker: NA
Text: APPOINTMENT OF ORGANIZES.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr 'CHAMBERS -I s the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Post-war Reconstruction aware that

Speaker: NA
Text: the New South Wales branch of the new

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal party has appointed Mr George

Speaker: NA
Text: I A. Wilson as its State organizer at a

Speaker: NA
Text: salary of £2,000 .a year ? I n view of the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that this gentleman is not a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: soldier, will the Minister consider

Speaker: NA
Text: making provision in the preference-to-

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation that this position

Speaker: NA
Text: t shall be declared vacant so that the

Speaker: NA
Text: party will have to give preference

Speaker: NA
Text: to servicemen when filling any posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: of tions which are created in its new

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: Yes , I am aware

Speaker: NA
Text: that the appointment has been made,

Speaker: NA
Text: had the position become vacant after

Speaker: NA
Text: the passing of certain legislation that is

Speaker: NA
Text: to be brought jbef ore the House, i t would

Speaker: NA
Text: have been obligatory on the Liberal party

Speaker: NA
Text: to appoint an ex-serviceman. I cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: say whether the legislation, i f passed,

Speaker: NA
Text: can be made retrospective, but I shall

Speaker: NA
Text: meet give the matter consideration.

Text: PRICE OF MILK .

Text: Mor e than a fort-

Speaker: NA
Text: night ago, I asked the Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: on notice, to arrange for the holding of

Speaker: NA
Text: an independent inquiry into the cost to

Speaker: NA
Text: dairymen of producing milk i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney and Newcastle zones, and I asked

Speaker: NA
Text: the price recommended by the

Speaker: NA
Text: authority appointed for this purpose be

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted by the Prices Commission as the

Speaker: NA
Text: are amount to be paid to dairymen. As

Speaker: NA
Text: matter' is urgent, I ask the Acting

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House to see that the

Speaker: NA
Text: shall be, i f possible, answered

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: I shall arrange for

Speaker: NA
Text: an answer to be given, as soon as possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: RAIL TRANSPORT.

Speaker: NA
Text: ACCOMMODATION FOR MEMBERS OF

Speaker: NA
Text: PARLIAMENT-RESTRICTION S ON INTER-

Speaker: NA
Text: STATE TRAVEL.

Speaker: Mr BRYSON
Text: Whe n I was travel-

Speaker: NA
Text: ling from Melbourne to Canberra yester-

Speaker: NA
Text: day I was given a seat at Albury in

Speaker: NA
Text: an obsolete second-class railway carriage

Speaker: NA
Text: of the kind that is normally used for

Speaker: NA
Text: carrying passengers between intermediate

Speaker: NA
Text: stations. A bus capable of seating 36

Speaker: NA
Text: passengers was provided to carry four

Speaker: NA
Text: members of Parliament from Yass to

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra, and took two hours to make

Speaker: NA
Text: the journey of less than 40 miles. A

Speaker: NA
Text: private car was waiting for another

Speaker: NA
Text: member. I ask the Minister for Trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: port whether he can make immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements to provide a sleeping-car

Speaker: NA
Text: for the journey between Albury and

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra. I f not, will he arrange for

Speaker: NA
Text: some other suitable method of transport

Speaker: NA
Text: to replace the present one?

Speaker: Mr WARD
Text: Mor e than one authority

Speaker: NA
Text: is involved in arranging transport to and

Speaker: NA
Text: from Canberra. The State railways, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable memiber is aware, still

Speaker: NA
Text: remain under the direct administration

Speaker: NA
Text: of State authorities. The provision of

Speaker: NA
Text: a bus service between Yass and Canberra

Speaker: NA
Text: is the concern of the Minister for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Interior. As for the suggestion that sleep-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing cars be restored in order to suit the

Speaker: NA
Text: convenience of members of Parliament,

Speaker: NA
Text: I regret that I cannot favorably con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider any proposal for discriminating in

Speaker: NA
Text: favour of members of Parliament as

Speaker: NA
Text: compared with the general public.

Speaker: NA
Text: The question of the restoration of sleep-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing cars is to be considered at the next

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting of the War Railway Committee,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is hoped that arising out of its

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberations a decision to restore sleeping

Speaker: NA
Text: cars at an early date will be. made.

Speaker: Mr SHEEHAN
Text: Ca n the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Transport say whether the War Rail-

Speaker: NA
Text: way Committee at its forthcoming con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference will give consideration to the

Speaker: NA
Text: lifting of restrictions on interstate rail

Speaker: NA
Text: travel? I f not, will he arrange to have

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter placed on the committee's

Speaker: NA
Text: agenda?

Speaker: Mr WARD
Text: Tha t matter is included

Speaker: NA
Text: in the committee's agenda, and judging

Speaker: NA
Text: from the latest reports I am very hopeful

Speaker: NA
Text: that some of the restrictions will be lifted.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS.

Speaker: Mr HOLT
Text: Ha s the Acting Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House any information to give to

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members regarding press

Speaker: NA
Text: reports that the practice which has existed

Speaker: NA
Text: for many years in dealing with questions

Speaker: NA
Text: without notice is to be changed? Is it

Speaker: NA
Text: intended tbat the proposed change shall

Speaker: NA
Text: apply only to questions directed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, and, i f so, does the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman propose to nominate

Speaker: NA
Text: a deputy in this House to deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: matters concerning his own administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion when put to him by private members ?

Speaker: NA
Text: Can he say whether it is proposed to

Speaker: NA
Text: extend the new practice to Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: other than the Prime Minister?

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: A s the result of

Speaker: NA
Text: what appears to be a growing practice of

Speaker: NA
Text: asking, without notice, questions which

Speaker: NA
Text: are not of urgent public importance

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! The Chair

Speaker: NA
Text: at all times determines the importance

Speaker: NA
Text: and urgency of questions. I hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer is not reflecting on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chair.

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: I had no intention to

Speaker: NA
Text: reflect on the Chair, Mr Speaker. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: merely expressing the Prime Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: opinion that some questions, without

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, do not seem to him to be of urgent

Speaker: NA
Text: public importance, and that the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of such questions is increasing.

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: Questions without

Speaker: NA
Text: notice are not more numerous than they

Speaker: NA
Text: were ten years ago.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! I cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: allow a debate on the subject.

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: Whe n Mr Bruce

Speaker: NA
Text: was Prime Minister he referred to this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter in, I think, 1929. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister proposes to give direct answers

Speaker: NA
Text: only to questions which are addressed to

Speaker: NA
Text: him by party leaders in the House, and

Speaker: NA
Text: then only i f he is able to answer them

Speaker: NA
Text: with the information at his disposal.

Speaker: Mr HOLT
Text: Ar e questions by private

Speaker: NA
Text: members to be addressed to a deputy of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister?

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: Generall y speaking,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister's intention is to

Speaker: NA
Text: confine his answers to questions addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: to him by the leaders of the parties

Speaker: NA
Text: the House. As to questions addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: private members to other Ministers,

Speaker: NA
Text: is hoped that i f they are of an urgent

Speaker: NA
Text: character and can be answered readily,

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers will continue to reply to

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is proposed to ask that long questions

Speaker: NA
Text: which obviously the Ministers to whom

Speaker: NA
Text: they are addressed cannot answer such

Speaker: NA
Text: off hand shall be placed on the noticeof

Speaker: NA
Text: paper.

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: Th e Prime Minister is

Speaker: NA
Text: also Minister for Defence. Should

Speaker: NA
Text: -private member desire to ask a question

Speaker: NA
Text: touching the Department of Defence, to

Speaker: NA
Text: what Minister should he direct it?

Speaker: Mr HOLT
Text: Th e Prime Minister also House?

Speaker: NA
Text: will deputize for the Minister for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Army during the absence of the latter

Speaker: NA
Text: from Australia.

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: Tha t is a matter to may

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have not given much thought, to

Speaker: NA
Text: and I do not know the Prime Minister's lating

Speaker: NA
Text: views concerning it.

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Text: I ask you, Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, whether it is competent for any

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister to state as a matter of practice

Speaker: NA
Text: that he will not answer any. questions

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of a matter of public

Speaker: NA
Text: portance and urgency ? Is i t not for you

Speaker: NA
Text: to permit any private member to put any

Speaker: NA
Text: question on any matter of public

Speaker: NA
Text: urgency to a Minister? Can there

Speaker: NA
Text: any preclusion of that right?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: A n honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber has the choice of asking a question

Speaker: NA
Text: either orally or in writing, upon notice,

Speaker: NA
Text: in his own way, provided always that forthwith.

Speaker: NA
Text: he keeps within the 'Standing Orders;

Speaker: NA
Text: and it then rests with the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: whom the question is asked to decide ing a question?

Speaker: NA
Text: whether he will answer it orally, or re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quire that notice of it be given. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, i t is a well-established practice,

Speaker: NA
Text: for which they are many precedents,

Speaker: NA
Text: that a Minister need not answer any

Speaker: NA
Text: question, and it is totally disorderly

Speaker: NA
Text: an honorable member to insist that

Speaker: NA
Text: given an answer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Later:

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Standin g Order 92

Speaker: NA
Text: relates to the asking of questions reto

Speaker: NA
Text: specting public business. I n view of the answer.

Speaker: NA
Text: in statement of the Acting Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: by the House, will you, Mr Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: it rule as to whether or not the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, or any other Minister,. has

Speaker: NA
Text: any power under the Standing Orders

Speaker: NA
Text: them. to refuse to accept a question that

Speaker: NA
Text: is put to him by an honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member? I f no such power exists, and

Speaker: NA
Text: a refusal would constitute a breach

Speaker: NA
Text: the Standing Orders and of the rights

Speaker: NA
Text: and privileges of honorable members, will

Speaker: NA
Text: you, as the custodian and guardian of

Speaker: NA
Text: those rights and privileges, submit to the

Speaker: NA
Text: a Prime Minister a memorandum explain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing their nature? Will you also ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that there shall not be a breach of the

Speaker: NA
Text: rules and procedure of this honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr SPEAKER,-Standin g Order 92

Speaker: NA
Text: provides-

Speaker: NA
Text: After Notices have been given, Questions

Speaker: NA
Text: be put to Ministers of the Crown relating

Speaker: NA
Text: public affairs; and to other Members re-

Speaker: NA
Text: to any Bill, Motion, or other public

Speaker: NA
Text: matter connected with the business on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Notice Paper, of which such Members may

Speaker: NA
Text: have charge.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t will be noted that honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: have the privilege of asking Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: questions. The practice has been for a

Speaker: NA
Text: imMinister either to answer a question

Speaker: NA
Text: orally or to require its submission in writ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, in order that a written reply may

Speaker: NA
Text: be made. I have already informed the

Speaker: NA
Text: be honorable member for Warringah that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is not the slightest doubt that

Speaker: NA
Text: although an honorable member is pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vileged to ask a Minister a question, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister is not bound to answer i t

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Bu t a Minister cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: of prevent an honorable member from ask-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member is answering his own question.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am pointing out to him that nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Prime Minister or any other

Speaker: NA
Text: for Minister may do can prevent an honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: he able member from asking a question. At

Speaker: NA
Text: the same time, every Minister has the

Speaker: NA
Text: right either to answer or to decline to

Speaker: NA
Text: answer it and, should he decline, it would

Speaker: NA
Text: be disorderly were an honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: endeavour to insist upon an immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: DISCHARGED SERVICE

Speaker: NA
Text: PERSONNEL.

Speaker: NA
Text: VOCATIONAL TRAINING-UNIVERSIT Y

Speaker: NA
Text: TRAINING ALLOWANCES.

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: Las t Wednesday, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Wentworth ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Harrison) asked for certain information

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to the vocational training of dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: charged service personnel, and I under-

Speaker: NA
Text: took to furnish it.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! Does the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister desire to read an answer to a

Speaker: NA
Text: question?

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: Yes .

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I have ruled that

Speaker: NA
Text: leave of the House must be obtained in

Speaker: NA
Text: such circumstances.

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: b y leave--The total

Speaker: NA
Text: take it for granted that these come within

Speaker: NA
Text: that category. The position generally is

Speaker: NA
Text: easing considerably, and the public will

Speaker: NA
Text: be satisfied when it realizes what progress

Speaker: NA
Text: is being made.

Speaker: Mr CONELAN
Text: I s the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: representing the Minister for Supply

Speaker: NA
Text: a bushel and Shipping aware that textiles

Speaker: NA
Text: made in Australia, and exported to New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand, are being sold there as having

Speaker: NA
Text: been made in England? Will he take

Speaker: NA
Text: steps to see that those materials are

Speaker: NA
Text: branded " Made in Australia " ?

Speaker: Mr BEASLEY
Text: I am surprised to

Speaker: NA
Text: hear that that is being done, because

Speaker: NA
Text: double weft cloth has been manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tured in Australia for the very purpose

Speaker: NA
Text: of supplying the New Zealand market.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not attempt to hide that fact.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t would have been the duty of any

Speaker: NA
Text: government to endeavour to secure

Speaker: NA
Text: that export trade, and double weft

Speaker: NA
Text: cloth was made for New Zealand when

Speaker: NA
Text: people in our own country were not

Speaker: NA
Text: being supplied with it. I f the goods

Speaker: NA
Text: are being sold as having been made in

Speaker: NA
Text: England, I think that the suggestion that

Speaker: NA
Text: they should be branded " Made in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia " is a wise one, and should be

Speaker: NA
Text: ad'opted.

Speaker: NA
Text: SYDNEY GRAVING DOCK.

Speaker: Mr SHEEHAN
Text: W i l l the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: representing the Minister for the Interior

Speaker: NA
Text: who is responsible for issuing invita-

Speaker: NA
Text: to attend the opening of the Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: graving dock? - Have invitations been

Speaker: NA
Text: issued to representatives of the em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployees? Have arrangements been made

Speaker: NA
Text: to prevent an occurrence similar to that

Speaker: NA
Text: and in which Captain de Groot figured at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Navy, opening of the Sydney harbour bridge?

Speaker: Mr LAZZARINI
Text: I shall obtain the

Speaker: NA
Text: POSTAL DEPARTMENT.

Speaker: Mr MARTENS
Text: I received to-day

Speaker: NA
Text: from Home H i l l a telegram protesting

Speaker: NA
Text: against the refusal of the Postmaster-

Speaker: NA
Text: no General's Department to take mail

Speaker: NA
Text: matter across a river in a boat, with

Speaker: NA
Text: result that a letter posted at

Speaker: NA
Text: Home H i l l for delivery at Ayr, 6

Speaker: NA
Text: miles distant, had to go through Rock-

Speaker: NA
Text: hampton and Winton, the total distance

Speaker: NA
Text: covered being between 1,400 and 1,500

Speaker: NA
Text: miles. Will the Minister representing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Postmaster-General give the reason for

Speaker: NA
Text: this departure from the usual practice in

Speaker: NA
Text: similar circumstances?

Speaker: NA
Text: M"r. CALWELL - I shall bring the

Speaker: NA
Text: complaint to the notice of the Postmaster-

Speaker: NA
Text: General, and shall ask him to give urgent

Speaker: NA
Text: and sympathetic consideration to it.

Speaker: NA
Text: SEED OATS.

Speaker: Mr ADERMANN
Text: I ask the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Commerce and Agriculture

Speaker: NA
Text: whether or not there are any seed oats in

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia. I f there are, will the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government make transport available

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately, in order that the seed may

Speaker: NA
Text: be brought to the eastern States; or

Speaker: NA
Text: dairying industry to understand definitely

Speaker: NA
Text: that no seed is to be made available, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government does not regard the

Speaker: NA
Text: growing of fodder for dairy cattle as of

Speaker: NA
Text: any consequence?

Speaker: Mr SCULLY
Text: I t is a reflection on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government to suggest that it does

Speaker: NA
Text: not desire the growing of feed for dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: stock; that is most essential.

Speaker: NA
Text: information supplied by the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Agriculture in Western Australia is that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is only a limited quantity of oats

Speaker: NA
Text: in that State. Everything possible is

Speaker: NA
Text: being done to have oats brought

Speaker: NA
Text: eastern States for all essential purposes;

Speaker: NA
Text: this seed has even been given priority

Speaker: NA
Text: over wheat. The honorable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: may rest assured that the Government FEASEB-

Speaker: NA
Text: has explored every avenue in its attempts

Speaker: NA
Text: to secure seed, the importance of which

Speaker: NA
Text: it recognizes fully.

Speaker: NA
Text: PILLAGING.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: Wil l the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Supply and Shipping inform the

Speaker: NA
Text: House whether he has read a report from

Speaker: NA
Text: Lae by Brigadier Pascoe to the effect

Speaker: NA
Text: that, of 2,000 cases of beer consigned to

Speaker: NA
Text: troops in that area at Christmas time,

Speaker: NA
Text: over 400 cases were pillaged at Sydney?

Speaker: NA
Text: I f not, will he scrutinize the report, and

Speaker: NA
Text: lay it on the table of the House? Has

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister also received a report that

Speaker: NA
Text: Red Cross supplies of orange juice and

Speaker: NA
Text: other goods directed to troops in that

Speaker: NA
Text: area were similarly pillaged, as were

Speaker: NA
Text: also Red Cross hygiene supplies for

Speaker: NA
Text: nurses? What action does the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment propose to take to put an end to

Speaker: NA
Text: these depredations on goods and com-

Speaker: NA
Text: forts consigned to the troops, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting areas?

Speaker: Mr BEASLEY
Text: Nobod y with any

Speaker: NA
Text: national pride or spirit could be other

Speaker: NA
Text: than disgusted at the pillaging that has

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred in some ports of Australia,, and

Speaker: NA
Text: in other ports throughout the world, of

Speaker: NA
Text: goods destined for the fighting forces. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am sure that there is no difference of

Speaker: NA
Text: opinion between us on this matter, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause no person could stoop to a more

Speaker: NA
Text: despicable action than that referred to;

Speaker: NA
Text: but, unfortunately, pillaging is rife. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government originally set aside a sum

Speaker: NA
Text: of about £200,000 for the purpose of

Speaker: NA
Text: is the building up an organization on the

Speaker: NA
Text: waterfront to meet this problem, but

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately, the trouble is not con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fined to pillaging on the water-

Speaker: NA
Text: f.ront. The origin of the evil is far

Speaker: NA
Text: behind the waterfront. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: believes that goods are pillaged long

Speaker: NA
Text: before they reach the ships' sides. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: do not blame the wharfi labourers alone

Speaker: NA
Text: for what has occurred. I hope that we

Speaker: NA
Text: The shall soon be able to root out those

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for the evil, and expose them

Speaker: NA
Text: to the world at large.

Speaker: NA
Text: to the GOVERNOR-GENERAL'S SPEECH.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADDKESS-IN-REPLY.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from the 9th March

Speaker: NA
Text: (vide page 546), on motion by Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: That the following Address-in-Reply to His

Speaker: NA
Text: Royal Highness the Governor-General s Speech

Speaker: NA
Text: be agreed to:-

Speaker: NA
Text: MAY IT PLEASE YOUB ROYAL HIGHNESS :

Speaker: NA
Text: We, the House of Representatives of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: in Parliament assembled, desire to express

Speaker: NA
Text: our loyalty to our most Gracious Sovereign,

Speaker: NA
Text: to extend to Your Royal Highness a welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia, and to thank Your Royal High-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness for the Speech which you have been

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to address to Parliament.

Speaker: Mr SMITH
Text: Wakefield) [3.0] - I asso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciate myself with the sentiments that have

Speaker: NA
Text: been expressed by honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding the appointment of His Royal

Speaker: NA
Text: Highness the Duke of Gloucester as

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General of the Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: I appreciate the fact that a Labour Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment has shown in a practical way

Speaker: NA
Text: its loyalty to the British Throne by the

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment to that high office of a

Speaker: NA
Text: brother of His Majesty the King. This,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, gives tlie lie direct to those

Speaker: NA
Text: who have been loud in their criticism of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labour party i n saying that its mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers are not loyal subjects of the K i n g .

Speaker: NA
Text: I feel sure that this appointment proves

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond doubt that we are, and always

Speaker: NA
Text: have been, as loyal as any other body,

Speaker: NA
Text: and perhaps more loyal than some. I ,

Speaker: NA
Text: in common with other honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House, trust that the term of office

Speaker: NA
Text: of His Eoyal Highness w i l l be a most

Speaker: NA
Text: pleasant one, and I feel sure that i t w i l l

Speaker: NA
Text: bo. The Prime Minister ( Mr Curtin)

Speaker: NA
Text: rightly said, at the parliamentary dinner

Speaker: NA
Text: tendered to the Governor-General, that i t

Speaker: NA
Text: was a family gathering, meaning, I take

Speaker: NA
Text: it, that f r o m now on we should regard

Speaker: NA
Text: His Eoyal Highness as one of ourselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure that he will feel as much at

Speaker: NA
Text: home with us as we shall be w i th h i m .

Speaker: NA
Text: I trust that his wish fo r world peace to be

Speaker: NA
Text: restored during his stay amongst us w i l l

Speaker: NA
Text: be realized.

Speaker: NA
Text: I express my pleasure at the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister has been able to take

Speaker: NA
Text: up his important duties again. I trust

Speaker: NA
Text: that his health w i l l remain sufficiently

Speaker: NA
Text: robust to enable h i m to continue his excel-

Speaker: NA
Text: lent leadership of this country. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sorry to hear that at present he is slightly

Speaker: NA
Text: indisposed, but I am. pleased to know

Speaker: NA
Text: that he is not seriously i l l . I hope the

Speaker: NA
Text: people realize the tremendous responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility which he has had to shoulder dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the trying years i n which he has been

Speaker: NA
Text: in office. No doubt his onerous duties

Speaker: NA
Text: its Prime Minister have been the greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: contributing factor to the undermining

Speaker: NA
Text: of his health. I wonder sometimes, when

Speaker: NA
Text: hearing certain criticism of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, whether the people f u l l y realize tlie

Speaker: NA
Text: true value of the work which the present

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministry has done during the greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: crisis i n the world's history. The job i3

Speaker: NA
Text: not yet finished, but, when listening to

Speaker: NA
Text: the remarks of some honorable members,

Speaker: NA
Text: one would imagine that the war was a

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary matter. They ask for the

Speaker: NA
Text: transfer of man-power, speak of a wastage

Speaker: NA
Text: of man-power, and allege that too many

Speaker: NA
Text: men are i n the fighting forces. They

Speaker: NA
Text: say that many of those men could be

Speaker: NA
Text: employed more profitably i n other direc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. That, of course, would be a fact

Speaker: NA
Text: if we could direct the operations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: enemy.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I was passing a fire brigade

Speaker: NA
Text: station a few days ago, I saw men stand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing around seemingly with, nothing to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: But would any honorable member con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tend that the brigade should be disbanded

Speaker: NA
Text: because of that fact? Of course not. A

Speaker: NA
Text: similar position arises with regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting forces. The Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: rightly pointed out that the disposition

Speaker: NA
Text: and use of Australia's fighting forces have

Speaker: NA
Text: been agreed to by the H i g h Command.

Speaker: NA
Text: Surely that position could not be i m -

Speaker: NA
Text: proved upon. Certainly we i n this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber, not knowing all of the facts, are

Speaker: NA
Text: not competent to pass judgment as to

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the best use is being made of

Speaker: NA
Text: those forces. Some honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: have had the audacity to do so, but only

Speaker: NA
Text: for the purpose of furthering their own

Speaker: NA
Text: political ends. I n that respect they are

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to play the game of politics

Speaker: NA
Text: pretty low. The Leader of tlie Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion ( Mr Menzies), speaking i n this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate of the operations upon which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian forces were engaged i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific Islands, said-

Speaker: NA
Text: Tlie role allotted to the Australian forces

Speaker: NA
Text: since the drive began is the secondary role of

Speaker: NA
Text: mopping up by-passed areas which, as I under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand it, cannot be regarded any longer as of

Speaker: NA
Text: primary military moment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Flinders

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Ryan) is recorded i n Hansard as

Speaker: NA
Text: having said-

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not forget these things when I say that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian troops have been relegated to the

Speaker: NA
Text: role of charwoman of the Pacific, mopping up

Speaker: NA
Text: the mess left behind as the front oi battle

Speaker: NA
Text: moved forward.

Speaker: NA
Text: Very properly, the members of our forces

Speaker: NA
Text: who have returned f r o m the north have

Speaker: NA
Text: taken exception to statements of that

Speaker: NA
Text: kind. I n the Melbourne Herald of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 8th of this month, the following

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared:-

Speaker: NA
Text: Thirty walking wounded Army and Air

Speaker: NA
Text: Force men, who returned by flying boat from

Speaker: NA
Text: the islands, ridiculed recent public statements

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australian military operations were con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fined to mopping up.

Speaker: NA
Text: "Nothing made us more mad than to get

Speaker: NA
Text: reports from home saying we have been rele-

Speaker: NA
Text: gated to mopping-up operations", said one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the soldiers. " I would like to organize

Speaker: NA
Text: a patrol of politicians who have been making

Speaker: NA
Text: these statements."

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Such statements were made i n this House

Speaker: NA
Text: for one reason only. I am certain that

Speaker: NA
Text: those who made them, did not intend to

Speaker: NA
Text: reflect on our forces, but they were using

Speaker: NA
Text: them for political ends. Unfortunately

Speaker: NA
Text: for them, their statements have rebounded

Speaker: NA
Text: to their own political disadvantage.

Speaker: NA
Text: "When this was brought to the attention

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Leader of the Opposition, he

Speaker: NA
Text: said-

Speaker: NA
Text: The point that we have made is that this

Speaker: NA
Text: appears to he a secondary i-ole.

Speaker: NA
Text: That qualification was not used when the

Speaker: NA
Text: original statement was made. I t is only

Speaker: NA
Text: natural that our soldiers, who are doing

Speaker: NA
Text: such a wonderful job in the north, should

Speaker: NA
Text: take exception to remarks of the kind

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have quoted.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members of the Opposition are very

Speaker: NA
Text: fond of recalling tbe result of the recent

Speaker: NA
Text: referendum for the enlargement of Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth powers. The spate of propa-

Speaker: NA
Text: ganda released during the referendum

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign by those who objected to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's proposals appealed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: selfishness and fear of the people, who

Speaker: NA
Text: were war-weary, and had become tired of

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations. They were led to believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that if they voted against the referendum

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals, they could, and would, get rid

Speaker: NA
Text: of war-time controls almost immediately.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a matter of fact, war-time controls

Speaker: NA
Text: were imposed and kept in operation for

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefit of the (people, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: am convinced that they will eventually

Speaker: NA
Text: realize that fact. Of course, mistakes

Speaker: NA
Text: were made, and it is probable that more

Speaker: NA
Text: will be made in the future. Perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: officers did not always discharge their

Speaker: NA
Text: duties in a way to inspire confidence, but,

Speaker: NA
Text: for the most part, they have done a diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cult job well. We have not had to go

Speaker: NA
Text: without any essential commodity. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: course of my travels, I have seen no one

Speaker: NA
Text: who was cold or hungry. Indeed, never

Speaker: NA
Text: have I, in all my experience, seen the

Speaker: NA
Text: people so prosperous, and my memory

Speaker: NA
Text: goes back over a good many years, during

Speaker: NA
Text: which time I have seen many ups and

Speaker: NA
Text: downs in Australia. When I read letters

Speaker: NA
Text: from people in England and Scotland,

Speaker: NA
Text: where they have to go without the most

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary things, while at the same time

Speaker: NA
Text: being subjected to the danger of bomb-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, I realize that we in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: should, in the words of the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, go down on our knees and thank God

Speaker: NA
Text: that, in the main, we have been spared

Speaker: NA
Text: thus far. This is due, first, to the sacri-

Speaker: NA
Text: fice of the Mother Country, and then to

Speaker: NA
Text: the timely assistance given to Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Smith.

Speaker: NA
Text: by the United States of America. I well

Speaker: NA
Text: remember that when the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: took action to obtain assistance from the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America, there was an

Speaker: NA
Text: outcry from a certain class of person in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia that the Labour Government

Speaker: NA
Text: was disloyal, and that the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: was slighting the Mother Country. At

Speaker: NA
Text: that time, the Prime Minister knew per-

Speaker: NA
Text: fectly well that Great Britain, which was

Speaker: NA
Text: undergoing a terrible ordeal in fighting

Speaker: NA
Text: the battle for world freedom, could not

Speaker: NA
Text: help us. Therefore, he appealed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America, which came to

Speaker: NA
Text: our aid. When our men came back from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Middle East, I watched company

Speaker: NA
Text: after company marching through the

Speaker: NA
Text: streets of Adelaide, and I remember the

Speaker: NA
Text: feeling of security which the spectacle

Speaker: NA
Text: gave to the public. As the Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister said, Australia was saved by the

Speaker: NA
Text: help of Great Britain and of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America, and by the sacrifice

Speaker: NA
Text: of our own gallant men, who placed their

Speaker: NA
Text: bodies between us and the enemy. We

Speaker: NA
Text: can never thank those men enough for

Speaker: NA
Text: what they did for us and for civilization.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have heard people use the phrase

Speaker: NA
Text: " equality of sacrifice ". There can be

Speaker: NA
Text: no sacrifice equal to that made by men

Speaker: NA
Text: who give their lives. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: supreme sacrifice.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last week honorable members had the

Speaker: NA
Text: privilege of hearing the Minister for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Navy ( Mr Makin) give an account of

Speaker: NA
Text: what one unit of the " silent service"

Speaker: NA
Text: had done in this war. What a record

Speaker: NA
Text: of gallantry on the ipart of men who go

Speaker: NA
Text: down to the sea in ships! Their deeds

Speaker: NA
Text: and their names will live in history.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those men gave their all-thei r lives.

Speaker: NA
Text: In view of all the circumstances, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: clear that the regulations which have

Speaker: NA
Text: been promulgated, and the restrictions

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Government in its wisdom has

Speaker: NA
Text: seen fit to impose, have been for the

Speaker: NA
Text: preservation of the people of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and the good of the nation; and,

Speaker: NA
Text: accordingly, we should accept them un-

Speaker: NA
Text: complainingly, and do all that we can

Speaker: NA
Text: to carry them out. I n this connexion,

Speaker: NA
Text: the press could play a helpful part. The

Speaker: NA
Text: newspapers of this country could be a

Speaker: NA
Text: powerful factor in maintaining the

Speaker: NA
Text: morale of the people, but I fear that

Speaker: NA
Text: they have not been so helpful as they

Speaker: NA
Text: might have been. Take, for instance,

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper references to troubles i n tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: coal-mining industry. Every day we

Speaker: NA
Text: read bow much coal has ibeen lost because

Speaker: NA
Text: of actions of the coal-miners, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the public gets the impression that these

Speaker: NA
Text: men are intent on sabotaging .the war

Speaker: NA
Text: effort. One honorable member said i n

Speaker: NA
Text: this House that coal-miners who would

Speaker: NA
Text: not work should be taken f r o m the mines

Speaker: NA
Text: and put i n the f r o n t line; i n other

Speaker: NA
Text: words, that they should be short. M y

Speaker: NA
Text: experience as an employee and as an

Speaker: NA
Text: employer convinces me that that is not

Speaker: NA
Text: the way ,to get the best out of men.

Speaker: NA
Text: Goal-mining is not attractive work, and

Speaker: NA
Text: in the main, the coal-miners of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country have done well. Like other

Speaker: NA
Text: people, they are much more likely to

Speaker: NA
Text: give their best when they are encouraged

Speaker: NA
Text: and given credit for the services that

Speaker: NA
Text: they have rendered. A t various times

Speaker: NA
Text: the Premier of South Australia has said

Speaker: NA
Text: that, unless more coal were provided,

Speaker: NA
Text: train services would have to be curtailed

Speaker: NA
Text: and restrictions imposed on the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: electric light and power, and f r o m time

Speaker: NA
Text: to time the dwindling stocks of coal have

Speaker: NA
Text: been featured i n the newspapers of that

Speaker: NA
Text: State. Nevertheless, train services have

Speaker: NA
Text: been maintained, and there have been

Speaker: NA
Text: no restrictions on the use of electricity

Speaker: NA
Text: for domestic purposes. The needs of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people have been met. Propaganda of

Speaker: NA
Text: that kind is not i n the best interests

Speaker: NA
Text: an all-in war effort.

Speaker: NA
Text: I listened with interest to the speech

Speaker: NA
Text: of the right honorable memiber f o r Cow-

Speaker: NA
Text: per ( Sir Earle Page), i n which he ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pressed his ideas concerning the need

Speaker: NA
Text: for water conservation. I agree w i th

Speaker: NA
Text: him that something of that kind

Speaker: NA
Text: should be done, but, fo r the most

Speaker: NA
Text: part, he referred to projects within the

Speaker: NA
Text: sphere of the States-work s which, as he

Speaker: NA
Text: well knows, the Commonwealth Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has no power to undertake. To

Speaker: NA
Text: the uninitiated the proposals of the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman may sound all right,

Speaker: NA
Text: hut those who know how he opposed the

Speaker: NA
Text: granting of further powers to the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth realize that his speech was

Speaker: NA
Text: merely so much " kite-flying".

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable gentleman also men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned housing needs, but what did the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government of which he was a member,

Speaker: NA
Text: and other governments which he sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported, do to supply the needs when

Speaker: NA
Text: labour and material were available i n

Speaker: NA
Text: abundance? 'Can he say how many

Speaker: NA
Text: houses were built under the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth housing scheme ? Although many

Speaker: NA
Text: national works could have been under-

Speaker: NA
Text: taken i n those years, nothing was done;

Speaker: NA
Text: previous governments preferred to give

Speaker: NA
Text: men the dole rather than opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: to work.

Speaker: NA
Text: The right honorable gentleman and

Speaker: NA
Text: other honorable members opposite advo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cate an active immigration policy; their

Speaker: NA
Text: slogan is, " Populate or perish". I

Speaker: NA
Text: agree that Australia needs a much larger

Speaker: NA
Text: population, but something more than the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy which has been followed i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: past is necessary to that end. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: have passed through country towns and

Speaker: NA
Text: villages I have missed many once-

Speaker: NA
Text: thriving industries; they no longer exist,

Speaker: NA
Text: because those who control industry find

Speaker: NA
Text: it, cheaper to concentrate their businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: in the metropolitan areas. " B i g busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness " has crushed out competition, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the result is seen in deserted country

Speaker: NA
Text: towns and villages. I n the past, many

Speaker: NA
Text: primary .producers have not been able

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay their way. I t has taken a war

Speaker: NA
Text: and a Labour government to give some

Speaker: NA
Text: stability to primary production. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: reminded of what the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for I n d i ( Mr MCEwen) once said when

Speaker: NA
Text: of he was a Minister in a former govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment-

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia could not afford to {guarantee

Speaker: NA
Text: more tlian 3s. ]0d. a bushel f.o.b., which,

Speaker: NA
Text: on the basis of guaranteed .production, is

Speaker: NA
Text: equal to approximately 3s. a bushel at sidings.

Speaker: NA
Text: He went on to say that a war expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture of £70,000,000 would not permit i t .

Speaker: NA
Text: To-day, war expenditure is at the rate, of

Speaker: NA
Text: over £400,000,000 a year. The present

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Menzies)

Speaker: NA
Text: visited Adelaide i n September, 1939,

Speaker: NA
Text: when he was Prime Minister, and was

Speaker: NA
Text: reported i n the Adelaide Advertiser as

Speaker: NA
Text: having said-

Speaker: NA
Text: With £32,000,000 needed for defence, I can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not see how I am goinig to raise money for

Speaker: NA
Text: the wheat -industry, either by loan or from

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue.

Speaker: NA
Text: The The present Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: in the 'Senate, Senator MCLeay, when

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Commerce, announced that

Speaker: NA
Text: he favoured the nayment of 2s. 10-id. a

Speaker: NA
Text: bushel fo r bagged wheat. That repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented approximately 2s. 6d. a bushel

Speaker: NA
Text: at country sidings. On that occasion,

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator MCLeay said-

Speaker: NA
Text: I earnestly say that these financial pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posals represent not only a fair, but a

Speaker: NA
Text: generous, nipiproach to the problem by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the same subject, the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: memiber for Barker ( Mr Archie

Speaker: NA
Text: Cameron) said-

Speaker: NA
Text: In my opinion, the .price is too high. I

Speaker: NA
Text: confess frankly that I have not been enthusi-

Speaker: NA
Text: astic ,'tliout any whe/it stabilization scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: To-day those men are telling the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia that the present Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment lias let the primary producers down.

Speaker: NA
Text: By whom this broadcast statement Avas

Speaker: NA
Text: authorized, I cannot remember-

Speaker: NA
Text: We cannot continue to provide largo sums

Speaker: NA
Text: of public money to support the wheat-growers

Speaker: NA
Text: while they go on producing unsaleable grain.

Speaker: NA
Text: Such a procedure would be demoralizing and

Speaker: NA
Text: unsound.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition, speaking

Speaker: NA
Text: at a meeting on one occasion, said words

Speaker: NA
Text: to the effect that farmers never paid a

Speaker: NA
Text: decent wage. That is not the farmer's

Speaker: NA
Text: fault. He is the creature of circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stance. Always at the mercy of financial

Speaker: NA
Text: interests, he has never controlled his own

Speaker: NA
Text: business. He had no control over the

Speaker: NA
Text: price of the goods he produced, and this

Speaker: NA
Text: city concentration has been a disadvan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tage to him and to the nation. I f we

Speaker: NA
Text: are to develop this country and increase

Speaker: NA
Text: its population, we must have greater re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gard for human values than we have had.

Speaker: NA
Text: We must be prepared, with other nations,

Speaker: NA
Text: to practise the principles of the Atlantic

Speaker: NA
Text: Charter: Freedom from fear, freedom

Speaker: NA
Text: from want, freedom of speech and free-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom of worship. Those ideals offer some

Speaker: NA
Text: hope to the human race, and i f they are

Speaker: NA
Text: realized they will give this nation an

Speaker: NA
Text: incentive to expand, confident that its

Speaker: NA
Text: future is assured.

Speaker: NA
Text: .If the primary producers of this

Speaker: NA
Text: munity are to succeed-we should make

Speaker: NA
Text: that possible for them as there is

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow of doubt that they are of the

Speaker: NA
Text: first importance to the country-the

Speaker: NA
Text: mortgage branch of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank must give advances at a much

Speaker: NA
Text: lower rate of interest than at present;

Speaker: NA
Text: alternatively, we must create a producers'

Speaker: NA
Text: hank. Of all the evils afflicting the

Speaker: NA
Text: primary producer, the mortgage is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Smith.

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest, because its demands must be

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied before he can satisfy the barest

Speaker: NA
Text: needs of himself and his dependants and

Speaker: NA
Text: because it forces him to work his soil

Speaker: NA
Text: without rest. While the farmer must,

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to meet heavy annual interest

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments, continue to deny his soil

Speaker: NA
Text: the rest that Nature ordains, we shall

Speaker: NA
Text: never be able effectively to grapple with

Speaker: NA
Text: the twin problems of maintaining soil

Speaker: NA
Text: fertility and preventing soil erosion.

Speaker: NA
Text: I u this chamber last September, I

Speaker: NA
Text: showed that soil erosion is one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: most urgent problems which this

Speaker: NA
Text: country has to face, and I hope that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Soil Conservation Ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice, the proposed establishment of

Speaker: NA
Text: which has been announced by the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Commerce and Agriculture ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Scully), will be set up without delay in

Speaker: NA
Text: order that it may speedily take up its

Speaker: NA
Text: task, which, I consider, should also em-

Speaker: NA
Text: brace water conservation and re-afforesta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. More than ever before is the heed

Speaker: NA
Text: evident for an authority to undertake

Speaker: NA
Text: those three tasks in the interests not

Speaker: NA
Text: only of ourselves but also of posterity.

Speaker: NA
Text: We live from our soils. Depleted soil

Speaker: NA
Text: vigour means depleted human vigour and

Speaker: NA
Text: unfertile soil an unfertile people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Destroy the soil and you destroy the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation. A nation with 60 per cent, of its

Speaker: NA
Text: population living in cities under arti-

Speaker: NA
Text: ficial conditions of life, will not repro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce in sufficient numbers to maintain

Speaker: NA
Text: a natural life. Keep only sufficient on

Speaker: NA
Text: the land to feed the population in the

Speaker: NA
Text: cities and then denature the foodstuffs

Speaker: NA
Text: by refining and preservation, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: result must be national extinction.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rural areas are the only sure source of

Speaker: NA
Text: population increase. A natural affinity

Speaker: NA
Text: exists between man and the soil; remove

Speaker: NA
Text: him from contact with freshly grown

Speaker: NA
Text: foods and he becomes as stale as the

Speaker: NA
Text: food he consumes. Our need is to dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: comtribute our population over the more

Speaker: NA
Text: fertile areas of our land on smaller

Speaker: NA
Text: not a holdings. To that eud the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: octopus that is strangling the life out

Speaker: NA
Text: of our nation must be grappled with.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because primary production is the life-

Speaker: NA
Text: stream of this nation, the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank, through its mortgage department

Speaker: NA
Text: or a producers' bank, should purchase -

Speaker: NA
Text: all banks and privately held mortgages on

Speaker: NA
Text: land used for primary production, and

Speaker: NA
Text: interest should be reduced to a flat rate

Speaker: NA
Text: of 11 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: I make it quite clear to those who

Speaker: NA
Text: have written to me protesting against

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's banking proposals

Speaker: NA
Text: that they have a perfect right to exby

Speaker: NA
Text: press their opinions on that or any assuming

Speaker: NA
Text: other subject, but that they must give

Speaker: NA
Text: me the same right. Most of the protests

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. have received were prepared for those matter,

Speaker: NA
Text: who signed them by the banks or other

Speaker: NA
Text: financial interests. I have no hesitation

Speaker: NA
Text: in saying that because, for the most part,

Speaker: NA
Text: the phrasing of the letters is identical. and

Speaker: NA
Text: Those from the same district are written

Speaker: NA
Text: on the same class of paper and contained

Speaker: NA
Text: in similar envelopes. I n contrast to years

Speaker: NA
Text: the stereotyped protests sent to me, I which

Speaker: NA
Text: received from a farmer constituent of

Speaker: NA
Text: mine, who is not obliged to go cap in

Speaker: NA
Text: hand to the bank for an overdraft, a destruction.

Speaker: NA
Text: letter from which the following is an

Speaker: NA
Text: extract:-

Speaker: NA
Text: I am anxiously waiting for the bank legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation. I hope i t will go through. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: for a fact that many who had petitions placed

Speaker: NA
Text: under their noses to sign, signed because

Speaker: NA
Text: under the banks' thumb,, they dare not refuse,

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise they be asked to reduce their over-

Speaker: NA
Text: draft, so if I were in your place I would take

Speaker: NA
Text: the petitions for what they are worth.

Speaker: NA
Text: [Extension of lime granted.']

Speaker: NA
Text: When I sought the suffrages of my con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituents at the last general election I

Speaker: NA
Text: gave them a pledge that i f I and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party I supported were returned

Speaker: NA
Text: to office I should make it one of my first

Speaker: NA
Text: duties to advocate banking reform. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: well pleased that I now have the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to address myself to this sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: ject so soon after the Treasurer ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Chifley) has introduced the measures

Speaker: NA
Text: embodying the Government's proposals

Speaker: NA
Text: for banking reform. I have not yet failed

Speaker: NA
Text: to honour any pledge which I have given,

Speaker: NA
Text: and, regardless of the consequences to

Speaker: NA
Text: myself personally, I have no intention of

Speaker: NA
Text: retracting the promise which I gave to

Speaker: NA
Text: my constituents in respect of this subject.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fortunately, I am not wholly dependent

Speaker: NA
Text: upon my parliamentary salary for a

Speaker: NA
Text: livelihood. However, the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals are in the best interests of the

Speaker: NA
Text: country. On this matter I agree entirely

Speaker: NA
Text: with the views expressed in the follow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing letter, dated the 20th January last,

Speaker: NA
Text: which I received from one of my con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituents who is a returned soldier of the

Speaker: NA
Text: last war, and whose name I shall be

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to supply to any who might doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: the authenticity of the communication:-

Speaker: NA
Text: I am enclosing printed matter I received

Speaker: NA
Text: post which I consider an insult to my

Speaker: NA
Text: intelligence and yours. I t insults me in

Speaker: NA
Text: that I am unable to express my own

Speaker: NA
Text: views on the question, and insults you in

Speaker: NA
Text: assuming that you would believe this printed

Speaker: NA
Text: i f signed by me, to represent my own

Speaker: NA
Text: considered opinion.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am a returned soldier of 1914-18 War and

Speaker: NA
Text: have two sons in the services to-day (my only

Speaker: NA
Text: other son is sixteen years of age). I sincerely

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that the men who are lighting to-dny,

Speaker: NA
Text: those already discharged, will not have to

Speaker: NA
Text: face the difficulties which confronted many of

Speaker: NA
Text: us on our return to civil life and during the

Speaker: NA
Text: which followed. I t is a tragic policy

Speaker: NA
Text: assures us that we cannot expect to be

Speaker: NA
Text: as prosperous when all are producing for use

Speaker: NA
Text: as when the majority of our men are engaged

Speaker: NA
Text: in destruction or producing the means of

Speaker: NA
Text: ' I trust that never again will financial in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terests be able to bring about economic depres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion, while abundance of all the necessities of

Speaker: NA
Text: life exist alongside extreme poverty, simply

Speaker: NA
Text: through withholding the medium which enables

Speaker: NA
Text: a man to exchange his labour or produce for

Speaker: NA
Text: being goods or services on an equitable basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those are the views of people who have

Speaker: NA
Text: come through the mill. I am not a

Speaker: NA
Text: financier, and I do not claim to under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand finance in the full sense of the

Speaker: NA
Text: word; but I know something about the

Speaker: NA
Text: operations of the present banking system,

Speaker: NA
Text: and as the result of that experience I am

Speaker: NA
Text: anxious that the Government's proposals

Speaker: NA
Text: shall be enacted assoon as possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the Leader of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion ( Mr Menzies) was addressing a

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting as part of the preliminaries

Speaker: NA
Text: in the formation of the new Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: party he said in effect, according

Speaker: NA
Text: to press reports of his remarks, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour caucus was composed of ignorant

Speaker: NA
Text: and irresponsible men. I am surprised

Speaker: NA
Text: that a cultured man like the right honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentleman should cast such asper-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions on honorable members on this side

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House. As a member of the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment party I take strong exception

Speaker: NA
Text: to those remarks. They remind me of

Speaker: NA
Text: the speech made by the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Cowper ( Sir EarlePage)

Speaker: NA
Text: when he was Prime Minister- I think he

Speaker: NA
Text: held the office for one day-i n which he

Speaker: NA
Text: attacked the present Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition, and the reply made by the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition on that occasion i n

Speaker: NA
Text: which he likened the attack made upon

Speaker: NA
Text: him to a stream of mud. Judging from

Speaker: NA
Text: his recent attack upon members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government party to which I have just

Speaker: NA
Text: referred, i t would appear that the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition did not escape un-

Speaker: NA
Text: contaminated, because to-day he is indulg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing i n tactics similar to those of which

Speaker: NA
Text: he accused the right honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Cowper. I n his unfair and unjust

Speaker: NA
Text: reference to honorable members on this

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the chamber he is himseif casting

Speaker: NA
Text: mud. However, abuse is not argument;

Speaker: NA
Text: and, again, I express surprise that a man

Speaker: NA
Text: of the attainments of the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman should descend to such tactics.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure that they w i l l react against

Speaker: NA
Text: him and the party he now leads.

Speaker: NA
Text: repeat, that I am pledged to support the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's banking proposals.

Speaker: NA
Text: letters which I wrote recently to my con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituents I pointed out that the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: paganda being disseminated throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: the country to-day i n the interests of the

Speaker: NA
Text: banks and other financial institutions is

Speaker: NA
Text: similar to that circulated throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia when the Fisher Government

Speaker: NA
Text: brought down its proposals f or the estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lishment of the Commonwealth Bank.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of my constituents, an ex-banker,

Speaker: NA
Text: replied that I was wrong i n the views I

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed, but I have taken the oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to refresh my memory of the

Speaker: NA
Text: happenings at that time. I consulted

Speaker: NA
Text: the files of the Adelaide Register f or

Speaker: NA
Text: 1911 which at that time was one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: leading newspapers i n the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth. I n the issue of that paper dated

Speaker: NA
Text: the 17th November of that year, when

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Bank B i l l was at the

Speaker: NA
Text: second-reading stage, I found the follow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing leading article, which honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members no doubt w i l l perceive bears a

Speaker: NA
Text: close resemblance to the leading articles

Speaker: NA
Text: now being published i n the Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: Herald and the Sydney Sun:- _

Speaker: NA
Text: If a Com monwealth Bank is not required,

Speaker: NA
Text: it will be an expensive encumbrance fraught

Speaker: NA
Text: with possibilities of serious mischief to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. The proposal to create the bank un-

Speaker: NA
Text: justly conveys an implied reflection upon the

Speaker: NA
Text: business capacities of Australians, because it

Speaker: NA
Text: i3 undeniable that the banking facilities in

Speaker: NA
Text: existence are excellent in character and ample

Speaker: NA
Text: in scope. Obviously, if the savings of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people are to be diverted to federal purposes,

Speaker: NA
Text: the State Government will be gravely handi-

Speaker: NA
Text: enpped. Their difficulties in floating loans will

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Smith.

Speaker: NA
Text: be increased, and consequently higher rates

Speaker: NA
Text: of interest will be demanded. The federal

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme may also lead to a material increase

Speaker: NA
Text: iu the interest rates for accommodation on

Speaker: NA
Text: mortgages and other securities, and thus in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volve loss to the whole community.

Speaker: NA
Text: I recall that, i n 1920, interest rates on

Speaker: NA
Text: second mortgages were between 8 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, and 10 per cent, and on first mort-

Speaker: NA
Text: gages, 7^ per cent. The extract con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinued-

Speaker: NA
Text: From the standpoint of international law, a

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank is open to objection-b y

Speaker: NA
Text: no means merely academic-o n account of

Speaker: NA
Text: being indirectly a menace to peace. Regula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions under the Hague Convention expressly

Speaker: NA
Text: enact that " private property cannot be confis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated ". They safeguard the moneys of a

Speaker: NA
Text: private bank and enable its credit to endure,

Speaker: NA
Text: even through a military disaster; but clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: show that the resources of a State bank might

Speaker: NA
Text: I be confiscated by a raiding expedition.

Speaker: NA
Text: In The article concluded-

Speaker: NA
Text: If there is a genuine demand for the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Bank-an d there has been no sig"i

Speaker: NA
Text: of it-

Speaker: NA
Text: The same objection is voiced to the

Speaker: NA
Text: banking proposals of the present Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment-

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . that demand proceeds from a section

Speaker: NA
Text: of the public who imagine that the institution

Speaker: NA
Text: will deal " generously" with them. Appa-

Speaker: NA
Text: rently, therefore, if the bank is to satisfy its

Speaker: NA
Text: most ardent advocates, i t will precipitate a

Speaker: NA
Text: financial disaster, in which the fair name of

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole Commonwealth may be besmirched.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those comments appeared i n the Register

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1911. To-day, the Register is only a

Speaker: NA
Text: memory, but the Commonwealth Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: is a monument to the Fisher Government

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Commonwealth of Australia. I

Speaker: NA
Text: wholeheartedly commend the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's banking proposals.

Speaker: NA
Text: The views expressed by the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister on international affairs and

Speaker: NA
Text: agreements w i l l have widespread support.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f Australia is selfishly to devote itself

Speaker: NA
Text: solely to its own interests and disregard

Speaker: NA
Text: the rights of other countries, the prospect

Speaker: NA
Text: of preserving peace i n the future w i l l be

Speaker: NA
Text: remote indeed. I conclude w i th an ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tract f r o m an article i n the Reader'*

Speaker: NA
Text: Digest of January, 1944, by Mr W i l l i a m

Speaker: NA
Text: Hard, who was writing on the subject of

Speaker: NA
Text: American internationalism-

Speaker: NA
Text: If this world means to have peace, i t must

Speaker: NA
Text: first have economic well-being. I do not say

Speaker: NA
Text: that prosperity insures peace. I do say that

Speaker: NA
Text: poverty and depression are the biggest danger

Speaker: NA
Text: to peace.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those words admirably express my

Speaker: NA
Text: own views. One nation cannot enjoy

Speaker: NA
Text: economic security while other nations

Speaker: NA
Text: have a very low standard of living. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: we put into practice the principles of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Atlantic Charter, the future of nations,

Speaker: NA
Text: including Australia, will be assured.

Speaker: Mr LEMMON
Text: Forrest) [4.50] -O n rural industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of the electors of Forrest, I desire

Speaker: NA
Text: to extend a welcome to His Royal HighGeneral's

Speaker: NA
Text: ness the Governor-General, the Duchess,

Speaker: NA
Text: and their f amily. When I listened to

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General's Speech, the member

Speaker: NA
Text: sitting next to me remarked: " This is an

Speaker: NA
Text: historic occasion". After His Royal

Speaker: NA
Text: Highness had concluded his Speech, I

Speaker: NA
Text: commented: "This is an historic occatralia

Speaker: NA
Text: sion for two reasons. The first is that

Speaker: NA
Text: His Royal Highness is the first member

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Royal Family to become Governorcompelled

Speaker: NA
Text: General of the Commonwealth of Ausshortage

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. The second is that the Speech

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrates that this Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: already, to a certain degree, given effect

Speaker: NA
Text: to the promises which it made to the

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the fighting forces and the

Speaker: NA
Text: civilian population". The Curtin Goto-day.

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment is the only administration in

Speaker: NA
Text: the world which has already tackled the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem of rehabilitation while the nation

Speaker: NA
Text: is still at war. Therefore, I consider that

Speaker: NA
Text: the opening of the third session of

Speaker: NA
Text: 17th Parliament will be historic.

Speaker: NA
Text: The seventeenth paragraph of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General's Speech stated that-

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's role in allied strategy has

Speaker: NA
Text: for a major effort in the feeding of the

Speaker: NA
Text: iirmics of liberation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The next paragraph declared that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's annual expenditure on food

Speaker: NA
Text: for the services now exceeds £100,000,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because of the gigantic task that

Speaker: NA
Text: has been allotted to Australia, I

Speaker: NA
Text: take this opportunity to pay a tribute

Speaker: NA
Text: to the primary producers of this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proportion of enlistments from

Speaker: NA
Text: Section was higher than that from any

Speaker: NA
Text: other section of the community. When

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia was threatened with invasion

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Japanese, many sons of farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: enlisted i n the services, and their fathers, introduced.

Speaker: NA
Text: who had ceased active farming two or

Speaker: NA
Text: three years before, again assumed the

Speaker: NA
Text: management of the properties. I n doing

Speaker: NA
Text: they have rendered . excellent service. other States ?

Speaker: NA
Text: Proof of that is to be found in the manner

Speaker: NA
Text: in which they have maintained produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I was gratified to learn that in June

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government will reconsider the

Speaker: NA
Text: present allocation of man-power; and I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that a large percentage of men

Speaker: NA
Text: released from the services or from indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try later this year will be diverted to

Speaker: NA
Text: Paragraph 19 of the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: Speech announced that Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia had been compelled , to import grain,

Speaker: NA
Text: the and members of the Country party have

Speaker: NA
Text: confidently asserted that the Scully wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme was responsible for that situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: To disprove their statements, I take the

Speaker: NA
Text: only other period in the history of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: that compared with the present-

Speaker: NA
Text: time, namely, 1914. That year was the

Speaker: NA
Text: last occasion on which Australia was

Speaker: NA
Text: to import grain. There was no

Speaker: NA
Text: of man-power or superphosphate

Speaker: NA
Text: and no restrictions had been imposed on

Speaker: NA
Text: production. The explanation was that

Speaker: NA
Text: drought had ruined the crops. For ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: actly the same reason, the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is obliged to import grain

Speaker: Mr HOLT
Text: Wh y was the wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: acreage restricted in Western Australia?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr LEMMON" -Whe n acreage re-

Speaker: NA
Text: striction in Western Australia was first

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed, a representative of Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian wheat-growers came to Can-

Speaker: NA
Text: berra. That representative was no other

Speaker: NA
Text: than Mr Teasd'ale, of whom the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Barker ( Mr Archie

Speaker: NA
Text: called Cameron) and the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Indi spoke as the most able wheat expert

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia. Mr Teasdale implored the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to introduce a complete

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat-growing holiday in Western Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. His view was that not a bushel

Speaker: NA
Text: of wheat should be grown in that State.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, the Western Australian wheat-

Speaker: NA
Text: growers regarded that recommendation

Speaker: NA
Text: as too drastic. The Minister for Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: this merce and Agriculture ( Mr Scully)
