Speaker: NA
Text: listened to their plea, and restricted

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat-growing to one-third of the basic

Speaker: NA
Text: acreage. That is the reason why the one-

Speaker: NA
Text: third reduction in Western Australia was

Speaker: Mr HOLT
Text: Doe s the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber not think that the differing rates have

Speaker: NA
Text: so the effect of reducing production in the

Speaker: Mr LEMMON
Text: N o t at all. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: have said, this country is short of wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day because of the reduced quantities

Speaker: NA
Text: of superphosphate available during the

Speaker: NA
Text: last three years and because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: drought. I n some of the best wheat-

Speaker: NA
Text: producing lands i n the Commonwealth-

Speaker: NA
Text: I am referring to certain wheat-growing

Speaker: NA
Text: areas in the eastern States-ther e has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a drought f o r two years. Last year,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Commerce and Agricul-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture said that farmers who had suffered

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the drought should endeavour

Speaker: NA
Text: to sow twice their former acreage.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to refer now to the action of

Speaker: NA
Text: tlie honorable member f o r I n d i i n pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: claiming to the country that there had

Speaker: NA
Text: been a " £10,000,000 wheat steal". The

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member's propaganda methods

Speaker: NA
Text: in this regard are similar to those em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployed by Dr Goebbels i n Germany,

Speaker: NA
Text: namely, the use of half-truths and mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: statements which, i n effect, are the

Speaker: NA
Text: blackest of lies. I shall analyse briefly

Speaker: NA
Text: what he calls the wheat "steal". When

Speaker: NA
Text: he first made his allegations on the 14th

Speaker: NA
Text: September, 1944, he said-

Speaker: NA
Text: A comparison of tlie estimated return from

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat which will be sold in Australia prior

Speaker: NA
Text: to 1945-46 harvest under the present policy,

Speaker: NA
Text: with the valuation of that wheat at present

Speaker: NA
Text: export value-fo r I - am willing to accept

Speaker: NA
Text: lis. Od. as a fair value-wil l show that in

Speaker: NA
Text: the next eighteen months the wheat-growers

Speaker: NA
Text: will bo the victims of a wheat "steal" of

Speaker: NA
Text: Two months later, the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber made another statement, i n which he

Speaker: NA
Text: quoted remarks by Mr Teastlale, whom

Speaker: NA
Text: lie admits to be a wheat expert, and

Speaker: NA
Text: whom I know to be well informed not

Speaker: NA
Text: only on the wheat position i n Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: but also i n regard to' the wheat markets

Speaker: NA
Text: of the world. The honorable member,

Speaker: NA
Text: referring to Mr Teasdale, said-

Speaker: NA
Text: If the amount to be paid by the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Wheat Board to bridge the gap between

Speaker: NA
Text: the concessional price for stock-feed and the

Speaker: NA
Text: average export realization be taken as the

Speaker: NA
Text: correct principle, then the Government will

Speaker: NA
Text: liiLve to pav to the board approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: £8,850,000. If, on the other hand, the

Speaker: NA
Text: realization of wheat sold in the free market

Speaker: NA
Text: east of Suez be taken as a basis, then the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, to do justice to the grower, will

Speaker: NA
Text: need to pay in approximately £9,850,000 on

Speaker: NA
Text: sicroiint of the two pools 0 and 7.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n effect the honora'ble member said,

Speaker: NA
Text: " I f the Government had. taken the pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent realization for wheat that the board

Speaker: NA
Text: sold two years ago . . . " Using

Speaker: NA
Text: that argument I could say that five years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago I sold 2,000 bags of wheat to Louis

Speaker: NA
Text: Dreyfus and Company Limited f o r 2s.

Speaker: NA
Text: a bushel, and i n the next year the price

Speaker: NA
Text: of wheat .rose to 5s. a bushel, therefore

Speaker: NA
Text: Louis Dreyfus and Company Limited

Speaker: NA
Text: stole that extra 3s. a bushel from me.

Speaker: NA
Text: That, of course, is ridiculous, yet i t is

Speaker: NA
Text: the basis of the argument advanced by

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable memiber i n support of the

Speaker: NA
Text: alleged "wheat steal". B u t let me

Speaker: NA
Text: examine this contention a little further.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bearing i n mind that the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member had said on the 14th September

Speaker: NA
Text: that the wheat " steal" would take place

Speaker: NA
Text: in the ensuing eighteen months, i t is

Speaker: NA
Text: interesting to note that two months later

Speaker: NA
Text: -he said-

Speaker: NA
Text: My estimate of £10,000,000 includes the

Speaker: NA
Text: succeeding No. 8 pool.

Speaker: NA
Text: There he alleges that the wheat " steal"

Speaker: NA
Text: goes back two years to the Nos. 6 and 7

Speaker: NA
Text: pools, and includes also the No. 8 pool.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then he changes his ground again, and

Speaker: NA
Text: says-

Speaker: NA
Text: Thus it is shown quite clearly by one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the best informed and most experienced wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: experts in the country that on the item of

Speaker: NA
Text: stock feed sales alone the wheat-growers have

Speaker: NA
Text: been mulct of at least £10,000,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: First he quoted Mr Teasdale's figure of

Speaker: NA
Text: £6,S00,000, and then almost i n the same

Speaker: NA
Text: breath he said that i n his opinion the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount would 'he £10,000,000. The posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is as the Government has stated,

Speaker: NA
Text: namely, that i n regard to stock feed a

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidy w i l l be paid to bring the return

Speaker: NA
Text: up to the realization price of the pool.

Speaker: NA
Text: That, of course, removes the whole basis

Speaker: NA
Text: of the honorable member's argument.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, he is still not satisfied. A l -

Speaker: NA
Text: though he finds that his argument is

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely wrong, he persists i n talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about the alleged " steal ", and he adopts

Speaker: NA
Text: another basis of argument. This time

Speaker: NA
Text: he has enlisted the support of Mr Coles,

Speaker: NA
Text: the president of the Farmers and Settlers

Speaker: NA
Text: Association of New South Wales. Now,

Speaker: NA
Text: current apparently, the " steal" is based on

Speaker: NA
Text: this argument which he addresses to

Speaker: NA
Text: the growers: " The Australian Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is only offering you 4s. 3d. a

Speaker: NA
Text: bushel, siding basis, for your wheat,

Speaker: NA
Text: whilst the Government of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America is offering 9s. 6d. a

Speaker: NA
Text: bushel, the Canadian Government 5s. 9d.

Speaker: NA
Text: a 'bushel, and the Government of Argen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tina 4s. 6d. a bushel". But let us

Speaker: NA
Text: examine those figures. I n the first place,

Speaker: NA
Text: the American Government is not guaran-

Speaker: NA
Text: teeing wheat-growers 9s. 6d. a bushel, but

Speaker: NA
Text: Ss. 5-Jd. a bushel on the basis of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian currency. Although it is true

Speaker: NA
Text: that at a later date-probabl y some time

Speaker: NA
Text: this year-th e price will go up to 9s. 6d.,

Speaker: NA
Text: the American figures cannot be taken

Speaker: NA
Text: as parallel values. For instance, a

Speaker: NA
Text: haircut in the United States of America

Speaker: NA
Text: costs a dollar i n Australian currency,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it would be just as logical for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian barbers to say: "We are

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled to charge 6s. 6d. for a hair-

Speaker: NA
Text: cut, because that is the price ruling in

Speaker: NA
Text: America". Actually there cannot 'he

Speaker: NA
Text: any such comparison of basic values. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States of America is prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: to chase inflation I have no intention of

Speaker: NA
Text: assisting this country to do so. I n regard

Speaker: NA
Text: to Canada the system of wheat deliveries

Speaker: NA
Text: is entirely different from that applying

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia. The Canadian farmer has

Speaker: NA
Text: to store his own wheat. I n Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: the farmer strips his wheat, delivers i

Speaker: NA
Text: tho sidings and is paid for it. I n Canada,

Speaker: NA
Text: a farmer who strips a crop averaging

Speaker: NA
Text: IS bushels to the acre may be told to

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver one-sixth of the yield immedi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ately. A month later he may be told to

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver a similar quantity. This instal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment delivery may go on for nine or ten

Speaker: NA
Text: months, and during this time the quality

Speaker: NA
Text: of the wheat deteriorates. I f it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: fair average quality when i t is brought

Speaker: NA
Text: to scales, the dock is taken by the farmer.

Speaker: NA
Text: He has to pay the cost of storage and he

Speaker: NA
Text: loses the interest on the delayed realiza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for the period during which the

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat has been stored. Often he has to

Speaker: NA
Text: cart his wheat through snow. This system

Speaker: NA
Text: costs money to the farmer and requires

Speaker: NA
Text: extra man-power. The honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Indi took no consideration of these

Speaker: NA
Text: facts when he made his comparisons. The

Speaker: NA
Text: last country he mentioned was Argentina.

Speaker: NA
Text: That country should .provide a reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: comparison with Australia, having regard

Speaker: NA
Text: to the proportion of its wheat that is

Speaker: NA
Text: exported and the relationship of wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: to the national economy. The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member said that the price in Argen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tina is 4s. 6d. a bushel on a siding

Speaker: NA
Text: basis. That is incorrect. Argentina has

Speaker: NA
Text: established a price of 4s. 6d. a bushel

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered at ports. I f we make a fair

Speaker: NA
Text: comparison, we find that Australia guar-

Speaker: NA
Text: antees a price of 5s. 3d. a bushel at

Speaker: NA
Text: ports.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are the supposed parallels which

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable memiber for Indi has used

Speaker: NA
Text: in an endeavour to incite the farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: to march on Canberra. What is the

Speaker: NA
Text: motive behind all this propaganda? I t

Speaker: NA
Text: is nothing more than an endeavour by

Speaker: NA
Text: the stooges of the merchants to smash

Speaker: NA
Text: organized marketing in this country. I .

Speaker: NA
Text: appeal to my fellow farmers not to heed

Speaker: NA
Text: such utterances. They should stick to

Speaker: NA
Text: the policy which has been enunciated by

Speaker: NA
Text: their organizations ever since they were

Speaker: NA
Text: first formed. They should recall the

Speaker: NA
Text: story of tlie dog and the bone, and not

Speaker: NA
Text: drop the substance for the shadow. The

Speaker: NA
Text: International Wheat Agreement will

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure stability of prices, which will in

Speaker: NA
Text: turn provide security for the farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: and their families. By maintaining a

Speaker: NA
Text: system of organized marketing, the

Speaker: NA
Text: growers will retain a solid foundation

Speaker: NA
Text: t to for their industry. I f they accept the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy of the so-called representatives of

Speaker: NA
Text: the farmers, who are actually doing the

Speaker: NA
Text: work of the private merchants, they will

Speaker: NA
Text: be forced to accept a fleeting price for

Speaker: NA
Text: their product and they will be at the

Speaker: NA
Text: mercy of the international wheat specu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lator.

Speaker: NA
Text: His Royal Highness the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General also referred to the task of

Speaker: NA
Text: rehabilitating anemibers of the fighting

Speaker: NA
Text: forces. I was very pleased to hear this

Speaker: NA
Text: afternoon from the Minister for Supply

Speaker: NA
Text: and Shipping that Australia is already

Speaker: NA
Text: exporting double-weft cloth to New Zea-

Speaker: NA
Text: land. The Government will be respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible for finding markets for many things

Speaker: NA
Text: which we are able to manufacture in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. I was also gratified to hear

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Minister for Commerce and

Speaker: NA
Text: Agriculture ( Mr Scully) proposed to

Speaker: NA
Text: introduce a bill dealing with wool, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that arrangements have been made by

Speaker: NA
Text: the British Ministry of Food to take

Speaker: NA
Text: 34,000 cases of apples from Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia for England this year, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that it will endeavour to increase that

Speaker: NA
Text: number to 72,000 cases. These facts

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate that the Government is already

Speaker: NA
Text: preparing plans for post-war recon-

Speaker: NA
Text: struction. I was also impressed

Speaker: NA
Text: favorably when. I heard the right honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Cowper (' Sir Earle

Speaker: NA
Text: Page) and the honorable memiber for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kalgoorlie ( Mr Johnson) ably expound

Speaker: NA
Text: the importance of water conservation and

Speaker: NA
Text: reticulation in Australia. Projects such

Speaker: NA
Text: as these and the standardization of rail-

Speaker: NA
Text: way gauges ar<j national works which are

Speaker: NA
Text: the direct responsibility of this Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I hope that, in order to handle

Speaker: NA
Text: these tasks, the Government will preserve

Speaker: NA
Text: the nucleus of the Civil Constructional

Speaker: NA
Text: Corps on the basis of voluntary enlist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in the years of peace. We can

Speaker: NA
Text: vise its experience and the modern

Speaker: NA
Text: machinery which it possesses in carrying

Speaker: NA
Text: many of our post-war plans into effect.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope also that the Government will

Speaker: NA
Text: give a high priority to the linking of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Indian Ocean with the Pacific Ocean

Speaker: NA
Text: by a standard gauge railway passing

Speaker: NA
Text: through the national capital. I disagree

Speaker: NA
Text: with the attitude of the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Denison (Dr Gaha) towards

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra, because I consider that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government should endeavour to do away

Speaker: NA
Text: with State parochialism and endea-

Speaker: NA
Text: vour to develop a national outlook.

Speaker: NA
Text: One way in which it can help to do

Speaker: NA
Text: this is by establishing a standard gauge

Speaker: NA
Text: railway linking Canberra with all States.

Speaker: NA
Text: The settlement of ex-servicemen on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Land was also referred to by His Royal

Speaker: NA
Text: Highness the Governor-iGeneral.

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaking has greater pitfalls than

Speaker: NA
Text: this. We must learn from the tragedies

Speaker: NA
Text: of the past in dealing with this problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: The complete loss to all governments in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia involved by the land settlement

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes which followed rthe war of

Speaker: NA
Text: 1914-18 was £45,000,000, representing an

Speaker: NA
Text: average loss of £1,200 in respect of every

Speaker: NA
Text: soldier settler. I do not quibble at the

Speaker: NA
Text: penditure of the money, but that loss must

Speaker: NA
Text: be an indication of the broken hopes of

Speaker: NA
Text: the men who returned from the war and

Speaker: NA
Text: tried to start life afresh on the land.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not want to see a repetition of that

Speaker: NA
Text: tragic story as the result of allowing

Speaker: NA
Text: our boys to settle on over-capitalized

Speaker: NA
Text: holdings and eventually to find them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves in a condition of debt and despair.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Wheat and Wool Growers Union of

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia recently appointed a

Speaker: NA
Text: vigilance committee, which already is

Speaker: NA
Text: doing good work to prevent a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: currence of past mistakes. A soldier

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Lemmon.

Speaker: NA
Text: who returned not long ago had

Speaker: NA
Text: between £600 and £700 with which

Speaker: NA
Text: he wanted to buy a block of land.

Speaker: NA
Text: He knew nothing about land, and he did

Speaker: NA
Text: not want assistance from the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: He proposed to purchase an abandoned

Speaker: NA
Text: farm 16 miles from the rail-head, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: country was such that he could not pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibly make a success of the enterprise.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee induced him not to go on

Speaker: NA
Text: with it, knowing that if he did so he

Speaker: NA
Text: must lose his money, and break his heart

Speaker: NA
Text: too. When they approached a certain

Speaker: NA
Text: State officer who had recommended the

Speaker: NA
Text: property, he told us that it was no

Speaker: NA
Text: concern of ours; if the soldier had

Speaker: NA
Text: the money he could go ahead and

Speaker: NA
Text: buy the land. I hope that this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will take action to prevent men from

Speaker: NA
Text: making mistakes of the kind that this

Speaker: NA
Text: soldier so nearly made. Men should ibe

Speaker: NA
Text: prevented from entering into commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments which can end only in bankruptcy,

Speaker: NA
Text: and in worry to themselves and their

Speaker: NA
Text: families.

Speaker: NA
Text: Steps should be taken to arrange for

Speaker: NA
Text: the use of modern machinery to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: in farming operations. An organization

Speaker: NA
Text: should be set up to control modern plant

Speaker: NA
Text: that would be used to put farms into a

Speaker: NA
Text: state of production before soldier settlers

Speaker: NA
Text: took possession. Here is an example of

Speaker: NA
Text: what can be achieved by such means:

Speaker: NA
Text: No With the use of government rollers,

Speaker: NA
Text: timber was rolled on a certain area for

Speaker: NA
Text: 10s. an acre, and the clearing up was

Speaker: NA
Text: done for another 5s. an acre, making a

Speaker: NA
Text: total of 15s. To have cut that timber

Speaker: NA
Text: with the axe would have cost 35s. an acre,

Speaker: NA
Text: and burning and clearing up would prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: ably have cost another 15s. Similar

Speaker: NA
Text: economies can be achieved in the making

Speaker: NA
Text: exof dams for the - conservation of water.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I started farming, we used to make

Speaker: NA
Text: dams with .a scoop and a. team of horses,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it cost £75 to rake out 1,000 yards.

Speaker: NA
Text: In later years tractors were used instead

Speaker: NA
Text: of teams, and thereby the cost was re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced to £45. To-day, by the use of a

Speaker: NA
Text: bulldozer, a similar dam can be excavated

Speaker: NA
Text: for £10. I f suitable machinery be, used

Speaker: NA
Text: under supervision there need not be any

Speaker: NA
Text: financial loss on soldier settlement.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope that once the men are placed

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the farms, local committees of ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: perienced men will be set up to assist and

Speaker: NA
Text: advise them. I n the past, the policy was

Speaker: NA
Text: to appoint as advisers to soldier settlers

Speaker: NA
Text: men who had academic qualifications-

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps they were bachelors of agricul-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture-bu t they lacked practical experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence. Such men were deputed to advise

Speaker: NA
Text: the settler how to grow wheat or to run

Speaker: NA
Text: a dairy farm. The fact is that when a

Speaker: NA
Text: man leaves the university he knows noth-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing about farming-h e has only got ready

Speaker: NA
Text: to begin learning. The man who knows

Speaker: NA
Text: something about farming is he who

Speaker: NA
Text: has been on the land for ten, fifteen, or

Speaker: NA
Text: twenty years. When I left the agri-

Speaker: NA
Text: cultural college, I thought I understood

Speaker: NA
Text: farming. Now, after I have been farm-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for seventeen years, I realize that I

Speaker: NA
Text: am only beginning to learn something

Speaker: NA
Text: aboii t it. These committees of experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: enced men should tell the new settler

Speaker: NA
Text: what land ought to be cleared for

Speaker: NA
Text: cultivation, and what land should be left

Speaker: NA
Text: under timber, and they should advise the

Speaker: NA
Text: settler generally on his farming opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. I n this way many of the problems

Speaker: NA
Text: which bepet soldier settlers after the last

Speaker: NA
Text: war would never arise.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have heard during this debate many

Speaker: NA
Text: references to the declining birthrate in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, and the need for a greater

Speaker: NA
Text: population. Some speakers have asserted

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australia could support a population

Speaker: NA
Text: of as many as 100,000,000. I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: if there is a continuation of dust storms

Speaker: NA
Text: -whic h arise from wind erosion-an d of

Speaker: NA
Text: water erosion, which is the washing away

Speaker: NA
Text: of the soil in our fertile valleys, and

Speaker: NA
Text: silting up of our rivers we shall be for-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunate if, 50 years hence, Australia can

Speaker: NA
Text: support a population of 10,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: people. I t is possible that soil

Speaker: NA
Text: erosion, unless something be done to

Speaker: NA
Text: check it, will eventually convert much

Speaker: NA
Text: of the fertile wheat lands of South Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, Victoria and New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: into a sandy waste. Soil erosion is much

Speaker: NA
Text: more dangerous to the future of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: than are the bombs falling on Berlin to

Speaker: NA
Text: the future of Germany. The destruction

Speaker: NA
Text: of a city represents no more than the

Speaker: NA
Text: waste of labour and of concrete and steel.

Speaker: NA
Text: The damage can be quickly repaired, but

Speaker: NA
Text: when we lose the top layer of soil from

Speaker: NA
Text: our countryside, we lose the work of

Speaker: NA
Text: nature over centuries. This top layer of

Speaker: NA
Text: fertile soil, which is being blown away

Speaker: NA
Text: in dust storms, consists of decomposed

Speaker: NA
Text: or oxidized rock, plus humus, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: decayed animal and vegetable matter that

Speaker: NA
Text: has been acted on by bacteria. These

Speaker: NA
Text: minute organisms, which can be detected

Speaker: NA
Text: only by the microscope, are present in

Speaker: NA
Text: humus in enormous numbers, and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: they which maintain the balance and pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductivity of the soil. They create organic

Speaker: NA
Text: matter which distinguishes the top soil,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is productive, from the sub-soil,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is non-productive. I f Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: goes on losing this top layer of soil,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is being blown out over the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Ocean, and sometimes even gets as far

Speaker: NA
Text: as New Zealand, where it becomes a valu-

Speaker: NA
Text: able top-dressing for pastures, there will

Speaker: NA
Text: be a gradual decline of productivity.

Speaker: NA
Text: Crops will yield less, pastures will become

Speaker: NA
Text: poor so that they will carry fewer stock,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the stock themselves will be of poorer

Speaker: NA
Text: quality. They will become less resistant

Speaker: NA
Text: to disease, and will have less food value.

Speaker: NA
Text: Erosion is tending all the time to destroy

Speaker: NA
Text: the balance which nature maintains in the

Speaker: NA
Text: soil. I t removes chemical properties

Speaker: NA
Text: which are necessary in plant life, i f those

Speaker: NA
Text: plants are to nourish healthy animals.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is hardly necessary for me to remind

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members that age-old Egyptian

Speaker: NA
Text: cities are to-day choked with sand as the

Speaker: NA
Text: result of soil erosion, because the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of ancient times, in their ignorauce,

Speaker: NA
Text: robbed the soil instead of farming it, thus

Speaker: NA
Text: upsetting the balance of Nature. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Roman Empire made a desert of North

Speaker: NA
Text: Africa in the very same way. I n recent

Speaker: NA
Text: the years, we have the spectacle of the dust

Speaker: NA
Text: bowl of the United States of America,

Speaker: NA
Text: caused by the exploitation of the soil, not

Speaker: NA
Text: through ignorance, but under economic

Speaker: NA
Text: pressure. Are we in Australia to remain

Speaker: NA
Text: blind to these lessons? I think not.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know the reasons for soil erosion.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is caused, in the main, by economic

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions which lead to the exploitation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the soil through over-cropping and

Speaker: NA
Text: over-stocking. A good deal is due to the

Speaker: NA
Text: instability of markets which force

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers to depart, from sound prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciples of farming, aud to follow unsound

Speaker: NA
Text: methods in order to get a higher return

Speaker: NA
Text: in the immediate future so as to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: their financial commitments. The remedy

Speaker: NA
Text: does not lie in giving lectures, or in

Speaker: NA
Text: exhibiting films, or in distributing

Speaker: NA
Text: pamphlets, or in radio broadcasts. I t lies

Speaker: NA
Text: in practical demonstrations by officers of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Agricultural Departments, and in the

Speaker: NA
Text: improvement of economic conditions in

Speaker: NA
Text: marginal farming areas so that -men may

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to make farming pay while still

Speaker: NA
Text: following good farming practices. I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government will set up an autho-

Speaker: NA
Text: rity under the Council for Scientific and

Speaker: NA
Text: Industrial Eesearch for the purpose of

Speaker: NA
Text: collating the researches carried out by

Speaker: NA
Text: the various State Departments of Agri-

Speaker: NA
Text: culture.

Speaker: NA
Text: [Extension of time granted.]

Speaker: NA
Text: To sum up, I suggest that the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pulsory wheat pool should be continued,

Speaker: NA
Text: with a guaranteed minimum price, in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to provide stability in the post-war

Speaker: NA
Text: period for primary producers. The Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment should establish a 'Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Wheat Eesearch Institute under

Speaker: NA
Text: the direction of the Council for Scientific

Speaker: NA
Text: and Industrial Eesearch, for the purpose

Speaker: NA
Text: of improving the milling qualities of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian wheat. I t should maintain .a

Speaker: NA
Text: nucleus of the Civil Constructional

Speaker: NA
Text: Corps as an organization on a voluntary

Speaker: NA
Text: basis to tackle tho post-war .job of land

Speaker: NA
Text: settlement, standardization of railway

Speaker: NA
Text: gauges, and water conservation and .re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticulation. We should use local knowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: for advising soldier settlers, on methods

Speaker: NA
Text: of cultivation, and to advise themwhich

Speaker: NA
Text: areas should be left under timber because,

Speaker: NA
Text: if they were cleared, they would erode.

Speaker: NA
Text: AVe should set up a Commonwealth com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission under the Department of Post-

Speaker: NA
Text: war Eeconstruction to tackle soil erosion

Speaker: NA
Text: on a national basis. These practical sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gestions will, I hope, be of assistance to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government when i t is preparing

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation to give effect to the policy

Speaker: NA
Text: outlined in the Speech of the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General.

Speaker: Mr RIORDAN
Text: Kennedy) [5.27] - I

Speaker: NA
Text: support the motion, and I join with other

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members in welcoming to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia their Eoyjal Highnesses, the Duke

Speaker: NA
Text: and Duchess of Gloucester, and the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of their family. I trust that their

Speaker: NA
Text: stay here will be enjoyable, and that when

Speaker: NA
Text: they leave they will carry away with

Speaker: NA
Text: them many happy memories.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Governor-General, in his Speech;

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned the drought which has caused

Speaker: NA
Text: such serious loss in many parts of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth. The problem of drought

Speaker: NA
Text: is not a new otic in Australia. I t may

Speaker: NA
Text: be said to be a part of our heritage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Every year some part of Australia is

Speaker: NA
Text: affected by drought. When the country

Speaker: NA
Text: is gripped by a severe drought, much is

Speaker: NA
Text: said and written about the need, to take

Speaker: NA
Text: precautions to meet such a situation; but

Speaker: NA
Text: when the rains come, all proposals for

Speaker: NA
Text: grappling with the problem are put on

Speaker: NA
Text: one side and forgotten till drought recurs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Only last year, this Parliament voted

Speaker: NA
Text: money for the relief of drought-stricken

Speaker: NA
Text: areas, but the people in many parts of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia which are subject to drought

Speaker: NA
Text: received no assistance from the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth or from the State governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n time of drought hundreds of families

Speaker: NA
Text: are ruined by conditions over which they

Speaker: NA
Text: have no control, but those conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: might be controlled or mitigated by go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment action. This Parliament should

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with the matter as a national

Speaker: NA
Text: problem, or it could act in association

Speaker: NA
Text: with the State governments. I t is my

Speaker: NA
Text: earnest wish that the National Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment should deal with the problems of

Speaker: NA
Text: drought and soil erosion in a national

Speaker: NA
Text: way. The present Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: already improved the lot of a considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: section of the people, but I now appeal

Speaker: NA
Text: to it to give serious consideration to the

Speaker: NA
Text: need for investigation of all proposals

Speaker: NA
Text: advanced for the purpose of mitigating

Speaker: NA
Text: the effects of drought. During the last

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentary sittings great duststorms,

Speaker: NA
Text: the like of: which had never previously

Speaker: NA
Text: been experienced, occurred in certain

Speaker: NA
Text: parts of Australia. I t Was stated by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Forrest ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Lemmon) that those storms carried away

Speaker: NA
Text: the top soil of fertile farms in Victoria

Speaker: NA
Text: and New South Wales, much of whicli

Speaker: NA
Text: was blown into the ocean. The question

Speaker: NA
Text: has been asked whether there is a dust

Speaker: NA
Text: bowl in Australia. I am convinced that -

Speaker: NA
Text: there is, and that it is centred in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Lake Eyre district in Central Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sand from that area has been blown into

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland and New South Wales, and

Speaker: NA
Text: even Victoria has been affected. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia, many farmers have been

Speaker: NA
Text: forced to lea've their homes because of. the

Speaker: NA
Text: sand deposited by means o£ windstorms.

Speaker: NA
Text: The brown soil plains in the gibber

Speaker: NA
Text: country are interspersed at intervals of

Speaker: NA
Text: many chains, and, in some places,

Speaker: NA
Text: miles, with sand dunes from which the

Speaker: NA
Text: sand is moving in the direction of New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales and South Australia, and

Speaker: NA
Text: even the pastoral areas of Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: and Victoria are threatened. Those men

Speaker: NA
Text: who are courageous enough to work on

Speaker: NA
Text: the frontiers of Australia for the purpose

Speaker: NA
Text: of carrying on primary production are

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned about the approach of this

Speaker: NA
Text: sand from the Lake Eyre district.

Speaker: NA
Text: The late Dr Bradfield left valuable

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals for the improvement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: position. He achieved an international

Speaker: NA
Text: reputation, and has left many monuments

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia, one of which is his. scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: for the preservation of our heritage by

Speaker: NA
Text: mitigating the effects of drought and thus

Speaker: NA
Text: saving the people of this country many

Speaker: NA
Text: millions of pounds. I f no action be

Speaker: NA
Text: taken to grapple with the problem of soil

Speaker: NA
Text: erosion, the present devastation will

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue until the more fertile portions

Speaker: NA
Text: of the continent are affected. The time

Speaker: NA
Text: is longoverdue for a complete investi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gation of Dr Bradfield's proposals. They

Speaker: NA
Text: were not hurriedly prepared. He himself

Speaker: NA
Text: declared that for 30 years he had given

Speaker: NA
Text: thought to the problem, having ridden

Speaker: NA
Text: through most of the northern portion of

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland on horseback, and walked

Speaker: NA
Text: over a great area of the country. He came

Speaker: NA
Text: to the conclusion that water which now

Speaker: NA
Text: runs to waste into the Pacific Ocean

Speaker: NA
Text: on the eastern side of the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Dividing Range in far northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland, should be diverted to the

Speaker: NA
Text: western portion of that State. That

Speaker: NA
Text: would make a greatly increased popula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion possible in that part of Queensland,

Speaker: NA
Text: and lead to the preservation of the pas-

Speaker: NA
Text: toral industry. The Battle for the I n -

Speaker: NA
Text: land, written by P. R. V. Timbury,

Speaker: NA
Text: should be read by every honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber. The scheme outlined by Dr Brad-

Speaker: NA
Text: field appears as an appendix to that

Speaker: NA
Text: Timbury refers not only to the Bradfield

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme, but also to the proposals in Ion

Speaker: NA
Text: Idriess' book, The Great Boomerang,

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: take action to implement those schemes.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope that the Government will, as

Speaker: NA
Text: soon as possible, appoint a committee,

Speaker: NA
Text: if not a royal commission, of expert and

Speaker: NA
Text: practical men for the purpose of investi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gating the proposals of Bradfield and

Speaker: NA
Text: Idriess. Timbury's book is a. valuable

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution to the literature dealing

Speaker: NA
Text: with the development of this continent.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: recalls the valuable work done by the
