Speaker: NA
Text: heard it suggested that water should

Speaker: NA
Text: be pumped from New Guinea to central

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. I am not qualified either to

Speaker: NA
Text: support or to oppose such a scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bradfield proposed to divert 5,000,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: tons of water annually into western

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland, and Idriess proposed the

Speaker: NA
Text: diversion of a further 5,000,000,000 tons.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t has been argued that the building of

Speaker: NA
Text: a tunnel would present difficulties. There

Speaker: NA
Text: are tunnels i n other parts of the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: The St. Gothard tunnel is 9£ miles in

Speaker: NA
Text: length, and the iSimplon tunnel has a

Speaker: NA
Text: length of 12$ miles. American engineers

Speaker: NA
Text: have tunnelled under the Hudson River,

Speaker: NA
Text: and through the Rockies and the Andes.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n Colorado, water has been diverted into

Speaker: NA
Text: the arid Montrose district, through a

Speaker: NA
Text: number ofi tunnels 6 miles in length. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: India, the Solani acqueduct, 65 yards

Speaker: NA
Text: wide, carries the Ganges canal over the

Speaker: NA
Text: Solani River. I n Russia, Moscow and

Speaker: NA
Text: other inland towns have become seaports

Speaker: NA
Text: by virtue of the construction of canals

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Baltic to the Black Sea. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Tennessee dam, constructed by the Ten-

Speaker: NA
Text: nessee Valley Authority, was financed

Speaker: NA
Text: wholly by the Government of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America. I n the Tennessee

Speaker: NA
Text: valley the water is backed up for 1,100

Speaker: NA
Text: miles. The height of the highest dam is

Speaker: NA
Text: 800 feet, and that of the lowest is 300

Speaker: NA
Text: the drop of 500 feet being spread over

Speaker: NA
Text: 650 miles. The objects of the schemes

Speaker: NA
Text: propounded by Bradfield and Idriess were,

Speaker: NA
Text: to minimize the effects of drought by

Speaker: NA
Text: conserving rainfall, halt, the extension

Speaker: NA
Text: of the dust bowl by preventing soil

Speaker: NA
Text: erosion, and above all assist the develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the inland portions of the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinent. I f an investigation of them, led

Speaker: NA
Text: to a favorable report being made, no

Speaker: NA
Text: time should be lost in implementing them.

Speaker: NA
Text: "We know full well that there are difficul-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties of man-power and supply. I f these

Speaker: NA
Text: are insuperable at present, this should be

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the first post-war projects to be

Speaker: NA
Text: put in hand. I am confident that

Speaker: NA
Text: an investigation would establish the

Speaker: NA
Text: soundness and worth of the proposals.

Speaker: NA
Text: The average Australian rainfall is

Speaker: NA
Text: about 18 inches; 32 per cent, of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia has a rainfall of more than

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 inches, 32 per cent, an average of from

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 inches to 20 inches, and about 36

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent, under 10 inches. I f other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries can undertake such schemes,

Speaker: NA
Text: we should be prepared to do likewise.

Speaker: NA
Text: Diversion of waters as suggested by Brad-

Speaker: NA
Text: field and Idriess would make possible the

Speaker: NA
Text: irrigation of some of the best pastoral

Speaker: NA
Text: lands of Queensland, which will grow

Speaker: NA
Text: anything. I know the country thoroughly.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t has open rolling downs, with black

Speaker: NA
Text: soil feet thick in some portions of it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n other parts, the soil is a sandy loam.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been informed by one who ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to be able to speak authoritatively that

Speaker: NA
Text: the area through which this water would

Speaker: NA
Text: pass is much more fertile than the area

Speaker: NA
Text: served by the Tennessee valley dam. Yet

Speaker: NA
Text: we are hesitant, because the estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of the project is about £30,000,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Year in and year out, millions of pounds

Speaker: NA
Text: is lost as the result o£ drought, and

Speaker: NA
Text: millions of acres of land is blown to sea.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f these schemes were implemented, those

Speaker: NA
Text: who are carrying on the pastoral indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try would be able to plant and conserve

Speaker: NA
Text: fodder, and they would not feel the effects

Speaker: NA
Text: of drought as they do to-day, when i t is

Speaker: NA
Text: not possible for them to secure the water

Speaker: NA
Text: that they need, or to be assured of rain-

Speaker: NA
Text: fall which would enable fodder crops to

Speaker: NA
Text: be harvested. Agriculture could be

Speaker: NA
Text: developed in country which to-day is

Speaker: NA
Text: devoted wholly and solely to pastoral

Speaker: NA
Text: feet, pursuits. We have seen what has hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pened at Griffith and Leeton, where the

Speaker: NA
Text: supply of water led to the springing up

Speaker: NA
Text: of new towns and the establishment of

Speaker: NA
Text: new industries. We mouth platitudes

Speaker: NA
Text: about the decentralization of population

Speaker: NA
Text: and industry after the war, but I know

Speaker: NA
Text: that development along those lines is

Speaker: NA
Text: part and parcel of the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: post-war policy. The inland is crying

Speaker: NA
Text: out for development. Timbury, in his

Speaker: NA
Text: book, appeals to the people of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia to realize that they are facing a

Speaker: NA
Text: calamity. I f effect were given to the

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes proposed by these two great

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians, we should go a long way

Speaker: NA
Text: towards mitigating the effects of any

Speaker: NA
Text: impending calamity. Decentralization

Speaker: NA
Text: of population would follow. The drift

Speaker: NA
Text: of population from western Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: has been very marked for a long period.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f water were diverted to the west, that

Speaker: NA
Text: portion of the continent would be revita-

Speaker: NA
Text: lized, and population would return to it.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should also be able to sustain a policy

Speaker: NA
Text: of migration, and carry out works of

Speaker: NA
Text: vital national importance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

Speaker: Mr RIORDAN
Text: Ther e is a great

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage of houses throughout the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth. I can speak feelingly on

Speaker: NA
Text: this subject because I myself have been

Speaker: NA
Text: ti victim of that shortage. Much has

Speaker: NA
Text: been said and written on the subject, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I am aware that the demand on our

Speaker: NA
Text: timber stocks for defence purposes is so

Speaker: NA
Text: great that timber has to be imported.

Speaker: NA
Text: .1 know, too, that there is a great shortage

Speaker: NA
Text: of building trade workers, due to the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that so many artisans are either in the

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting services or are engaged on high

Speaker: NA
Text: priority defence work. By the time that

Speaker: NA
Text: the present shortage of 300,000 houses is

Speaker: NA
Text: met, probably another 200,000 will be

Speaker: NA
Text: required. [Extension of time granted.]

Speaker: NA
Text: I realize that in time of war. the para-

Speaker: NA
Text: mount consideration must be the defence

Speaker: NA
Text: of the country, but in time of peace the

Speaker: NA
Text: first consideration should be the health

Speaker: NA
Text: and well-being of the community. Proper

Speaker: NA
Text: housing is essential to a healthy nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I well recall a conversation which I had

Speaker: NA
Text: some years ago with Dr Watson Brown,

Speaker: NA
Text: who was then practising at Longreach,

Speaker: NA
Text: in western Queensland. He told me that

Speaker: NA
Text: he had carried out an investigation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: health of the children in western Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land, and in the course of our talk he

Speaker: NA
Text: pictured the conditions under which

Speaker: NA
Text: women in northern and western Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: hind had to live and work in corrugated

Speaker: NA
Text: iron cottages. I n the summer time,

Speaker: NA
Text: when the temperature is high, the cook-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of a meal on a hot stove is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: pleasant job. The appalling housing

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions which exist in many of the

Speaker: NA
Text: outback parts of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: should be remedied, and I am glad that

Speaker: NA
Text: the present Government proposes to

Speaker: NA
Text: tuekle this problem in a national way

Speaker: NA
Text: by the introduction of a Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: housing scheme. Some years ago the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce-Page Government won an election

Speaker: NA
Text: on its promise to provide houses for

Speaker: NA
Text: the people. I t is true that legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: was passed, but nothing was done to

Speaker: NA
Text: implement it. The present Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has not only promised to provide houses

Speaker: NA
Text: for those in need of them, but i t has also

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed a Housing Commission to pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pare a practicable housing scheme. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: members of that body visited north

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland, but unfortunately they did

Speaker: NA
Text: not visit the western part of that State.

Speaker: NA
Text: L'n my opinion, housing conditions in

Speaker: NA
Text: western Queensland should be investi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gated, and I appeal to the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to arrange for that to be done. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: designing houses it is important that

Speaker: NA
Text: the district in which they are to

Speaker: NA
Text: be erected shall be considered. Many

Speaker: NA
Text: architects with a knowledge of cli-

Speaker: NA
Text: matic conditions in and around Brisbane

Speaker: NA
Text: may know nothing of the conditions which

Speaker: NA
Text: obtain at Cairns, .1,100 miles farther

Speaker: NA
Text: north. As Cairns is as far from Bris-

Speaker: NA
Text: bane as is Melbourne, honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers will realize how -greatly the climatic

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions of Cairns and Melbourne must

Speaker: NA
Text: differ. Houses are being built at Cairns

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Commonwealth scheme, but,

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately, they are not suitable for

Speaker: NA
Text: tropical regions. The by-laws of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Cairns City Council provide for a

Speaker: NA
Text: mean height of 10 feet between floor and

Speaker: NA
Text: ceiling, but the houses which are being

Speaker: NA
Text: erected there by the commission have only

Speaker: NA
Text: 9-ft. walls. Most houses in the district

Speaker: NA
Text: have 12 feet between floor and ceiling.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some years ago the Queensland Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment established a Workers Dwellings

Speaker: NA
Text: Department, and remarkably good work

Speaker: NA
Text: has been done by that body. Recently

Speaker: NA
Text: it has been re-organized with a view

Speaker: NA
Text: to undertaking an extended building pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gramme. As a result of its activities

Speaker: NA
Text: the percentage of workers who own their

Speaker: NA
Text: own homes, or are buying homes, is

Speaker: NA
Text: greater in Queensland than in any other

Speaker: NA
Text: State. I congratulate the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: on the introduction of its housing

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Speech ofi His Royal Highness

Speaker: NA
Text: shows that tlie foresight and courage

Speaker: NA
Text: which have characterized the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: hitherto will be applied to the problems

Speaker: NA
Text: of the future. At the last elections the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government was given the greatest vote

Speaker: NA
Text: of confidence ever accorded to any govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, and, when the next appeal is made

Speaker: NA
Text: to the electors, I am confident that an

Speaker: NA
Text: even more striking indication of their

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence i n the Government will be

Speaker: NA
Text: given. Everywhere that I go throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth I hear people say

Speaker: NA
Text: that they intend to continue to support

Speaker: NA
Text: the Curtin Government. The workers

Speaker: NA
Text: desire the Government to carry on with

Speaker: NA
Text: its good work, and at the next elections

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government will be given another

Speaker: NA
Text: mandate.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Ha s the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber anything to say on the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: banking proposals?

Speaker: Mr RIORDAN
Text: The Standing

Speaker: NA
Text: Orders do not permit me to anticipate

Speaker: NA
Text: the debate on a subject already on the

Speaker: NA
Text: notice-paper.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the Menzies Government occu-

Speaker: NA
Text: pied the treasury bench we heard and

Speaker: NA
Text: also read a good deal in the press of the

Speaker: NA
Text: need for a " new order ", but to-day very

Speaker: NA
Text: little is said about a " new order",

Speaker: NA
Text: although we hear howls about socialism.

Speaker: NA
Text: The emaciated socialist tiger has been

Speaker: NA
Text: dug up from the political cemetery. Al l

Speaker: NA
Text: the old party political clap-trap is

Speaker: NA
Text: wheeled out again by the Opposition in

Speaker: NA
Text: an attempt to gull the people. I am con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fident that i f the policy outlined in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Speech of His Royal Highness is put into

Speaker: NA
Text: operation the verdict of the people given

Speaker: NA
Text: at the last elections will be repeated and

Speaker: NA
Text: with greater emphasis when the next

Speaker: NA
Text: appeal to them is made.

Speaker: Mr ARCHIE CAMERON
Text: Barker)

Speaker: NA
Text: [8.11] -Th e arrival of a Royal Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernor-General in this country, is

Speaker: NA
Text: new to Australian political history.

Speaker: NA
Text: As one who descended from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Jacobites, I welcome the brother of

Speaker: NA
Text: the King. I n due course, after His Royal

Speaker: NA
Text: Highness has carried out the duties

Speaker: NA
Text: assigned to him in a manner befitting a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the present Royal Family, I

Speaker: NA
Text: suppose that the Commonwealth will have

Speaker: NA
Text: another Governor-General; and some of

Speaker: NA
Text: us look forward with interest to what

Speaker: NA
Text: will happen then. I shall not discuss that

Speaker: NA
Text: matter now, but honorable members oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: site will know what I mean.

Speaker: NA
Text: I desire to refer particularly to two

Speaker: NA
Text: matters, first, the position which con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fronts us in regard to external affairs,

Speaker: NA
Text: and, secondly, the control and use of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Army. Since the war began

Speaker: NA
Text: there has been an extensive development

Speaker: NA
Text: ofi the external activities of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth. We have sent Ministers and

Speaker: NA
Text: High Commissioners to many countries

Speaker: NA
Text: to which we had not thought of sending

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives when war broke out five

Speaker: NA
Text: and a half years ago. That development

Speaker: NA
Text: hastaken place without any debate in

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parliament. Very little attention

Speaker: NA
Text: has been paid by either House of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament to an activity which, for good

Speaker: NA
Text: or i l l , will affect the future of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: for several generations. I t stands second

Speaker: NA
Text: only in importance to certain aspects of

Speaker: NA
Text: the conduct ofi the present war. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: now gone so far along the road to victory

Speaker: NA
Text: that we can form some idea of what the

Speaker: NA
Text: state of the world will be after our

Speaker: NA
Text: enemies have been defeated. Two years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago we could not safely have done so.

Speaker: NA
Text: The future of the British Empire is our

Speaker: NA
Text: first concern. I t has been proved - I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope to the satisfaction of every honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member in this chamber-tha t the

Speaker: NA
Text: security of the Commonwealth, so far as

Speaker: NA
Text: we can foresee the future, lies in our

Speaker: NA
Text: membership of the British Empire or the

Speaker: NA
Text: British Commonwealth of Nations. Call

Speaker: NA
Text: it what you like. I t is only a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: of names. I prefer the old name,

Speaker: NA
Text: " British Empire ", under which I was

Speaker: NA
Text: brought up. Every development in tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: war or the realm of external affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: proves the absolute necessity for better

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding and very much closer co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operation between the British Dominions

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Motherland than has existed

Speaker: NA
Text: up to date. That co-operation has to

Speaker: NA
Text: be based on complete freedom and on a

Speaker: NA
Text: complete understanding of our own re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quirements and those of the other

Speaker: NA
Text: dominions. I believe that can be

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved. Last year the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Curtin) went to London and took

Speaker: NA
Text: part in certain imperial discussions- I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope, for the benefit of this country. We

Speaker: NA
Text: fully realize that under war-time condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions we cannot be told publicly so much

Speaker: NA
Text: about some things as we may desire to

Speaker: NA
Text: hear. The conditions that will prevail

Speaker: NA
Text: after this war will affect the British

Speaker: NA
Text: Empire vitally. At one time, we were

Speaker: NA
Text: all very proud to belong to an Empire

Speaker: NA
Text: on which the sun never sets. Its vast

Speaker: NA
Text: spread was considered to be a great safe-

Speaker: NA
Text: guard. To-day i t has other implications.

Speaker: NA
Text: The British Empire contains elements of

Speaker: NA
Text: great danger, unless the situation, is

Speaker: NA
Text: properly handled. Means of communi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation and the speed of transport have

Speaker: NA
Text: increased under war-time conditions;

Speaker: NA
Text: the inventive genius of man always

Speaker: NA
Text: finds scope in inventing means of

Speaker: NA
Text: destruction, at a greater rate and i n a

Speaker: NA
Text: better way than in peace-time. That has

Speaker: NA
Text: been true of air transport in this war,

Speaker: NA
Text: was true in the war of 1914-18, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that it would prove to be true

Speaker: NA
Text: if the next generation were unfortunate

Speaker: NA
Text: enough to be involved in another war

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 or 30 years hence. The British

Speaker: NA
Text: Dominions are dispersed throughout the

Speaker: NA
Text: world. They must live dispersed lives,

Speaker: NA
Text: according to their individual conditions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The cardinal principle, which I want

Speaker: NA
Text: the House to realize, is that henceforth

Speaker: NA
Text: there must be no half-measures and that

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Britain and the Dominions must be

Speaker: NA
Text: in a condition whereby they can unite for

Speaker: NA
Text: defence against any possible combination

Speaker: NA
Text: of powers which may face them. When

Speaker: NA
Text: this war broke out, it is undeniable

Speaker: NA
Text: that that state of affairs did not exist.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many people, particularly on the other

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the House, absolutely scouted

Speaker: NA
Text: the idea of the necessity of any arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of that sort or the likelihood of

Speaker: NA
Text: war in our time. They proved to be

Speaker: NA
Text: quite wrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: The next important point in the field

Speaker: NA
Text: of external relations is the position that

Speaker: NA
Text: will be occupied by two other great

Speaker: NA
Text: Powers after the war. The first is the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America. Before the

Speaker: NA
Text: war it exercised great control from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Arctic to the Antarctic through the two

Speaker: NA
Text: Americas; but after the war, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: result of bases which it has acquired,

Speaker: NA
Text: and, I believe, will acquire in conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quence of the peace treaties when they

Speaker: NA
Text: are signed, it will have not only a north-

Speaker: NA
Text: south territorial area to look after, but

Speaker: NA
Text: also a great sea responsibility extending

Speaker: NA
Text: from the East Indies eastward through

Speaker: NA
Text: the Panama Canal to the West Indies.

Speaker: NA
Text: In other words, it will possess land and

Speaker: NA
Text: sea power over one-half of the globe. It

Speaker: NA
Text: will have great responsibilities in all

Speaker: NA
Text: areas in which it is concerned. The other

Speaker: NA
Text: change will be that which has taken place

Speaker: NA
Text: in the position of the Union of Soviet-

Speaker: NA
Text: Socialist Republics as the result

Speaker: NA
Text: of the progress of the war. It alone

Speaker: NA
Text: of the three great Powers is determined

Speaker: NA
Text: to extend its territories in many direc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, a striking contrast to the inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national attitude of ourselves and that of

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Archie Cameron.

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States of America. No one

Speaker: NA
Text: questions that the English-speaking

Speaker: NA
Text: countries of the world are endeavouring

Speaker: NA
Text: to produce a state of affairs in which

Speaker: NA
Text: the small nations will have equal rights

Speaker: NA
Text: as it with the great nations, in which

Speaker: NA
Text: their peoples will be able to live in

Speaker: NA
Text: security, to own their lands, to trade,

Speaker: NA
Text: to develop industries, perhaps to migrate

Speaker: NA
Text: and to invest abroad under conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: which will be pre-eminently satisfactory

Speaker: NA
Text: to them. I refer particularly to some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the nations in Europe. But that is

Speaker: NA
Text: not the basis on which Russian foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: policy is f ounded. To-day on the eastern

Speaker: NA
Text: frontier we see a line of occupations and

Speaker: NA
Text: what will probably be annexures run-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning through Finland, Latvia, Estonia,

Speaker: NA
Text: Lithuania, Poland, Hungary and

Speaker: NA
Text: Rumania, and we do not know whether

Speaker: NA
Text: they will rest just there. So that cardinal

Speaker: NA
Text: fact must be borne in mind by all Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians i f they are to have a clear grasp

Speaker: NA
Text: of what may emerge from the forth-

Speaker: NA
Text: coming peace conference. Too many

Speaker: NA
Text: of our people do not fully under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand the external affairs problem. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: is not merely a matter of relationship

Speaker: NA
Text: between us and some other country per

Speaker: NA
Text: medium of a Minister or a High Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner. I t goes much deeper than

Speaker: NA
Text: that. I t involves very much more than

Speaker: NA
Text: everyday affairs. There are problems of

Speaker: NA
Text: communications, transport, trade and

Speaker: NA
Text: commerce barriers, immigration laws,

Speaker: NA
Text: airlines, postal services and all that

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of thing, which are emin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ently bound up with the prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem of external affairs. So as we en-

Speaker: NA
Text: deavour to put into force a policy which

Speaker: NA
Text: impinges on the spheres of influences of

Speaker: NA
Text: any other nation in any of. those respects

Speaker: NA
Text: we begin to trespass. Before long we

Speaker: NA
Text: shall require to give consideration to the

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the deliberations at the Dum-

Speaker: NA
Text: barton Oaks 'and the Bretton Woods

Speaker: NA
Text: conferences, the nature of which

Speaker: NA
Text: I am not able to ascertain. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: applied to the External Affairs Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, through the Minister, a couple of

Speaker: NA
Text: times for information. I t has been pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: mised, but I have not yet received it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whether other honorable gentlemen are

Speaker: NA
Text: better informed, I do not know. That

Speaker: NA
Text: observation leads me to this. I want

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government sooner or later to face

Speaker: NA
Text: this question-I s its idea of post-war

Speaker: NA
Text: problems to be based on the practice of

Speaker: NA
Text: open diplomacy or secret diplomacy?

Speaker: NA
Text: That is question No. 1.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: able member advise?

Speaker: Mr ARCHIE CAMERON
Text: I am

Speaker: NA
Text: not giving my policy at the moment. No

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt, after the honorable member comes

Speaker: NA
Text: back from San Erancisco, he will be only

Speaker: NA
Text: too anxious to give his advice.

Speaker: Mr CONELAN
Text: D o not be jealous.

Speaker: Mr ARCHIE CAMERON
Text: I am

Speaker: NA
Text: not a bit jealous. "We need to decide

Speaker: NA
Text: whether we shall adopt a system of open

Speaker: NA
Text: or secret diplomacy. The Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament has not discussed that vital

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. That brings to a head the

Speaker: NA
Text: question whether we are to have private

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiation for trade treaties, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of thing. They are intimately bound

Speaker: NA
Text: together. A fair proportion of the time

Speaker: NA
Text: we spend talking here should be regularly

Speaker: NA
Text: devoted to developments in the realm of

Speaker: NA
Text: external affairs, but that is not done.

Speaker: NA
Text: Such debate is squeezed out by the sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem under which we work. Time is taken

Speaker: NA
Text: up with questions. Ministers make most

Speaker: NA
Text: important pronouncements on foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: relations, move that the papers be printed,

Speaker: NA
Text: and never allow the subjects involved to

Speaker: NA
Text: be debated until the day on which Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment adjourns. That is not a state of

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs under which there can be intelli-

Speaker: NA
Text: gent understanding of external affairs. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not go so far as to say that our men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tality is atrophied by the system, but, i f

Speaker: NA
Text: more time is not devoted by this Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament to th© all-important problem

Speaker: NA
Text: of international affairs, it may .easily

Speaker: NA
Text: become atrophied. We see important

Speaker: NA
Text: documents laid before us as last year we

Speaker: NA
Text: had laid before us the famous Australian-

Speaker: NA
Text: New Zealand Agreement, known as

Speaker: NA
Text: the "Anzac Pact". I will not go

Speaker: NA
Text: into the merits of that agreement, for

Speaker: NA
Text: I doubt whether i t has any. I t was t

Speaker: NA
Text: signed i n this chamber beneath kleig

Speaker: NA
Text: lights and before moving picture cameras.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Transport ( Mr Ward)

Speaker: NA
Text: took several minutes to read i t through

Speaker: NA
Text: before he would sign it, but no time has

Speaker: NA
Text: ever been devoted by this House to its

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration. I raise that point specific-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally, because i t is known that two senior

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Ministers have lately

Speaker: NA
Text: left for the other side of the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that they are going to an

Speaker: NA
Text: Imperial conference to be held somewhere.

Speaker: NA
Text: Afterwards they will go to a conference

Speaker: NA
Text: at San Erancisco which will be attended

Speaker: NA
Text: by the representatives of certain nations.

Speaker: NA
Text: When those Ministers come back

Speaker: NA
Text: they must bring reports to Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Are we to have a state of affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: in which those matters will not be dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussed in this House. I n days gone by

Speaker: NA
Text: that system did not prevail. One of

Speaker: NA
Text: the most important intra-Imperial docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments ever signed was the Ottawa Agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, but that was the subject of many

Speaker: NA
Text: days' debate before it became law as a

Speaker: NA
Text: schedule to an act of this Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: The next thing to which I refer is

Speaker: NA
Text: the question of the negotiation or im-

Speaker: NA
Text: position ofi peace. I am not sure which

Speaker: NA
Text: word will be best suited to the event.

Speaker: NA
Text: None of us may be very well informed on

Speaker: NA
Text: that. Perhaps honorable gentlemen on

Speaker: NA
Text: the treasury bench will not be much better

Speaker: NA
Text: informed than we shall be. We read a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot in the press and hear discussions over

Speaker: NA
Text: the air about whether we should have a

Speaker: NA
Text: soft peace or a hard peace. I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: moved, by either adjective. I f we are to

Speaker: NA
Text: avoid a recurrence of what the world has

Speaker: NA
Text: suffered over the last five and a half years

Speaker: NA
Text: what is needed is that the peace shall be

Speaker: NA
Text: just and nothing else. That is the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant thing. Therefore the part that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are to play in the negotiations or the

Speaker: NA
Text: part that we are to play after the terms

Speaker: NA
Text: have been decided by other powers is

Speaker: NA
Text: something to which this House should

Speaker: NA
Text: pay some attention, because we may very

Speaker: NA
Text: easily be caught up in events over which

Speaker: NA
Text: we have exercised no supervision, and to

Speaker: NA
Text: which we have given no thought. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: will be too late for the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to say after the event: " That

Speaker: NA
Text: is very unfortunate, but certain things

Speaker: NA
Text: have been done and we were not fully

Speaker: NA
Text: informed or did not fully inform Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment ". I t stands to reason, in my view,

Speaker: NA
Text: tbat the very first thing in any peace terms

Speaker: NA
Text: which will be negotiated or imposed after

Speaker: NA
Text: the war is what is to be done about naval

Speaker: NA
Text: armament. My own view, perhaps not

Speaker: NA
Text: orthodox, but not without historical justi-

Speaker: NA
Text: fication, is that in the present state

Speaker: NA
Text: of the world there is no necessity

Speaker: NA
Text: for the maintenance of naval arma-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments by more than two powers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those two powers are Great Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: and the United States of America. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: would he in the interest of world peace i f

Speaker: NA
Text: the naval policing of the world were en-

Speaker: NA
Text: trusted to those two powers. ' We should

Speaker: NA
Text: not then have the set of circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: which has faced the world for a long

Speaker: NA
Text: time under which there tends to grow

Speaker: NA
Text: up between great powers, or between

Speaker: NA
Text: small powers, a competition in the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision of naval armaments for defence,

Speaker: NA
Text: or offence, as the case may be. These two

Speaker: NA
Text: powers have proved through their record

Speaker: NA
Text: during this war that neither is out for

Speaker: NA
Text: territorial aggrandizement, or the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: quest of any other country. Each is. out

Speaker: NA
Text: to secure only its own, and to see that the

Speaker: NA
Text: inoffensive peoples of Europe and other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries in the world are left to live

Speaker: NA
Text: and develop in peace. Wherever the

Speaker: NA
Text: Navy at any time of the world's history

Speaker: NA
Text: lias entered into defence operations i t

Speaker: NA
Text: has had a very important bearing on the

Speaker: NA
Text: outcome of any war in which it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: able to engage. Holding those views, I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that it is advisable that there

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be any competition in naval

Speaker: NA
Text: armament when the war is over.

Speaker: NA
Text: The next point that comes up for con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration is what is known as the Atlantic

Speaker: NA
Text: Charter. In that respect I do not know

Speaker: NA
Text: where the Commonwealth of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: stands to-day. There was a lot said about

Speaker: NA
Text: the Atlantic Charter from the treasury

Speaker: NA
Text: bench not so many months ago, but for

Speaker: NA
Text: the past few months there has 'been a very

Speaker: NA
Text: significant silence indeed. I should be

Speaker: NA
Text: very much intrigued to know whether all

Speaker: NA
Text: powers allied and associated with us at

Speaker: NA
Text: present have accepted the principles of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Atlantic Charter, and whether such

Speaker: NA
Text: powers have agreed to carry out its prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciples, particularly with, respect to

Speaker: NA
Text: tries which some of them are overrunning

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day. No man can read the terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: peace to which Rumania or Finland has,

Speaker: NA
Text: .agreed, and to which it appears Poland,

Speaker: NA
Text: will be compelled to agree, without

Speaker: NA
Text: feeling in his heart that there has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a serious and violent violation

Speaker: NA
Text: of one of the most important terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Atlantic Charter. That is the freedom

Speaker: NA
Text: under which people are to decide their

Speaker: NA
Text: own form of government, and the allegi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance they will offer to other governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Polish question has been referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: in this House. I recall the debate which

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Archie Cameron.

Speaker: NA
Text: took place on external affairs in May,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1939, before the war broke out. On that

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion I told the House why I was

Speaker: NA
Text: opposed to the Polish guarantee. I t was

Speaker: NA
Text: for the simple reason that we were going

Speaker: NA
Text: to sign a guarantee which we could never

Speaker: NA
Text: carry out; and that has been proved by

Speaker: NA
Text: events. Whatever may be our feelings

Speaker: NA
Text: with regard to the Polish question, the

Speaker: NA
Text: future of Poland will not be decided by

Speaker: NA
Text: what the English-speaking peoples of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world think to be right or just. The

Speaker: NA
Text: future of Poland, is being decided else-

Speaker: NA
Text: where, just as the future of Rumania,

Speaker: NA
Text: Hungary and some other countries are

Speaker: NA
Text: being decided by the same people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: same place. One of the cardinal lessons

Speaker: NA
Text: of world history is this: a country like

Speaker: NA
Text: East Prussia cannot be taken and handed

Speaker: NA
Text: over to a foreign country. We

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot settle a problem of that

Speaker: NA
Text: kind by simply saying that, wc are

Speaker: NA
Text: going to give a part of Poland to

Speaker: NA
Text: Russia, and compensate Poland by hand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing over to it part of East Prussia. We

Speaker: NA
Text: know the story of the lost provinces in

Speaker: NA
Text: northern Italy; and we know what

Speaker: NA
Text: Alsace-Lorraine means between France

Speaker: NA
Text: and 'Germany. Is i t to be the deliberate

Speaker: NA
Text: policy of one of the three great Allies

Speaker: NA
Text: in this war that it will create another

Speaker: NA
Text: problem, another festering cancer, on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Baltic of. the type that must result under

Speaker: NA
Text: the conditions which we understand are

Speaker: NA
Text: to be imposed? I t is with great regret

Speaker: NA
Text: that I refer to a matter like this, because

Speaker: NA
Text: I realize as well as any other honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member that the fate of Poland, or any

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Balkan or Baltic States, is not

Speaker: NA
Text: going to be determined by anything we

Speaker: NA
Text: sav here. I t is not; but we are parties

Speaker: NA
Text: to certain international agreements. We

Speaker: NA
Text: coun- did accept the Atlantic Charter; and

Speaker: NA
Text: some people will want to know exactly

Speaker: NA
Text: what we propose to do ahout it. I t is a

Speaker: NA
Text: -question which we cannot answer by

Speaker: NA
Text: shelving it. I t will come up for solution

Speaker: NA
Text: in due course.

Speaker: NA
Text: The next point is with respect to the

Speaker: NA
Text: part that Unrra is to play i n the rehabili-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation of the devastated countries. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not think that a bill was ever introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: into this Parliament with more fanfare

Speaker: NA
Text: of trumpets and greater show than was

Speaker: NA
Text: the case in respect of that bill. I t went

Speaker: NA
Text: through this House without a proper

Speaker: NA
Text: explanation. With the cast-iron majority

Speaker: NA
Text: whicli tbe Government has, and which is

Speaker: NA
Text: as subservient as any. majority possibly

Speaker: NA
Text: could be, it stands to reason that any

Speaker: NA
Text: measure the Government introduces,

Speaker: NA
Text: which receives not only the ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: imprimatur but also the imprimatur of

Speaker: NA
Text: caucus, is .bound to become the law of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr BuitKii -W e shall hear to-morrow

Speaker: NA
Text: from honorable members opposite that a

Speaker: NA
Text: wild caucus dominates the Cabinet.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr ARCHIE CAMERON" -When -

Speaker: NA
Text: ever I look at the Opposition benches

Speaker: NA
Text: I feel that I am looking at some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the proposed advisory coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: cil of the Commonwealth Bank. The

Speaker: NA
Text: measure relating to TJnrra had hardly

Speaker: NA
Text: become law when the Attorney-General

Speaker: NA
Text: (Dr Evatt) who introduced it, and

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended it to this House in un-

Speaker: NA
Text: qualified terms, went to Lapstone, in

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales, and made some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: most scathing comments about that or-

Speaker: NA
Text: ganization that could have been made by

Speaker: NA
Text: any responsible Minister. The Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General has disappeared to parts, per-

Speaker: NA
Text: haps, unknown, but the identity of

Speaker: NA
Text: which we may guess; but there has been

Speaker: NA
Text: no explanation from the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman as to why he went to Lap-

Speaker: NA
Text: stone and gave such a thorough thrashing

Speaker: NA
Text: to his very favoured infant then only a

Speaker: NA
Text: few weeks old.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: H e wanted to draw

Speaker: NA
Text: attention from the Government.

Speaker: Mr ARCHIE CAMERON
Text: I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that he was more inclined to focus atten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion on himself than to draw it from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. That is something which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Attorney-General at some future date,

Speaker: NA
Text: if his onerous duties of puttingthe United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America, the United King-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom, Russia and China in proper order

Speaker: NA
Text: will allow him to attend to matters like

Speaker: NA
Text: this, might very well use for the instruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and edification of this chamber.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the important terms of peace

Speaker: NA
Text: to which I referred in passing concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: East Prussia. There will be a lot of talk

Speaker: NA
Text: as to what we are to do with Germany,

Speaker: NA
Text: Italy and Japan. I f there is to be any

Speaker: NA
Text: chance of security in the post-war world,

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the important things that must be

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken is the national control of the

Speaker: NA
Text: armaments industry.

Speaker: Mr CONELAN
Text: Socialism .

Speaker: Mr ARCHIE CAMERON
Text: Honor -

Speaker: NA
Text: able members opposite need not get ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: cited. One practice which, no doubt, has

Speaker: NA
Text: been conducive towards the breeding of

Speaker: NA
Text: military disturbance in certain of the

Speaker: NA
Text: smaller countries has been the export of

Speaker: NA
Text: armaments from several of the bigger

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. My own personal view, which

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentlemen can take for what

Speaker: NA
Text: it is worth-an d I am not endeavouring

Speaker: NA
Text: to speak for the party to which I

Speaker: NA
Text: belong

Speaker: Mr SHEEHAN
Text: Wha t party is that?

Speaker: Mr ARCHIE CAMERON
Text: I have

Speaker: NA
Text: been in five parties in eighteen, years.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n fact it is one of the points, perhaps,

Speaker: NA
Text: on which I should qualify to challenge

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister of Great Britain,

Speaker: NA
Text: because I doubt i f he has been in so many

Speaker: NA
Text: parties. I f I had my way, the export of

Speaker: NA
Text: arms from countries like Great Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: and the United States of America ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to be prohibited by the governments of

Speaker: NA
Text: those countries. This is a matter to

Speaker: NA
Text: which the 'Commonwealth Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: also ought to devote some attention, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause we have a right to put our case on

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter before an Imperial Conference.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that the strongest way of giving

Speaker: NA
Text: effect to the policy of Australia will be

Speaker: NA
Text: by holding more conferences between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dominions arid the Motherland, and

Speaker: NA
Text: thereat arriving at uniform policies be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore entering international conferences.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should go into international confer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ences as a united British Empire, deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mined on some line of policy. We should

Speaker: NA
Text: not go into such conferences as so many

Speaker: NA
Text: different British communities who have

Speaker: NA
Text: not agreed upon anything, but can only

Speaker: NA
Text: say that we agree to differ. A disunited

Speaker: NA
Text: British Empire after this war is over will

Speaker: NA
Text: be a menace to the peace and security of

Speaker: NA
Text: the world, just as I believe that a similar

Speaker: NA
Text: menace will be the right of any company,

Speaker: NA
Text: or government, to export arms outside

Speaker: NA
Text: the country in which they are manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: factured.

Speaker: NA
Text: The forthcoming conference at San

Speaker: NA
Text: Erancisco may be looked upon as a kind

Speaker: NA
Text: of prologue to world peace. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: know. I have my doubts as to when

Speaker: NA
Text: peace will actually be declared. After the

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting ceases, there might be a long

Speaker: NA
Text: period i f not of anarchy, at any rate oi

Speaker: NA
Text: great internal disturbance, in many of

Speaker: NA
Text: the countries which have been overrun,

Speaker: NA
Text: and, of course, in the conquered countries

Speaker: NA
Text: with which we are at war to-day. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is inevitable. I also put it to honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members that before we are through with

Speaker: NA
Text: the war, notwithstanding what the news-

Speaker: NA
Text: papers now say, the German Army might

Speaker: NA
Text: give a very different ^twist to the meaning

Speaker: NA
Text: of Fortress Europe from that which we

Speaker: NA
Text: have had up to date. The ground now

Speaker: NA
Text: being approached by the Allies on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Western Front lends itself to

Speaker: NA
Text: easy defence. Therefore, I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied that the war is going to end on,

Speaker: NA
Text: say, Friday week. The representatives of

Speaker: NA
Text: many governments are to meet in San

Speaker: NA
Text: Francisco, but so far as I am able to

Speaker: NA
Text: judge, there is no informed world opinion

Speaker: NA
Text: as to what they should do. So far as the

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives of this country are con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned-an d I do not say this in a party

Speaker: NA
Text: political, or personal, sense-ther e is no

Speaker: NA
Text: informed opinion in the 'Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia as to what ought to be done

Speaker: NA
Text: at the San Francisco conference or

Speaker: NA
Text: any other similar conference after

Speaker: NA
Text: this war is over or before i t ends.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reason for that is chiefly because

Speaker: NA
Text: no debate has taken place in this Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment on the matters to be discussed. So,

Speaker: NA
Text: as honorable members, we present to our

Speaker: NA
Text: constituents, and as a nation we present

Speaker: NA
Text: to the world, the spectacle of sending

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers abroad without instructions

Speaker: NA
Text: being given to them by the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: that they represent. They may have

Speaker: NA
Text: received instructions from the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, but events even during the life-

Speaker: NA
Text: time of the Curtin Government have

Speaker: NA
Text: shown that when it came to a *' show-

Speaker: NA
Text: down", something which Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted to do was not what their sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: porters wanted to do. I do not say that

Speaker: NA
Text: that will happen very often. Sometimes

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to the Lord that it would happen,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it does not. But that possibility will

Speaker: NA
Text: be borne in mind by the representatives of

Speaker: NA
Text: other countries who will meet the repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives of the Commonwealth at San

Speaker: NA
Text: Francisco. A great variety of govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment representatives are going to San

Speaker: NA
Text: Francisco.

Speaker: Mr LAZZARINI
Text: Th e honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber personifies the saying, " The devil

Speaker: NA
Text: was sick, the devil a monk would be ".

Speaker: Mr ARCHIE CAMERON
Text: I wish

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Minister for Home Security

Speaker: NA
Text: would not talk in his sleep. At the San

Speaker: NA
Text: Francisco conference, this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: will be represented by two senior Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters. The Opposition also will send

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives to the conference. Per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonally, I am opposed to members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition in this Parliament attend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the conference under the conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been laid down for them.

Speaker: NA
Text: [Extension of time granted.'] I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: in the rather outmoded idea that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is in office and should

Speaker: NA
Text: govern. I t should take the responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: for its administration. The Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: should not take part in things which it

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot control or influence. The decision

Speaker: NA
Text: as to who should represent the country

Speaker: NA
Text: at such a conference should be

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the Government. The dele-

Speaker: NA
Text: gation should consist of government

Speaker: NA
Text: nominees, and should give effect to the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy of the Government, and nobody

Speaker: NA
Text: else. No honorable member who goes from

Speaker: NA
Text: this side of the House will be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: commit a future Parliament. He cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: say what will be done by a majority of

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Liberal party when we

Speaker: NA
Text: occupy the treasury bench, as no doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: we shall after the next elections. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: order to do so, We shall have to double

Speaker: NA
Text: our numbers, and that will mean an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: fusion of new blood and new ideas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, we face a future which

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps is not easily predictable.

Speaker: NA
Text: I pass now to the other important

Speaker: NA
Text: matter with which I desire to deal,

Speaker: NA
Text: namely, the position of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Army. I n view of remarks reported in

Speaker: NA
Text: the press recently, and attributed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chief of the A ir Staff, I may have some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing to say later about the Royal Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Air Force, but I shall reserve

Speaker: NA
Text: those comments until the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Air ( Mr Drakeford) makes in this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber the statement that to-day he

Speaker: NA
Text: promised to prepare. A good deal of

Speaker: NA
Text: confused thinking is evident i n what

Speaker: NA
Text: has been said by Ministers. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: listened to nearly every speaker- I

Speaker: NA
Text: have seldom been out of the chamber-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I could be excused for thinking at

Speaker: NA
Text: one moment that the waging of the

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: has done a remarks of Mr Lillie.

Speaker: Mr LANGTRY
Text: Mr L i l l i e said-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCEwen now desires to relate price for

Speaker: NA
Text: for stock feed to the present high

Speaker: NA
Text: export values. This is in distinct contrast to

Speaker: NA
Text: his attitude as a Minister. When a Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: Recently, he said Australia could not afford to guarantee

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 3s. lOd. a bushel, f.o.b., which on

Speaker: NA
Text: the basis of guaranteed production is equal

Speaker: NA
Text: to approximately 8s. a bushel at sidings. War

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure, he said, of £70,000,000 would not

Speaker: NA
Text: permit i t . War expenditure to-day is over

Speaker: NA
Text: £400,000,000 a year. Then, he voted to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: half of any return over 3s. lOd. a bushel, f.o.b.,

Speaker: NA
Text: for export wheat into an equalization fund, the

Speaker: NA
Text: growers to get tlie balance. Now he advocates

Speaker: NA
Text: an open purse.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Indi has said

Speaker: NA
Text: both inside and outside this chamber that

Speaker: NA
Text: there has been a £10,000,000 "steal"

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Australian wheat-growers. .That

Speaker: NA
Text: statement definitely is not in accord with

Speaker: NA
Text: facts. The truth is that wheat-growers

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be robbed of one penny. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Forrest has just

Speaker: NA
Text: explained to the House that when the

Speaker: NA
Text: pool is finalized for all wheat sold, for

Speaker: NA
Text: export and home consumption, the farmer

Speaker: NA
Text: will receive the average price for all wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: sold. I n my own electorate 80 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: of the growers who forwarded wheat to

Speaker: NA
Text: the pool and were paid 4s. a bushel for it,

Speaker: NA
Text: have bought at least some of it hack at

Speaker: NA
Text: 3s. 6d. a bushel. The Government is pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to provide the balance whether

Speaker: NA
Text: it is 6d., Sd., or 2s. a bushel. There-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore, the statements that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: made by honorable members opposite are

Speaker: NA
Text: far from the facts. I have no objection

Speaker: NA
Text: to members of the Opposition visiting my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, but when they do, I expect

Speaker: NA
Text: them to tell the truth. The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Indi should be an acrobat

Speaker: NA
Text: instead of a politician. He is adept at

Speaker: NA
Text: turning somersaults, sidestepping and

Speaker: NA
Text: dodging facts, activities which hurt him.

Speaker: NA
Text: The same may be said of almost every

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Australian Country party.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have no argument with members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal party except that they stand for

Speaker: NA
Text: vested interests. I t is ridiculous for

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Australian Country party

Speaker: NA
Text: to say that the wheat-growers ofAus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia are not getting a fair deal. Appar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ently the honorable member for Indi has

Speaker: NA
Text: told that story so often that he is begin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning to believe it himself. I am reminded

Speaker: NA
Text: of a man. who came to me when I was

Speaker: NA
Text: carting wool near the River Murray, and

Speaker: NA
Text: said that he was hungry. I said, " Are

Speaker: NA
Text: you ? " He replied, " Yes, i f I had some

Speaker: NA
Text: fat I would f r y some fish i f I had some

Speaker: NA
Text: fish to fry ". A similar argument is used

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honorable member for Indi. What

Speaker: NA
Text: was the position when this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: assumed ofiice and the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Gwydir ( Mr Scully) became Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Commerce? The problem then

Speaker: NA
Text: was over-production. Huge stocks of

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat were held in all States, and

Speaker: NA
Text: methods had to be devised to dispose

Speaker: NA
Text: of the surplus. These included the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of power alcohol. Some wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: stored in Western Australia was found

Speaker: NA
Text: to bo weevil-infested. The position to-day

Speaker: NA
Text: after three bad seasons-on e of them the

Speaker: NA
Text: worst in history-i s vastly different

Speaker: NA
Text: owing to a severe drought. Evens-

Speaker: NA
Text: the Albury, Wagga, Temora and Cowra

Speaker: NA
Text: districts which were never expected to-

Speaker: NA
Text: fail in times of most severe drought, are-

Speaker: NA
Text: suffering badly. They have never pre--

Speaker: NA
Text: viously failed in my experience, which

Speaker: NA
Text: includes the droughts of 1902, 1914 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 1919. They were always able to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce some fodder, but to-day, when we

Speaker: NA
Text: are faced with the responsibility of feed-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing more people than ever before, crops

Speaker: NA
Text: are practically valueless. The Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Commerce and Agriculture ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Scully) has considered all aspects of the

Speaker: NA
Text: situation and has released some wheat in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to keep sheep and cattle alive. Men

Speaker: NA
Text: who are receiving wheat for starving

Speaker: NA
Text: stock are getting their own wheat back

Speaker: NA
Text: at a reduced rate, whilst good purchase

Speaker: NA
Text: prices are being paid for i t by the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment. The Commonwealth has

Speaker: NA
Text: already paid about £2,000,000 for the

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat used for starving stock and a

Speaker: NA
Text: further payment of about £6,000,000 will

Speaker: NA
Text: be available soon. I n spite of this, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Indi ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: MCEwen) said that the wheat-growers are

Speaker: NA
Text: not getting a fair deal and are being

Speaker: NA
Text: robbed of millions of pounds. I f the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable gentleman had said, " Vote for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party at the next elections; it is

Speaker: NA
Text: your friend, we are your enenjies", he

Speaker: NA
Text: would have told the truth. I have stated

Speaker: NA
Text: tho facts of the case. I attended a meet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of farmers convened by the Farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: and Settlers Association to which he

Speaker: NA
Text: referred. The Minister for Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: merce and Agriculture was invited

Speaker: NA
Text: to attend, but he could not do so,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the honorable member for Ballarat

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: was allowed ten minutes in which to

Speaker: NA
Text: speak, but, when I tried to explain the

Speaker: NA
Text: true position the chairman made me sit

Speaker: NA
Text: down. He had been an Australian Coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try party candidate at the previous elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. The gun was loaded and the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: x'ernment case was lost before we arrived

Speaker: NA
Text: at the meeting. The meeting was not

Speaker: NA
Text: representative of actual wheat-growers.

Speaker: NA
Text: -It was organized by the Farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: and Settlers Association which,

Speaker: NA
Text: everybody knows, has been f o r the

Speaker: NA
Text: last twenty years the mouthpiece of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Country party. I myself

Speaker: NA
Text: resigned f r o m membership of the associa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion over twenty years ago because of its

Speaker: NA
Text: political tendencies. The honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber f or Ballarat was also prevented f r o m

Speaker: NA
Text: stating the truth at the meeting because

Speaker: NA
Text: he tried to explain the position i n his

Speaker: NA
Text: own way. I compliment the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Commerce and Agriculture upon what

Speaker: NA
Text: he has done f or the wheat industry. Erom

Speaker: NA
Text: the time when the Labour party assumed

Speaker: NA
Text: office, the contrast between what i t has

Speaker: NA
Text: done f o r the primary producers and what

Speaker: NA
Text: its predecessors did f or them has been

Speaker: NA
Text: very marked. Whether the man on the

Speaker: NA
Text: land grows wheat, wool, f a t lambs or

Speaker: NA
Text: vegetables, he receives good guaranteed

Speaker: NA
Text: prices, which previous governments did

Speaker: NA
Text: not provide f or him. I am sorry that

Speaker: NA
Text: the referendum proposals were rejected

Speaker: NA
Text: by the people, because as the law stands

Speaker: NA
Text: at present, prices f or primary produce

Speaker: NA
Text: can be guaranteed f o r only six months

Speaker: NA
Text: after the end of the war. However, that

Speaker: NA
Text: is not the fault of this Government. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have always advocated guaranteed prices

Speaker: NA
Text: for all primary products and u n t il

Speaker: NA
Text: guaranteed prices are paid, the primary

Speaker: NA
Text: producer w i l l not have a f a i r chance of

Speaker: NA
Text: survival. He w i l l be forced to put his

Speaker: NA
Text: products on the market when they are

Speaker: NA
Text: ready and he w i l l be at the mercy of

Speaker: NA
Text: the exploiters, who are numerous.

Speaker: NA
Text: shall now quote some extracts from a

Speaker: NA
Text: publication on primary production which

Speaker: NA
Text: should be of interest to the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member f or Bendigo ( Mr R a n k i n ) -

Speaker: NA
Text: The Country party was associated with

Speaker: NA
Text: the then United Australia party for many

Speaker: NA
Text: years but they were more concerned about

Speaker: NA
Text: securing ministerial office than about fighting

Speaker: NA
Text: for the interests they were supposed to repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent. Mr Wilson, Independent Country party

Speaker: NA
Text: member in 1940 said that had members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Country party displayed the same

Speaker: NA
Text: vigour and aggressiveness on behalf of the

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat-growers that they displayed in achieving

Speaker: NA
Text: their personal ambitions, the farmers would

Speaker: NA
Text: be in a better position.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Langtry.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Wheatgrower of Western Australia con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained an article in which i t said, " What

Speaker: NA
Text: traitors these Federal Country party repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives have proved themselves to the people

Speaker: NA
Text: they claim to represent." The article went on

Speaker: NA
Text: to say, " The numerous representatives to the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Australia party-Country party Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Government proved the futility of making

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives to a party whose aims and

Speaker: NA
Text: as objects were and are completely at variance

Speaker: NA
Text: with the aims of primary producers ".

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a further extract from the same

Speaker: NA
Text: publication-

Speaker: NA
Text: It is estimated that as a result of assured

Speaker: NA
Text: markets and payable prices, returns to primary

Speaker: NA
Text: producers are now about £40,000,000 a year

Speaker: NA
Text: higher than before the war. At tlie same time,

Speaker: NA
Text: bank indebtedness of primary producers lias

Speaker: NA
Text: been reduced by about £00,000,000 compared

Speaker: NA
Text: with pre-war figures.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable members opposite overlook

Speaker: NA
Text: many of the things that this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has done. I t has subsidized the

Speaker: NA
Text: producers of necessary primary commo-

Speaker: NA
Text: dities. There are many of these, but

Speaker: NA
Text: they have not been mentioned by honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentlemen opposite. Here are some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the things that this Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: doing-

Speaker: NA
Text: Wheat-growers, with other producers, receive

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefit of a Commonwealth subsidy on

Speaker: NA
Text: superphosphate. In December, 1941, assent

Speaker: NA
Text: was given to a bill introduced by the present

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Commerce and Agriculture pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: viding for the appropriation of £850,000 to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide a subsidy on superphosphate of £1 5s.

Speaker: NA
Text: a ton. In March, 1943, the Primary Producers'

Speaker: NA
Text: Relief ((Superphosphate) Act was passed. This

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriated the sum of £900,000 to enable the

Speaker: NA
Text: price to be pegged on the basis of £5 Is. a ton

Speaker: NA
Text: for 18 per cent, superphosphate. Last year

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of the subsidy rose to £1,300,000

Speaker: NA
Text: and the estimate for the present year is

Speaker: NA
Text: £2,750,000. The Government believes that it

Speaker: NA
Text: is of the utmost importance to assist growers

Speaker: NA
Text: to keep down the costs of production.

Speaker: NA
Text: Action has also been taken to peg the price

Speaker: NA
Text: of cornsacks at 13s. 4Jd. a dozen, f.o.r. capital

Speaker: NA
Text: I cities. . The subsidy on cornsacks is costing

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth £1,000,000 a year, or

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately 5s. a dozen.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government will pay all transport costs

Speaker: NA
Text: for wheat shipped interstate during the

Speaker: NA
Text: drought. The transport of wheat interstate

Speaker: NA
Text: may cost about £2,000,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the true story.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member f o r Kennedy

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Riordan) made a fine, well-con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered speech on the subject of water con-

Speaker: NA
Text: servation, and I compliment him upon his

Speaker: NA
Text: effort. There is no more important pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: blem facing this Parliament than that of

Speaker: NA
Text: water conservation, because i t involves

Speaker: NA
Text: the prevention of soil erosion. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: ample evidence of what this nation has

Speaker: NA
Text: suffered for many years as the result

Speaker: NA
Text: of water shortages. We should concen-

Speaker: NA
Text: trate on persuading State governments to

Speaker: NA
Text: make good use of money which should be

Speaker: NA
Text: provided by the Commonwealth for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of water conservation. A great

Speaker: NA
Text: deal of interstate jealousy has occurred

Speaker: NA
Text: over the proposed diversion of the Snowy

Speaker: NA
Text: River waters. I n New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: millions of cubic feet of water run away

Speaker: NA
Text: to the sea every week. Settlers in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Riverina and western New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: have been agitating for a long time to

Speaker: NA
Text: Iiave the Snowy River waters diverted to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Murrumbidgee, and the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales Government appointed a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee to investigate the matter. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended the diversion of that water

Speaker: NA
Text: tor the purpose of irrigation. Since the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee made its report, a deputation

Speaker: NA
Text: has waited on the Premier of Victoria

Speaker: NA
Text: requesting that the water be used in a

Speaker: NA
Text: hydro-electric scheme for Victoria. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: is difficult to say where that water will

Speaker: NA
Text: be used. I f we cannot get water in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Riverina area from the Snowy River

Speaker: NA
Text: landowners iu the dry areas will be

Speaker: NA
Text: severely handicapped. Only a few days

Speaker: NA
Text: ago we read in the newspapers that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hume Weir had only 27 days' supply of

Speaker: NA
Text: water left. The Murray Valley covers a

Speaker: NA
Text: vast area and there should be sufficient

Speaker: NA
Text: water in the weir to last, another two

Speaker: NA
Text: years, not 27 days. When the plans and

Speaker: NA
Text: specifications for the Hume Weir were

Speaker: NA
Text: first prepared, they provided for the

Speaker: NA
Text: removal of Tallangatta, a town of about

Speaker: NA
Text: 800 inhabitants, which would have cost

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government about £500,000 in com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pensation. However, that was not done

Speaker: NA
Text: and the weir now can hold about half

Speaker: NA
Text: of the quantity of water that could have

Speaker: NA
Text: been stored. That fact should be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered seriously with a view to increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the storage capacity of the reservoir.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, the Commonwealth has

Speaker: NA
Text: no control over this matter owing to

Speaker: NA
Text: the defeat of the referendum proposals,

Speaker: NA
Text: but every member of Parliament through-

Speaker: NA
Text: out Australia should interest himself in

Speaker: NA
Text: tbis vital problem of water conservation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since 1902 the people have lost millions

Speaker: NA
Text: of pounds as the result of droughts. For

Speaker: NA
Text: instance, the rice-planting programme

Speaker: NA
Text: was restricted last year because there

Speaker: NA
Text: not sufficient water in the Burrinjuck

Speaker: NA
Text: dam. With present machinery and

Speaker: NA
Text: engineering methods, we could make

Speaker: NA
Text: many dams to retain the water that

Speaker: NA
Text: falls in the wet seasons, and we should

Speaker: NA
Text: never be short of water. Unless we have

Speaker: NA
Text: extensive irrigation schemes, Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: will be in a bad way for the next genera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Erosion is increasing and our

Speaker: NA
Text: annual rainfall is decreasing in every

Speaker: NA
Text: State. With water we could use scien-

Speaker: NA
Text: tific methods to bind the soil, encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: the growth of herbage, and thus prevent

Speaker: NA
Text: further erosion. I hope that honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members will take serious note of what

Speaker: NA
Text: tlie honorable member for Kennedy said

Speaker: NA
Text: on this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: The subject of housing has been sadly

Speaker: NA
Text: neglected. That is not the fault of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, because our man-power

Speaker: NA
Text: resources have been used to the

Speaker: NA
Text: utmost in defending the nation. I

Speaker: NA
Text: compliment the Prime Minister on his

Speaker: NA
Text: firm attitude in prosecuting Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: war effort. Had it not been for his

Speaker: NA
Text: foresight and his consistent advocacy

Speaker: NA
Text: of a policy of 'obtaining assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: from another country we might not

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to meet in this Parliament to-day.

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary producers have complained

Speaker: NA
Text: about petrol and motor vehicle tyre short-

Speaker: NA
Text: ages, but this Government has done a good

Speaker: NA
Text: job in the interests of everybody. I support

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Wide Bay ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Corser), who said that at the first oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity the Government should make more

Speaker: NA
Text: petrol and tyres available to primary

Speaker: NA
Text: producers. The primary producers have

Speaker: NA
Text: been handicapped by force of circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances over which the Government had

Speaker: NA
Text: no control, but now that the immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: danger to the country has passed, and

Speaker: NA
Text: with the improvement in the petrol and

Speaker: NA
Text: rubber supply position, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: should, at the first opportunity, increase

Speaker: NA
Text: the ration to primary producers. Ration-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of these commodities has been carried

Speaker: NA
Text: out on an unsatisfactory basis. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: of cases in my own electorate in which

Speaker: NA
Text: men living within 2 or 3 miles of

Speaker: NA
Text: a town have been receiving the same

Speaker: NA
Text: ration as men living 15 or 20 miles out.

Speaker: NA
Text: When one is 15 or 20 miles from a

Speaker: NA
Text: town, it is difficult to get a doctor in case

Speaker: NA
Text: of illness. The whole of the people of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth have risen magnificently

Speaker: NA
Text: to the occasion. But there is a limit to

Speaker: NA
Text: was human endurance. Primary producers

Speaker: NA
Text: have done their best to meet the.force

Speaker: NA
Text: of circumstances, but tbey cannot con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue much longer, and our food prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems are likely to become greater. I

Speaker: NA
Text: -was pleased to bear tbe Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: promise a review of the man-power posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion by next June. The primary indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries are entitled to first consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: i n regard to man-power, because our fight-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing men must be fed. [Extension of time

Speaker: NA
Text: granted.] I hope that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: will consider the representations that I

Speaker: NA
Text: have made in regard to man-power, petrol

Speaker: NA
Text: and tyres. I realize, of; course, that it

Speaker: NA
Text: is faced with the problem of meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: many needs with few men, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: nobody can be expected to do what is

Speaker: NA
Text: impossible. We are lucky to be living

Speaker: NA
Text: still in a free country.

Speaker: NA
Text: I emphasize the paramount necessity

Speaker: NA
Text: making provision for water conservation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was i n the House when the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Kalgoorlie ( Mr Johnson)

Speaker: NA
Text: quoted those striking verses which Henry

Speaker: NA
Text: Lawson wrote in. the poem The Storm

Speaker: NA
Text: That is to Come. I f Lawson were alive

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day, he could not write truer words

Speaker: NA
Text: than " The drought has yet to break".

Speaker: NA
Text: Ifl it continues for another six months,

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of Australia will suffer

Speaker: NA
Text: severely from the mistakes that have

Speaker: NA
Text: been made in the past. I t is not yet

Speaker: NA
Text: late for the situation to be saved. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: not seen many droughts break before

Speaker: NA
Text: June. Let us be guided by the past, and

Speaker: NA
Text: not repeat its mistakes in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Water is the only thing which will make

Speaker: NA
Text: this country what it ought to be. I

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot do better than repeat the lines

Speaker: NA
Text: written hy Henry Lawson-

Speaker: NA
Text: I have pictured long in the land

Speaker: NA
Text: what the land I love might be,

Speaker: NA
Text: Whore the Darling rises from Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: rains and the floods rush out to the

Speaker: NA
Text: And is i t our fate to wake too late

Speaker: NA
Text: trut h that we have been blind,

Speaker: NA
Text: With a foreign foe at our harbour-gate and

Speaker: NA
Text: a blazing drought behind?

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us prepare for the next drought

Speaker: NA
Text: having the water with which to combat

Speaker: NA
Text: it. Our people then will be properly

Speaker: NA
Text: and will live in contentment. Any goBritain,

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment that tackles the matter of water

Speaker: NA
Text: conservation will have to its credit

Speaker: NA
Text: standing monument.

Speaker: NA
Text: the last five years, the major attention

Speaker: NA
Text: of the nation has been f ocused upon the

Speaker: NA
Text: winning of the present terrible war.

Speaker: NA
Text: With_ our allies, we can now state with

Speaker: NA
Text: certainty that the war cannot be lost to

Speaker: NA
Text: us. The propaganda , machine of the

Speaker: NA
Text: German Reich is feverishly seeking some

Speaker: NA
Text: means whereby it can split the unity of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Allied Nations and thereby cause

Speaker: NA
Text: them to lose the peace. Whilst I am pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to agree that those who make a

Speaker: NA
Text: particular study of foreign affairs are

Speaker: NA
Text: inclined, to look beyond the immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: problems at home, I , nevertheless, con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider that this House could devote more

Speaker: NA
Text: attention to our relationships with other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. Some criticism has been

Speaker: NA
Text: directed at the Government for not hav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing provided more opportunity for the

Speaker: NA
Text: House to debate international politics. I

Speaker: NA
Text: regard this criticism as most unfair. The

Speaker: NA
Text: of Minister for External Affairs (Dr Evatt)

Speaker: NA
Text: has made many excellent statements on

Speaker: NA
Text: which this subject could have been, de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bated had not the members of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA

Text: When oil that memorable day, 11th June,

Text: clusion of a treaty of alliance with the Uuion

Text: of Soviet Socialist Republics, I immediately

Speaker: NA
Text: commented: " As one who has laboured for

Text: over twenty years to establish a good under-

Text: standing between Soviet Russia and this coun-

Speaker: NA

Text: been a fact some years ago many grave

Speaker: NA
Text: avoided. Not only that, this war could never

Speaker: NA
Text: have occurred ". There was no exaggeration m

Speaker: NA
Text: these words; I meant every one of them. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: might have added that the Covenant of the

Text: League would have become an established and
