Text: goodwill amongst men " would have been well

Speaker: NA
Text: on the way.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us trace the history of this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: After the Russian revolution of Novem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber, 1917, the newly formed Soviet State

Speaker: NA
Text: was attacked by fourteen different powers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Already weakened by the war with Ger-

Speaker: NA
Text: many, it was thus further seriously

Speaker: NA
Text: weakened. During the progress of this war

Speaker: NA
Text: of intervention, the war of 1914-18 ended

Speaker: NA
Text: and a new Polish State was established,

Speaker: NA
Text: the eastern frontier being agreed upon

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Allied Supreme Council in 1919.

Speaker: NA
Text: This frontier has since been known as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Ourzon Line; it was named after the

Speaker: NA
Text: then British Foreign Secretary, Lord

Speaker: NA
Text: * Ourzon, a hard-bitten tory and a

Speaker: NA
Text: bitter enemy of the young Soviet

Speaker: NA
Text: State. The Allied Supreme Council

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed that the country east of this

Speaker: NA
Text: line was etbnologically, geographically

Speaker: NA
Text: and historically a part of the Ukraine

Speaker: NA
Text: and Byelo-Russia. On the 16th April,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1919, Poland launched a wanton and

Speaker: NA
Text: an unprovoked attack on the weakened

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet State, and by force of arms

Speaker: NA
Text: annexed western Byelo-Russia

Speaker: NA
Text: western Ukraine. From 1922 to 1925,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Polish Constitution gave the hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that Poland would become a democratic

Speaker: NA
Text: State, but the Pilsudski coup d'etat made

Speaker: NA
Text: Poland a Fascist State. The Pilsudski

Speaker: NA
Text: Fascist dictatorship embarked upon a

Speaker: NA
Text: policy of Polandization of tlie con-

Speaker: NA
Text: quered territory. I t made Polish the

Speaker: NA
Text: official language, withdrew religious

Speaker: NA
Text: freedom by suppressing the Greek Ortho-

Speaker: NA
Text: dox Church in favour of the official

Speaker: NA
Text: church of Poland, and in general carried

Speaker: NA
Text: out a policy of suppression of those four

Speaker: NA
Text: great freedoms which have since been

Speaker: NA
Text: outlined in the Atlantic Charter. The

Speaker: NA
Text: population was decimated and hundreds

Speaker: NA
Text: of homes were burnt to the ground in a

Speaker: NA
Text: vain endeavour to repress the inhabi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tants of the annexed regions. The people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Galicia resisted this oppression almost

Speaker: NA
Text: to the day when they were liberated by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Red Army.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the 4th September, 1939, Germany

Speaker: NA
Text: invaded Poland. The Polish Army, hope-

Speaker: NA
Text: lessly out of date and consisting mainly

Speaker: NA
Text: of horse cavalry, was no match for the-

Speaker: NA
Text: modern mechanized army of Germany-

Speaker: NA
Text: Despite the courage of its soldiers, Poland,

Speaker: NA
Text: went down in defeat within a fortnight;,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Polish Government, which had'

Speaker: NA
Text: rejected Soviet aid, fled the country. I n .

Speaker: NA
Text: these circumstances the Government of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics

Speaker: NA
Text: ordered the Red Army into eastern.

Speaker: NA
Text: Poland on the 17th September, in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to protect from Nazi brutality its blood

Speaker: NA
Text: brothers the Byelo-Russians and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Ukrainians in eastern Poland, and to

Speaker: NA
Text: make secure the rich corn-fields and

Speaker: NA
Text: mineral deposits of the Ukraine. By its

Speaker: NA
Text: march into Poland, the Soviet Union

Speaker: NA
Text: saved from Nazi bestialities, for the time

Speaker: NA
Text: being, millions of Ukrainians, Byelo-

Speaker: NA
Text: Russians and Jews, increased the distance

Speaker: NA
Text: between Germany and the old Soviet

Speaker: NA
Text: frontier, and gained additional time in

Speaker: NA
Text: which to strengthen its defences against

Speaker: NA
Text: the attack which it knew must come.

Speaker: NA
Text: This action, ofi course, gave a new lease of

Speaker: NA
Text: life to all those propaganda agencies

Speaker: NA
Text: which had been busily lying about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet Union from its earliest days.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Lloyd George came out strongly

Speaker: NA
Text: against those who recklessly demanded

Speaker: NA
Text: stern action against the .Soviet Union. I

Speaker: NA
Text: quote an extract from a letter sent to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Polish Ambassador in London on the

Speaker: NA
Text: and 28th September, 1939-

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is a notorious fact that the Polish peasants

Speaker: NA
Text: are living in great poverty owing to the

Speaker: NA
Text: operation of the worst feudal system in

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe. That aristocracy has been practically

Speaker: NA
Text: in power for years. A l l the promises of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessions made from time to time to the

Speaker: NA
Text: peasants have been thwarted by its influence

Speaker: NA
Text: on recent Polish Governments. That is why

Speaker: NA
Text: the advancing Russian troops are being hailed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the peasants as deliverers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The German invasion is designed to annex

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Reich provinces where the decided

Speaker: NA
Text: majority of the population is Polish by race,

Speaker: NA
Text: language and tradition. On the other hand,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Russian armies marched into territories

Speaker: NA
Text: which are not Polish, and which were forcibly

Speaker: NA
Text: annexed by Poland after the Great War, in

Speaker: NA
Text: spite of the fierce protests and the armed

Speaker: NA
Text: resistance of the inhabitants. The inhabi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tants of Polish Ukraine are of the same race

Speaker: NA
Text: and language as their neighbours in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Ukrainian Republic of the Soviet Union.

Speaker: NA
Text: I felt it was a matter of primary import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance to call attention at once to these salient

Speaker: NA
Text: considerations lest we commit ourselves

Speaker: NA
Text: rashly to war against Russia under tlie impres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion that her intervention was identical with

Speaker: NA
Text: that of Germany. The distinction between

Speaker: NA
Text: the two cases is increasingly acknowledged by

Speaker: NA
Text: British and French opinion. In these circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances it would be an act of criminal folly

Speaker: NA
Text: to place the Russian advance in the same

Speaker: NA
Text: category as that of the Germans, although it

Speaker: NA
Text: would suit Herr Hitler's designs that we

Speaker: NA
Text: should do so. I am delighted that our Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment have shown no indication of committing

Speaker: NA
Text: this country to such an attitude or enter-

Speaker: NA
Text: prise.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Soviet Union had thus blocked, for

Speaker: NA
Text: the time being, any further German ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: 7S11C6. A t 4 a.m. on the 22nd June, 1941,

Speaker: NA
Text: it was attacked by German forces. These

Speaker: NA
Text: events are fresh i n the minds of, every-

Speaker: NA
Text: body. There were some who predicted a

Speaker: NA
Text: swift Russian collapse. I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: they were, and for that matter still are,

Speaker: NA
Text: disappointed that this event did not occur.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Red Army was forced to retreat many

Speaker: NA
Text: hundreds of miles, but i t did not lose its

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting efficiency. Now, of course, the

Speaker: NA
Text: battle has been taken to German soil,

Speaker: NA
Text: Poland having heen liberated on the

Speaker: NA
Text: way.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: Menzies) was concerned lest

Speaker: NA
Text: Lublin Provisional Government-a

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment on the spot-should

Speaker: NA
Text: reflect the opinion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Poles. By wishful

Speaker: NA
Text: he reasoned that perhaps the emigre

Speaker: NA
Text: Government in London might represent

Speaker: NA
Text: Polish opinion. It must be admitted

Speaker: NA
Text: that until a ftree election has been held

Speaker: NA
Text: there is room for doubt, however slender

Speaker: NA
Text: it might be. Had the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman taken the trouble to study

Speaker: NA
Text: the decisions of the Yalta Conference,

Speaker: NA
Text: he would have found that the question

Speaker: NA
Text: had been answered in advance. That con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference laid it down that the Lublin Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment must be so broadened by the

Speaker: NA
Text: inclusion of democratic elements at home

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Mountjoy.

Speaker: NA
Text: and abroad as to make i t trul y repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentative of all shades of Polish opinion;

Speaker: NA
Text: and further, that free elections must be

Speaker: NA
Text: held at the earliest possible moment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that I have said enough to show

Speaker: NA
Text: that fears as to Poland's future are

Speaker: NA
Text: without foundation. The Sydney Morn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Herald of the 1st March, published a

Speaker: NA
Text: leading article i n which the following

Speaker: NA
Text: comments occurred:-

Speaker: NA
Text: To those critics who, like Sir William

Speaker: NA
Text: Beveridge, seem prone already to anticipate

Speaker: NA
Text: having to make a choice between " friends

Speaker: NA
Text: and principles", Mr Churchill said, in effect,

Speaker: NA
Text: they could not hope to enjoy both tlie luxury of

Speaker: NA
Text: old prejudices and the benefits of a co-operative

Speaker: NA
Text: international society freed from the menace of

Speaker: NA
Text: war. To have faith in a world peace organiza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and no faith in Russia is an incongruity

Speaker: NA
Text: for which there can be no accommodation in

Speaker: NA
Text: the post-war world, where materially and

Speaker: NA
Text: psychologically every nation will have to be

Speaker: NA
Text: rebuilt afresh, and rebuilt as a member of an

Speaker: NA
Text: international order devoted to the outlawing

Speaker: NA
Text: of war. The ideal may prove to be beyond

Speaker: NA
Text: human roach, but at least if the world means

Speaker: NA
Text: to strive for it there can be no condoning of

Speaker: NA
Text: such suspicions as those which Mr Churchill

Speaker: NA
Text: condemned.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is this incompatibility of aims which lm?

Speaker: NA
Text: disfigured the activities of the Polish Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in London, and exposes the weak case of

Speaker: NA
Text: those who protest that the Yalta resolutions

Speaker: NA
Text: are a desertion of the principles of the Atlantic

Speaker: NA
Text: Charter and of Britain's pre-war pledge to

Speaker: NA
Text: Poland. Obviously the London Poles had no

Speaker: NA
Text: voice in the redrawing of the map of Poland,

Speaker: NA
Text: or in the debates on the establishment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: "Provisional Polish Government of National

Speaker: NA
Text: Unity ", which the Allies have agreed shall be

Speaker: NA
Text: set up in place of both the London Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and the Lublin Committee. But on what

Speaker: NA
Text: ground is it maintained that there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: majority Polish view in favour of the Allies',

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangement; and how, save at the free elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr tions to be held under the new Provisional

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government, is the voice of Poland to be ascer-

Speaker: NA
Text: go- tained? In the political administration there

Speaker: NA
Text: is nothing settled which the prescribed vote of

Speaker: NA
Text: not the Polish people themselves cannot change,

Speaker: NA
Text: majority and, if the London Poles did not participate

Speaker: NA
Text: thinking, with the Lublin Committee in the preliminary

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiations in Moscow, that is due solely t"

Speaker: NA
Text: their obstinate refusal to do so. The necessity

Speaker: NA
Text: for some interim administration in the

Speaker: NA
Text: liberated country before the end of the war

Speaker: NA
Text: was clearly pointed out by Mr Churchill:

Speaker: NA
Text: Russia, he said, as the instrument of Poland's

Speaker: NA
Text: liberation, had a right, while engaged in large-

Speaker: NA
Text: scale operations against the heart of Germany,

Speaker: NA
Text: to have her army communications assured in

Speaker: NA
Text: an orderly countryside.

Speaker: NA
Text: As for the objection to the redrawing of

Speaker: NA
Text: Poland's eastern boundary, Mr Churchill

Speaker: NA
Text: justly protested that the " Curzon line" is not

Speaker: NA
Text: a Russian imposition on Pola,nd, but an

Speaker: NA
Text: ethnographical border proposed by the British

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign Office in 1919. In 1939 i t was made

Speaker: NA
Text: quite clear by tlie British Government that its

Speaker: NA
Text: guarantee to Poland related to the meditated

Speaker: NA
Text: German aggression and was never intended t °

Speaker: NA
Text: cover her eastern frontiers. The territorial

Speaker: NA
Text: compensation now proposed for Poland,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially on the Baltic, will make not only

Speaker: NA
Text: for a stronger State but also for one more

Speaker: NA
Text: easily protected by its sponsors. I t was the

Speaker: NA
Text: exposure of the pre-war Poland to German

Speaker: NA
Text: aggression which made any guarantee of her

Speaker: NA
Text: independence so precarious. Only Russia's

Speaker: NA
Text: strong arm and goodwill can preserve Polan.

Speaker: NA
Text: from any future German attack, and, in that

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility, Russia is entitled to be assured

Speaker: NA
Text: of the best position for any such action com-

Speaker: NA
Text: patible with ethnographical realities. Tin:

Speaker: NA
Text: critics, Polish or other, of the Allies' plan can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not be brought to explain why an eastern

Speaker: NA
Text: frontier which was adjudged just in 1919 by

Speaker: NA
Text: experts who certainly had no prejudices in

Speaker: NA
Text: favour of Soviet Russia, should be considered

Speaker: NA
Text: a.ny less so to-day.

Speaker: NA
Text: That leading article more than answers

Speaker: NA
Text: the accusations of the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition and the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Barker ( Mr Archie Cameron).

Speaker: NA
Text: He would be a bold man who

Speaker: NA
Text: would say that that journal is pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: judiced in favour of the Soviet Union.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not even the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: would make such a charge, especially in

Speaker: NA
Text: view of the large amount of space that

Speaker: NA
Text: that newspaper now gives to him for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of spreading his anti-Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: theories.

Speaker: NA
Text: A great deal of progressive legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: has be«n outlined in the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General's Speech. That fact has been

Speaker: NA
Text: seized upon by members of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion who now accuse the Government of

Speaker: NA
Text: distracting the minds of the people from

Speaker: NA
Text: the immediate tasks of war. The facts are.

Speaker: NA
Text: of course, that the plutocrats are tired of

Speaker: NA
Text: the war, and it is their propaganda that

Speaker: NA
Text: is disturbing the people's minds. The

Speaker: NA
Text: workers are not fools. I t is as patent to

Speaker: NA
Text: them as to anybody else that the glitter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing promise of the " new order " made by

Speaker: NA
Text: scared reactionaries back in 1941, and

Speaker: NA
Text: early in 1942, is not to be honoured. I f a

Speaker: NA
Text: " new order " is to be, i t must be fought

Speaker: NA
Text: for. Any one who thinks that the people

Speaker: NA
Text: who now hold power and wealth will re-

Speaker: NA
Text: treat from their position of privilege will

Speaker: NA
Text: be sadly mistaken. Vested interests have

Speaker: NA
Text: already commenced their offensive. Tens

Speaker: NA
Text: of thousands of pounds, which should be

Speaker: NA
Text: going into war loans, are now being

Speaker: NA
Text: spent on anti-working class propaganda.

Speaker: NA
Text: Newspaper space, leaflets and radio time

Speaker: NA
Text: are being used in an attempt to create

Speaker: NA
Text: a feeling of distrust and doubt. The

Speaker: NA
Text: working people can quite easily see that,

Speaker: NA
Text: if they are to be i n a position to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: this offensive on their wages and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions when the war is over, they must

Speaker: NA
Text: build up wages and conditions now while

Speaker: NA
Text: they have the chance. The amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial unrest is directly propor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionate to the volume and intensity of

Speaker: NA
Text: the propaganda o f the O p p o s i t i o n forces.

Speaker: NA
Text: T h e L a b o u r p a r t y is n o t d a u n t e d by

Speaker: NA
Text: thi s flood o f propaganda, n o r are t h e

Speaker: NA
Text: people deceived b y i t . I have before me

Speaker: NA
Text: a n unsolicited letter signed b y twenty*

Speaker: NA
Text: f i v e f a r m e r s i n a small c o u n t r y t o w n ,

Speaker: NA
Text: w h i c h is one o f m a n y such letters t h a t I

Speaker: NA
Text: have received. I t states-

Speaker: NA
Text: Dear Sir,

Speaker: NA
Text: We, tlie undersigned, desire to assure you

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Government that we are not being

Speaker: NA
Text: influenced by press and,' Ibamk propaganda

Speaker: NA
Text: against the pending legislation dealing with

Speaker: NA
Text: banking, and, for that matter, the taking over

Speaker: NA
Text: of the airways. We stand right behind the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government iu any course i t may be advisable

Speaker: NA
Text: to take.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t may ibe claimed that the banking system

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia is the best ever; but we are of

Speaker: NA
Text: the opinion that many changes can be effected

Speaker: NA
Text: for the betterment of the people as a w' o e.

Speaker: NA
Text: In reference to the wheat scheme, let i t be

Speaker: NA
Text: known that wo consider the Scully Quota

Speaker: NA
Text: Scheme was the salvation of the smaller

Speaker: NA
Text: growers. We trust we will not be landed

Speaker: NA
Text: back into the unenviable position which pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vailed iprior to the scheme coming into being.

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall not read the names of the signa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tories, as I know that many of them are

Speaker: NA
Text: clients of private banks, and to read

Speaker: NA
Text: their nameswould leave them open to

Speaker: NA
Text: victimization by those " benevolent" in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stitutions. I t will be noted that they also

Speaker: NA
Text: support the Scully wheat scheme, and as

Speaker: NA
Text: the twisted reasoning of the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Indi ( Mr MCEwen) has

Speaker: NA
Text: once again been exposed by my friend

Speaker: NA
Text: and colleague, the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Forrest ( Mr Lemmon), I shall not com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment further, other than to warn the

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers that this campaign being waged

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honorable memiber for Indi, Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: John Teasdale, and others is designed

Speaker: NA
Text: to smash the Australian Wheat Board

Speaker: NA
Text: and land the growers back into the

Speaker: NA
Text: tender hands of the wheat agents, once

Speaker: NA
Text: more to be mercilessly exploited. The

Speaker: NA
Text: events of the last five years have clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: shown that only a Labour Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has the courage and capacity to lead

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation in these difficult times. The

Speaker: NA
Text: events of tie future will show that only

Speaker: NA
Text: a Labour Government has the courage

Speaker: NA
Text: and foresight to meet the difficult periods

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead. Just as it planned to meet the

Speaker: NA
Text: war situation it now plans for peace.

Speaker: NA
Text: The ,pToblem of Australia's need for

Speaker: NA
Text: increased population seems to be a hardy

Speaker: NA
Text: annual in this chamber. Undoubtedly,

Speaker: NA
Text: this country needs more people. That

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be denied. Neither can i t be

Speaker: NA
Text: denied that the best way to increase the

Speaker: NA
Text: population is to rely on the natural

Speaker: NA
Text: increase, but the solution is not so simple

Speaker: NA
Text: that we merely need a "grow more

Speaker: NA
Text: babies" campaign. I f we are to have

Speaker: NA
Text: more people, either by natural increase

Speaker: NA
Text: or by immigration, work must be found

Speaker: NA
Text: for them. I t is worsethan useless to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase the population and have .that

Speaker: NA
Text: increased number out of work, sleeping

Speaker: NA
Text: -under bridges, or filling unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: -camps. We need more people to increase

Speaker: NA
Text: the wealth of our country and to develop

Speaker: NA
Text: our natural resources to a greater degree

Speaker: NA
Text: than at present. Numbers of people

Speaker: NA
Text: alone do not increase wealth. Only by

Speaker: NA
Text: people working can wealth be produced.

Speaker: NA
Text: The farmer on his land, the worker at

Speaker: NA
Text: the factory bench, the man or woman

Speaker: NA
Text: performing some socially necessary task,

Speaker: NA
Text: are the wealth producers. The gilded

Speaker: NA
Text: society damsel or the wealthy loafer in

Speaker: NA
Text: his club chair produce no more wealth

Speaker: NA
Text: than the poor unfortunate sheltering

Speaker: NA
Text: under a bridge, although, of course, one

Speaker: NA
Text: gets the lion's share of the wealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some one else produces, and the other,

Speaker: NA
Text: denied the right to work, has perfect

Speaker: NA
Text: freedom to starve.

Speaker: NA
Text: It follows, then, that before populatremendous

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is increased work should be guaranland

Speaker: NA
Text: teed. How is this work to be found?

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest that that can be done in two

Speaker: NA
Text: ways. In the first place we should

Speaker: NA
Text: expand secondary industries. In this

Speaker: NA
Text: field Western Australia opens up almost

Speaker: NA
Text: untouched resources. In that State there

Speaker: NA
Text: are. large deposits of almost every

Speaker: NA
Text: mineral known to man. The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Kalgoorlie ( Mr Johnson)

Speaker: NA
Text: has told us something about those reare

Speaker: NA
Text: sources, and about his personal observaEast

Speaker: NA
Text: tions in that part of Australia. SeconIndia,

Speaker: NA
Text: dary industry could be expanded if

Speaker: NA
Text: employed more people than at present in

Speaker: NA
Text: processing our own wool and making

Speaker: NA
Text: own cloth. We were told to-day that

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Mount joy.

Speaker: NA
Text: double-weft cloth is being made in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia in order to capture the New Zea-

Speaker: NA
Text: land market. I f that work can be

Speaker: NA
Text: done in the eastern States it can also

Speaker: NA
Text: be done in Western Australia, because

Speaker: NA
Text: the Albany Woollen Mills are capable

Speaker: NA
Text: of competing with any other mills of

Speaker: NA
Text: the kind in the Commonwealth. The

Speaker: NA
Text: second way in which I suggest work

Speaker: NA
Text: could be found is by expanding primary

Speaker: NA
Text: production. During the present drought,

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia has once again proved

Speaker: NA
Text: the sheet-anchor of Australia in the

Speaker: NA
Text: supply of grain. That State occasionally

Speaker: NA
Text: experiences dry years, but a general

Speaker: NA
Text: drought is unknown there. I t has never

Speaker: NA
Text: had a devastating drought such as that

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced in the eastern States. I n the

Speaker: NA
Text: safest rainfall area in Australia-south -

Speaker: NA
Text: western Australia-18,000,00 0 acres of

Speaker: NA
Text: country, after providing for forests,

Speaker: NA
Text: awaits development. The climate in that

Speaker: NA
Text: area-a s a white man's country-ha s no

Speaker: NA
Text: peer in all the world. Western Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia grows the best grapes in the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth, although that statement may

Speaker: NA
Text: be contested by honorable memlbers from

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia. I f any honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member will visit the Swan Valley with

Speaker: NA
Text: me, I shall show him that, although

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia does not make a

Speaker: NA
Text: great deal of wine, it produces the best.

Speaker: NA
Text: This has been proved many times by

Speaker: NA
Text: wines from the Houghton vineyards, at

Speaker: NA
Text: Middle Swan, which have defeated those

Speaker: NA
Text: of all-comers at the Melbourne Royal

Speaker: NA
Text: Show, including Seppelts, Penfolds, and

Speaker: NA
Text: other well-known makers. Those safe

Speaker: NA
Text: rainfall areas in Western Australia have

Speaker: NA
Text: potentialities; but, if closer

Speaker: NA
Text: settlement is to be made a reality,

Speaker: NA
Text: large estates will have to be subdivided.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of these estates have been developed,

Speaker: NA
Text: but others are covered with virgin bush.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another problem which must be faced

Speaker: NA
Text: is to find markets in which to sell our

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus products, and the more we develop

Speaker: NA
Text: the land the greater will be the surplus.

Speaker: NA
Text: Viewing this problem as a layman, it

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to me that our natural markets

Speaker: NA
Text: to be found, not in Europe, but in

Speaker: NA
Text: Asia. The people of Java, China,

Speaker: NA
Text: Burma and the Malay States, i f

Speaker: NA
Text: we they had a higher standard of living,

Speaker: NA
Text: could use more goods than Australia could

Speaker: NA
Text: our ever produce. The Soviet Union could

Speaker: NA
Text: take a tremendous quantity of our wool.

Speaker: NA
Text: The people of Australia have a very real

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in the standard 'of living of our

Speaker: NA
Text: near neighbours, and we should use what

Speaker: NA
Text: influence we have in world affairs to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist them to secure political inde-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendence.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am firmly convinced that the basic

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of the declining birth-rate is

Speaker: NA
Text: economic, as is borne out by vital

Speaker: NA
Text: statistics-

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable members will note the

Speaker: NA
Text: gradual decline during the depression

Speaker: NA
Text: years. I n 1934, the volume of employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment increased a little, so that in 1936 the

Speaker: NA
Text: birth-rate rose to 16.55. I n 1936, it rose

Speaker: NA
Text: still further to 17.13, in 19'37 to 17.43, in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1938 to 17.46, and in 1939, the last year

Speaker: NA
Text: for which figures are available, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: 17.65. These figures definitely show that

Speaker: NA
Text: the birth-rate rises and falls according to

Speaker: NA
Text: the economic standard of the people. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: "course, the answer given in advance to

Speaker: NA
Text: this contention by the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for North Sydney ( Mr Hughes)

Speaker: NA
Text: i? that the more money people possess the

Speaker: NA
Text: fewer children they have. He points to

Speaker: NA
Text: the wealthy classes and says that they

Speaker: NA
Text: have very few children. He points to

Speaker: NA
Text: the working class and says that they

Speaker: NA
Text: have most children. That is perfectly

Speaker: NA
Text: true, but he fails to point out that history

Speaker: NA
Text: has always shown that a dying class has

Speaker: NA
Text: no faith in the future, being concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: only with the selfish pursuit of pleasure.

Speaker: NA
Text: The rich woman will not have children

Speaker: NA
Text: because they would interfere with her

Speaker: NA
Text: social engagements. I n the main, such

Speaker: NA
Text: people look upon children as a nuisance.

Speaker: NA
Text: The working-class woman, on the other

Speaker: NA
Text: hand, likes and has children. I n her

Speaker: NA
Text: case the limiting factors are economic-

Speaker: NA
Text: the fear of insecurity of employment, the

Speaker: NA
Text: thought that a son lovingly raised may

Speaker: NA
Text: be killed in a future war, and the fear

Speaker: NA
Text: that a son or daughter will not be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: find a job. The inability properly to

Speaker: NA
Text: feed, clothe and educate a family are

Speaker: NA
Text: powerful limiting factors.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Parkes ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Haylen) is in my corner when he advo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cates marriage loans. I go further and

Speaker: NA
Text: say, let the fear of unemployment be

Speaker: NA
Text: abolished; let us ensure that every child

Speaker: NA
Text: born in Australia shall be properly fed,

Speaker: NA
Text: clothed, housed and educated, and its

Speaker: NA
Text: future guaranteed. We should provide

Speaker: NA
Text: free kindergartens and free the working-

Speaker: NA
Text: class mother from kitchen drudgery by

Speaker: NA
Text: Birth-rate. giving her the benefit of such modern

Speaker: NA
Text: 21.27 appliances as washing machines, electric

Speaker: NA
Text: 21.25 cooking and refrigeration. We should get

Speaker: NA
Text: ISI.86 on with our building programme now in

Speaker: NA
Text: 18.10 order to relieve the serious housing

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage. We recognize that the present

Speaker: NA
Text: 10.39 Government has inherited from previous

Speaker: NA
Text: governments a housing problem, but

Speaker: NA
Text: much could be done immediately to relieve

Speaker: NA
Text: the present situation. One way would

Speaker: NA
Text: be to compel people to make available

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation which they do not need.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is only necessary to go to any of the

Speaker: NA
Text: fashionable seaside resorts to see houses

Speaker: NA
Text: which arc not being occupied. Huge

Speaker: NA
Text: mansions with a great number of rooms,

Speaker: NA
Text: that are inhabited by only two or three

Speaker: NA
Text: people, should be divided into flats. The

Speaker: NA
Text: owner could have one and the other flats

Speaker: NA
Text: should be let. Of course, i t would still be

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to build_ many houses and we

Speaker: NA
Text: should begin to do so immediately. The

Speaker: NA
Text: housing situation is desperate now-wha t

Speaker: NA
Text: will it be when the servicemen are

Speaker: NA
Text: demobilized? The position in Perth may

Speaker: NA
Text: not be as bad as in some of the other

Speaker: NA
Text: capital cities, but it is bad enough. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know one man who, with his wife and

Speaker: NA
Text: thirteen children, is living in a shack

Speaker: NA
Text: which no decent person should be required

Speaker: NA
Text: to live in, while just across the road is

Speaker: NA
Text: an empty military camp in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings are being destroyed by vandals

Speaker: NA
Text: because there is no one to look after them.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should provide houses of which people

Speaker: NA
Text: can be proud at rents which they can

Speaker: NA
Text: afford to pay, or we should sell them at

Speaker: NA
Text: prices which they can afford to give. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: we improve economic conditions as I

Speaker: NA
Text: have suggested, and provide proper hous-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and amenities for the people, the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem of the declining birth-rate will

Speaker: NA
Text: solve itself.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr SHEEHAN)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS-WHEA T INDUSTRY-

Speaker: NA
Text: NORTHERN TERRITORY.

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr CHXFLEY) proposed-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: Mr HOLT
Text: Fawkner) [ 1 0 . 7 ] -

Speaker: NA
Text: pose to discuss a matter which I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: to be of great constitutional importance,

Speaker: NA
Text: namely, tlie announcement made through

Speaker: NA
Text: the press that the Prime Minister ( M

Speaker: NA
Text: Curtin) proposed to vary the customary

Speaker: NA
Text: method of dealing with questions asked

Speaker: NA
Text: without notice i n this House. The i n

Speaker: NA
Text: mation was that he himself would answer

Speaker: NA
Text: only such questions of urgency as were

Speaker: NA
Text: directed to h i m by party leaders.

Speaker: NA
Text: regret that the Prime Minister himself

Speaker: NA
Text: not present. I understand that he is i

Speaker: NA
Text: and I hope that he w i l l have a speedy

Speaker: NA
Text: recovery. I regard this matter as of

Speaker: NA
Text: such importance that, even i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: absence of the Prime Minister, ParliaGeneral's

Speaker: NA
Text: ment cannot allow the announcement to

Speaker: NA
Text: pass without comment. This is a time

Speaker: NA
Text: when private members of Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: must assert as powerfully as they can

Speaker: NA
Text: the rights whicli they possess, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: rights which, through them, the citizens

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Commonwealth have to air their

Speaker: NA
Text: grievances i n Parliament. Question time

Speaker: NA
Text: in this House has acquired a good deal

Speaker: NA
Text: of significance, particularly i n recent

Speaker: NA
Text: years. I recall a conversation which

Speaker: NA
Text: had some time ago on this subject with

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor Kenneth Bailey, who has

Speaker: NA
Text: advised the Government on constitutional

Speaker: NA
Text: matters. I n i t he stressed the imporhim

Speaker: NA
Text: tance which question time has acquired

Speaker: NA
Text: in the proceedings of the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament. When we are faced w i t h

Speaker: NA
Text: the possibility of so grave a departure

Speaker: NA
Text: from custom as that announced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, i t calls f o r discussion,

Speaker: NA
Text: and f o r a defence by private members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the rights which they have hitherto

Speaker: NA
Text: enjoyed.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is misleading to attach too much

Speaker: NA
Text: importance to the practice i n other

Speaker: NA
Text: liaments. Each Parliament develops

Speaker: NA
Text: own practices and traditions. I n some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the State Parliaments of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: is the practice to devote more time

Speaker: NA
Text: private members' business than is done

Speaker: NA
Text: in this Parliament, Therefore, private

Speaker: NA
Text: members of this Parliament must guard

Speaker: NA
Text: jealously their limited opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: bring before Ministers and the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment matters which they feel should

Speaker: NA
Text: be ventilated. I t has been said

Speaker: NA
Text: by Ministers and Government sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: porters that the time devoted to questions

Speaker: NA
Text: without notice, as well as the number

Speaker: NA
Text: I proof questions asked, has grown. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: true, but the growth can easily be ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: plained. The increase of the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: questions arises f r o m the fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: r . business attended to by this Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: has grown and that the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: matters which come to the notice of

Speaker: NA
Text: t i - individual members has increased enor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mously i n recent years, particularly dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the war. Those of us who have had a

Speaker: NA
Text: I decade or more of service i n this Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: is ment w i l l remember that a comparatively

Speaker: NA
Text: l l , limited range of matters came before us

Speaker: NA
Text: for attention, say, ten years ago. We had

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget to discuss, and various matters

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to (pensions, or the Postmaster-

Speaker: NA
Text: Department or the Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Department came before us, but there was

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing like the mass of detail, or the

Speaker: NA
Text: complex questions that there are to-day.

Speaker: NA
Text: W i t h that growth of the number of mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters dealt with by the Parliament there

Speaker: NA
Text: has been an increase 'of the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: questions properly put to Ministers. I say

Speaker: NA
Text: properly put, because otherwise you, Mr .

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, would restrain the questioner.

Speaker: NA
Text: Had the Prime Minister said that his

Speaker: NA
Text: I health was such that he could not give

Speaker: NA
Text: personal attention to these matters i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: House, all of us would have sympathized

Speaker: NA
Text: with hi m and accepted the nomination by

Speaker: NA
Text: of some deputy to deal with matters

Speaker: NA
Text: brought to his notice, but that is not the

Speaker: NA
Text: reason that is advanced. The justifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion f o r the proposed change is said to be

Speaker: NA
Text: that the number of questions has grown,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that too much time is devoted to

Speaker: NA
Text: them. I point out that the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter is more than the head of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, although i n that capacity there are

Speaker: NA
Text: matters which should he brought to his

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, and to which satisfactory replies

Speaker: NA
Text: Parare desired. The Prime Minister is also

Speaker: NA
Text: its the head of an important government

Speaker: NA
Text: department-th e Prime Minister's De-

Speaker: NA
Text: i t partment-and , as the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: to Opposition ( Mr Menzies) pointed out

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier to-day, he is also Minister f or

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence, and i n that capacity co-

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinates, through the Defence Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: to ment, matters of policy which arise in

Speaker: NA
Text: other service departments. To him, there-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore, we must look for decisions or

Speaker: NA
Text: announcements on matters of defence

Speaker: NA
Text: policy which affect all the services, as

Speaker: NA
Text: distinct from those which affect them in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dividually. I f the private members of

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parliament are to be denied oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunities normally available to them to

Speaker: NA
Text: place questions before the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter in his capacity as head of the -Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, or as head of thePrime Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: Department, or as Minister for Defence,

Speaker: NA
Text: a great cross-section of public adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration in this country will be cut off

Speaker: NA
Text: from inquiry. As the result of security

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions, there has been a limitation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the range of matters on which members

Speaker: NA
Text: can obtain information. I mentioned

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier that the number of matters to be

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt with has grown tremendously. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: we take the budget figures alone, and

Speaker: NA
Text: compare a pre-war budget of under

Speaker: NA
Text: £100,000,000 with a war-time budget

Speaker: NA
Text: providing for an expenditure of

Speaker: NA
Text: £700,000,000 a year, we get a side-light'

Speaker: NA
Text: on the growth of matters dealt with by

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parlia?nent. I t has been said that

Speaker: NA
Text: we still have the opportunity to place

Speaker: NA
Text: questions on the notice-paper, bnt I sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: mit that that is not a satisfactory alternations

Speaker: NA
Text: tive. Obviously, there are some matters

Speaker: NA
Text: which, because of the detailed nature of

Speaker: NA
Text: the questions or the necessity to obtain

Speaker: NA
Text: information 'before they can be answered,

Speaker: NA
Text: must be placed on the notice-paper. One

Speaker: NA
Text: very great merit in the practice of sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitting questions publicly in the House

Speaker: NA
Text: is that such questions are heard by all

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Government, as well as

Speaker: NA
Text: by supporters of the Government, and as

Speaker: NA
Text: such questions sometimes have ramifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions which extend beyond one depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, the questioner can be assured that

Speaker: NA
Text: his representations will receive immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: attention by all the Ministers involved.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those of us who have had experience as

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers know that matters referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: in questions asked in this place, as dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinct from those placed on the notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: paper make a greater impression on the

Speaker: NA
Text: mind of a Minister. I n the main, the

Speaker: NA
Text: questions placed on the notice-paper

Speaker: NA
Text: relate to matters concerning which, replies

Speaker: NA
Text: are prepared by departmental officers and

Speaker: NA
Text: brought to Ministers for confirmation

Speaker: NA
Text: and signature. There is so much of merit

Speaker: NA
Text: and value in' the practice which has

Speaker: NA
Text: developed in this place that it has .become

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the features of the life of this Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament. I t has taken the place which

Speaker: NA
Text: private members' business takes in other

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliaments, and even i f an hour each

Speaker: NA
Text: day be devoted to a consideration of these

Speaker: NA
Text: matters, i t is time well spent in protect-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the rights of individuals. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: rights call for greater attention to-day,

Speaker: NA
Text: when war-time pressure has caused the

Speaker: NA
Text: Executive to encroach more than

Speaker: NA
Text: ever on the freedom of individuals.

Speaker: NA
Text: As some justification for the attitude

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted by the Prime Minister in this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter, the Treasurer ( Mr Chifley) this

Speaker: NA
Text: afternoon quoted a precedent set by Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce in 1929, when he was Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter. .Since then I have indulged in some

Speaker: NA
Text: research and I find that the facts are not

Speaker: NA
Text: quite as the Treasurer presented them to

Speaker: NA
Text: us. On the 22nd August, 1929, the then

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, Mr Bruce, indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: that he and his Ministers would answer

Speaker: NA
Text: only questions which dealt with matters

Speaker: NA
Text: of urgency. He said-

Speaker: NA
Text: To save time, and in order that there may

Speaker: NA
Text: he full opportunity to obtain the information

Speaker: NA
Text: which honorable members require, the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has decided to ask for notice of all ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: except such as may be veTy urgent. This

Speaker: NA
Text: wil l ensure that more satisfactory replies can

Speaker: NA
Text: be given.

Speaker: NA
Text: Later, he added-

Speaker: NA
Text: As there is a full programme of legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: to be put through this session, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: proposes not to answer questions without

Speaker: NA
Text: notice unless they have this element of urgency.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable members will notice that Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce did not exclude himself from the

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility of dealing with questions,

Speaker: NA
Text: nor did he confine that responsibility to

Speaker: NA
Text: questions put to him by party leaders.

Speaker: NA
Text: He indicated that it was a practice to be

Speaker: NA
Text: followed by all members of his Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Of eight questions addressed t<»

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers on the 23rd August, 1929, the

Speaker: NA
Text: then Prime Minister answered four. On

Speaker: NA
Text: the next sitting day, the 2St,h, he replied

Speaker: NA
Text: to five out of the ten questions addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: to Ministers, the 29th three out of three,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the 30th five out of seven. On the

Speaker: NA
Text: 4th Septemlber, the next sitting clay, he

Speaker: NA
Text: replied to seven out of eleven, and on

Speaker: NA
Text: the 5th September seven out of nine.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even up to the issue of that edict by Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce questions had not at any time

Speaker: NA
Text: reached our standard to-day, either in the

Speaker: NA
Text: number asked or the length of time

Speaker: NA
Text: occupied. Despite the edict, he personally

Speaker: NA
Text: answered more than 50 per cent, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: questions in the first six sitting days

Speaker: NA
Text: after he had made the statement. So

Speaker: NA
Text: we cannot accept the practice adopted

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Bruce as a precedent. Perhaps the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, not being in the best

Speaker: NA
Text: of health, has allowed himself to be led-

Speaker: NA
Text: into a decision which is at variance with

Speaker: NA
Text: the traditional respect that he has always

Speaker: NA
Text: shown to the traditions of Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: and the rights and privileges of the

Speaker: NA
Text: members of this Parliament. I f that

Speaker: NA
Text: is the case, I hope that even i f he feels

Speaker: NA
Text: that he is not physically able to stand

Speaker: NA
Text: up to whatever effort is involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: answering questions, he will nominate a

Speaker: NA
Text: deputy who will have full authority to

Speaker: NA
Text: speak on his behalf as Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: and as Minister for Defence. Unless

Speaker: NA
Text: we can be assured of that, I and

Speaker: NA
Text: other private members must insist, not

Speaker: NA
Text: only for ourselves, but also for the

Speaker: NA
Text: institution of which we are a part and

Speaker: NA
Text: the people outside, who look to us for

Speaker: NA
Text: free expression in protection of their

Speaker: NA
Text: rights, on opposing the practice now

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated and demand restoration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: .privileges that we have enjoyed in the

Speaker: NA
Text: past.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: New England) [10.22].

Speaker: NA
Text: - I support the remarks of the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Fawkner ( Mr Holt)

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning the announcement by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Ourtin) to the

Speaker: NA
Text: press that he would reply only to ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions asked by the party leaders.

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot understand the attitude of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government on this matter. Preserva-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the liberties of the people was

Speaker: NA
Text: the very basis of the policy of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party. Every member on this

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the chamber is most sympathetic

Speaker: NA
Text: towards tlie Prime Minister during his

Speaker: NA
Text: illness. We do not want to embarrass him

Speaker: NA
Text: at all. However, every honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: realizes that the business of the country

Speaker: NA
Text: must go on and that, i f his health is not

Speaker: NA
Text: so good as it should be, the rights of

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament should not be abrogated. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister should have a rest or.

Speaker: NA
Text: as the honorable^ member for Fawkner

Speaker: NA
Text: suggested, he should appoint some one

Speaker: NA
Text: to answer questions on his behalf. I n the

Speaker: NA
Text: midst of a great war, when all sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: rules and regulations are being made by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government which never come before

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament until they are imposed on the

Speaker: NA
Text: public, i t is absolutely essential that

Speaker: NA
Text: the rights of honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: should be protected and that private

Speaker: NA
Text: members on either side should be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to question the Prime Minister and

Speaker: NA
Text: other Ministers about what is hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pening i n the conduct of the war or

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's policy, or to expose

Speaker: NA
Text: abuses which may be taking place. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: is all very well to say that we have the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to speak on the adjourn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the House, but tbat comes very

Speaker: NA
Text: late indeed.

Speaker: Sir FREDERICK STEWART
Text: An d 'thews

Speaker: NA
Text: is not a big audience.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Yes , but that does

Speaker: NA
Text: not matter. The point is that at ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion time, when every one is present in

Speaker: NA
Text: the House, what is asked is flashed to

Speaker: NA
Text: almost every part of Australia. I t is

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely essential that that period of

Speaker: NA
Text: interrogation should not be in any way

Speaker: NA
Text: restricted. The only way i n which to

Speaker: NA
Text: make a government with the majority

Speaker: NA
Text: which this Government possesses realize

Speaker: NA
Text: that it may have to do certain things

Speaker: NA
Text: or not do other things is to create a

Speaker: NA
Text: public opinion which will make i t realize

Speaker: NA
Text: that, if i t carries on in the way that i t is

Speaker: NA
Text: carrying on, the public will turn away

Speaker: NA
Text: from it. That is the greatest protection

Speaker: NA
Text: that democracy has. I t is the very

Speaker: NA
Text: negation of democracy for the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to attempt to suppress the asking

Speaker: NA
Text: of questions.

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: N o one is suppressing

Speaker: NA
Text: the asking of questions.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Question s are being

Speaker: NA
Text: suppressed. I f the Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: in contravention of the Standing Orders

Speaker: NA
Text: of this House, says that he will answer

Speaker: NA
Text: Dnly questions asked by the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition ( Mr Menzies) and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Australian Country party

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Fadden), as representing the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition, and that i f private members

Speaker: NA
Text: ask questions he will ignore them, he

Speaker: NA
Text: is interfering with the rights and

Speaker: NA
Text: privileges of honorable members and

Speaker: NA
Text: preventing them from airing their

Speaker: NA
Text: grievances. Only last week I asked

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for the Army ( Mr Forde)

Text: a question about the recapture of

Speaker: NA
Text: Nauru and Ocean Islands, and, before

Text: the Minister for the Army could even

Text: answer, the Prime Minister, like a new

Speaker: NA
Text: Henry V., jumped into the breach and

Speaker: NA
Text: replied himself. I do not know whether

Speaker: NA
Text: he was afraid that the Minister for the

Speaker: NA
Text: A.rmy would give the wrong reply, but

Speaker: NA
Text: if the direction that the Prime Minister

Text: is not to be asked questions by private

Speaker: NA
Text: members is to be enforced, will he refrain

Speaker: NA
Text: from answering questions asked of other

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers? I do not want to embarrass

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister in his illness. He

Speaker: NA
Text: needs a long rest to recuperate. But i t

Speaker: NA
Text: is a shocking and woeful departure from

Speaker: NA
Text: an established practice if honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers will not be answered by Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: unless in the view of Ministers, the

Speaker: NA
Text: questions are urgent. That is wrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: Very often a question is asked and in

Speaker: NA
Text: the reply the public gets a view of what

Speaker: NA
Text: actually happening. [Quorum formed.]

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is wrong, indeed, for the Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: in contravention of the Standing Orders,

Speaker: NA
Text: to deny private members the right to ask

Speaker: NA
Text: questions. I t is absurd to say that an

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable memiber is able to open up a

Speaker: NA
Text: question as effectively by putting it on

Speaker: NA
Text: the notice-paper as by asking i t without

Speaker: NA
Text: notice. I support the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Fawkner in his advocacy of. the rights

Speaker: NA
Text: of honorable members. Thev must be

Speaker: NA
Text: preserved. Honorable members must be

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed to ask questions as prescribed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Standing Orders and should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: forced to submit to rafferty rules,

Speaker: NA
Text: announced through the press, without

Speaker: NA
Text: your consent, Mr .Speaker, or the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent of this House. I hope that the Trea-

Speaker: NA
Text: surer ( Mr Chifley), who is now i n charge

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House, will pay regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Orders, and thus preserve the

Speaker: NA
Text: rights and privileges of honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers in this democracy, and that no action

Speaker: NA
Text: will be taken to prevent them from let-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting the people of Australia know what

Speaker: NA
Text: is going on in this Parliament, because,

Speaker: NA
Text: in effect, that will be the result of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's decision.

Speaker: Mr MCEWEN
Text: Indi) [10.33] - I re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quest the Government to arrange for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Commerce and Agriculture

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Scully) to make a clear-cut and

Speaker: NA
Text: authoritative announcement regarding

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe policy which it intends to follow with

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to payments into the Nos. 6 and 7

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat pools in respect of wheat sold at

Speaker: NA
Text: concessional prices. I do not propose to

Speaker: NA
Text: argue the merits of the case, but merely

Speaker: NA
Text: draw attention to a long series of conflict-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing announcements which have either

Speaker: NA
Text: been made by the Minister or attributed

Speaker: NA
Text: to him in reports of proceedings of

Speaker: NA
Text: various meetings which he has attended,

Speaker: NA
Text: or deputations he has received, as well as

Speaker: NA
Text: in statements issued from his office. I t is

Speaker: NA
Text: well known, of course, that in the early

Speaker: NA
Text: stages of the controversy over conces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sional wheat prices the Minister declared

Speaker: NA
Text: that no injustice was being done to

Speaker: NA
Text: growers. He certainly said that no pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment should be made to the pools in

Speaker: NA
Text: addition to the original 6d. a bushel sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidy announced by the Government, and

Speaker: NA
Text: provision for which has been made in two

Speaker: NA
Text: and, perhaps, three, budgets. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: is as the controversy developed and the jus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tice of the opposing case became so clear

Speaker: NA
Text: that it could no longer be defended by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, ' the Minister attended a

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting of the wheat and wool growers

Speaker: NA
Text: organization in New South Wales in July

Speaker: NA
Text: last. I n this House on the 14th Septem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber, he quoted what he said at that meet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing as follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: After full consideration, I announced that

Speaker: NA
Text: the price of stock feed would be increased

Speaker: NA
Text: so as to bring it up to the return from

Speaker: NA
Text: the pool concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thus he made it. clear that the returns

Speaker: NA
Text: from the pool sales of wheat for human

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption, power alcohol distilleries,

Speaker: NA
Text: stock feed and breakfast food would be

Speaker: NA
Text: averaged, and, insofar as the concessional

Speaker: NA
Text: sales fell short of that average, the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment would make up the difference.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whether one agrees with that policy or

Speaker: NA
Text: not the Minister's statement was clear.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t was accepted by some, but others made

Speaker: NA
Text: it the subject of a controversy. The fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that it was not generally accepted was

Speaker: NA
Text: made clear by a deputation representing

Speaker: NA
Text: the Farmers and Settlers Association

Speaker: NA
Text: which waited upon the Minister on the

Speaker: NA
Text: 17th September. His reply to that

Speaker: NA
Text: deputation which requested that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government liberalize its attitude was

Speaker: NA
Text: reported in the Sydney Morning Herald

Speaker: NA
Text: of the 18th September as follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: He had advised the Wheat Board, he said,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government would pay the difference

Speaker: NA
Text: between tlie average realization of Nos. 0 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 7 pools, and the concessional price on all

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat sold at concessional rates out of these

Speaker: NA
Text: pools.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was confirmation of what he said

Speaker: NA
Text: in July, what he reiterated in this House

Speaker: NA
Text: on the 14th September, and what he i n -

Speaker: NA
Text: formed the deputation on the 17th Sep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tember. On all of those occasions he did

Speaker: NA
Text: not f a i l to say that the growers, speaking

Speaker: NA
Text: through their organizations, were satis-

Speaker: NA
Text: fied. However, the fact that the growers

Speaker: NA
Text: were not satisfied was exemplified by the

Speaker: NA
Text: deputation representing the Farmers and

Speaker: NA
Text: Settlers Association, and subsequently at

Speaker: NA
Text: a conference of delegates of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Wheatgrowers Federation. Following the

Speaker: NA
Text: latter conference, Mr Lillie and Mr Stott.

Speaker: NA
Text: the president and secretary of the federa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, issued a statement in. which they

Speaker: NA
Text: said-

Speaker: NA
Text: We wish to make perfectly clear that tlie

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the conference was satisfactory.

Speaker: NA
Text: Regarding the controversy over concessional

Speaker: NA
Text: prices for stock feed, &c, the Minister made it

Speaker: NA
Text: abundantly clear that concessional prices being

Speaker: NA
Text: received for sales of wheat for breakfast food,

Speaker: NA
Text: stock feed and power alcohol, would not be

Speaker: NA
Text: taken into the calculations to ascertain the

Speaker: NA
Text: final realizations of the pool.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government would make up the dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference between the prices received for con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessional sales and the price received by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Wheat Board on export sales and

Speaker: NA
Text: the home-consumption price.

Speaker: NA
Text: That reported reply by the Minister to

Speaker: NA
Text: the conference represented a more liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude on the part of the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f the report given by those gentlemen

Speaker: NA
Text: was correct, i t involved the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: providing an additional sum of some

Speaker: NA
Text: millions of pounds over and above what

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister bad previously indicated the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government was prepared to provide f o r

Speaker: NA
Text: this purpose. I n order to ascertain the

Text: real position I asked the Minister i n this

Speaker: NA
Text: House on the 16th November whether he

Speaker: NA
Text: could confirm the report attributed to

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Lillie and Mr Stott, and, i f so,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether he and the Government did not

Speaker: NA
Text: think i t more fitting that announcements

Speaker: NA
Text: involving the expenditure of millions of

Speaker: NA
Text: pounds ought to be made by the Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: and not by persons who attended a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference. The Minister, i n his reply to which

Speaker: NA
Text: me, contradicted tlie reply

Speaker: NA
Text: him by -M.v. Lillie and Mr Stott. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister also said-

Speaker: NA
Text: The only assurance 1 gave to the deputation

Speaker: NA
Text: was the assurance that I gave to honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members in replying to a debate on a motion

Speaker: NA
Text: for adjournment moved by the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Indi at our last meeting, when I

Speaker: NA
Text: that average realizations of the pool would

Speaker: NA
Text: Air. MCEwen.

Speaker: NA
Text: be taken into consideration, and that I in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tended to make a submission to Cabinet seek-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing approval for an amount of money to be

Speaker: NA
Text: placed to the credit of the pool to bring these

Speaker: NA
Text: payments up to the realization figure.

Speaker: NA
Text: According to that reply, the position had

Speaker: NA
Text: reverted to that outlined in the state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment which the Minister made i n July,

Speaker: NA
Text: which he confirmed i n Parliament i n

Speaker: NA
Text: September, and which he confirmed again

Speaker: NA
Text: in reply to a deputation f r o m the Farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: and Settlers Association on tlie 1.7th Sep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tember, repudiating the report of the

Speaker: NA
Text: president and secretary of the Wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: Growers Federation and getting back to

Speaker: NA
Text: bis original formula. I can understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that; but the matter did not rest there.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said before, I am not attempting

Speaker: NA
Text: to canvass the merits of this particular

Speaker: NA
Text: controversy. I am only trying to elicit

Speaker: NA
Text: at long last a statement of fact, from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: The next authoritative announcement

Speaker: NA
Text: in this extraordinary series was made by

Speaker: NA
Text: the chairman of the Australian Wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: Board, Sir Olive MCPherson, on the 23rd

Speaker: NA
Text: January last. He stated that the board

Speaker: NA
Text: had been informed by the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: that i t had decided to eliminate "wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: sold f o r stock feed from the calculation

Speaker: NA
Text: of compensation to the wheat-growers in

Speaker: NA
Text: the No. 6 and No. 7 pools. There again,

Speaker: NA
Text: that is one formula which can be applied

Speaker: NA
Text: to this particular problem. I t is a formula

Speaker: NA
Text: that we can understand. Many people

Speaker: NA
Text: will agree with i t , but unquestionably if

Speaker: NA
Text: involves the provision of some millions of

Speaker: NA
Text: pounds more than would be necessary had

Speaker: NA
Text: the formula which the Minister himself

Speaker: NA
Text: announced been applied.

Speaker: Mr SCULLY
Text: Th e formula which

Speaker: NA
Text: was announced has been consistently

Speaker: NA
Text: adhered to.

Speaker: Mr MCEWEN
Text: I t was not the

Speaker: NA
Text: formula that the Minister announced.

Speaker: Mr SCULLY
Text: I t was, absolutely.

Speaker: Mr MCEWEN
Text: W a s i t the formula

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister announced at

Speaker: NA
Text: attributed to Gunnedah i n July?

Speaker: Mr SCULLY
Text: Yes , and i t has never

Speaker: NA
Text: been departed from.

Speaker: Mr MCEWEN
Text: T h e n w i l l the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter explain the circumstances i n which

Speaker: NA
Text: memhe received a deputation f r o m the

Speaker: NA
Text: said Farmers and Settlers Association on the

Speaker: NA
Text: 17th September, protesting against the

Speaker: NA
Text: application of a formula which would

Speaker: NA
Text: merely take into account the total average

Text: of the pool ?

Text: Incorrec t reports of the

Speaker: NA
Text: conversation which I had with that

Speaker: NA
Text: deputation were published in a section

Text: of the press. Mr Nock and Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Cambridge were satisfied with my

Text: M y purpose in rais-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the matter this evening was to elicit

Speaker: NA

Text: correct in stating that the Minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: declared that the policy is that which was

Speaker: NA
Text: announced by the chairman of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Wheat Board?

Text: Yes .

Speaker: Mr MCEWEN
Text: Th e chairman stated

Speaker: NA
Text: that the board had been informed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government that i t had decided to elimi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nate wheat sold for stock feed from the

Speaker: NA
Text: calculation of compensation to the wheat-

Speaker: NA
Text: growers having wheat in the No. 6 and

Speaker: NA
Text: No. 7 pools.

Speaker: Mr SCULLY
Text: That , is my intention

Speaker: NA
Text: and that information has been given

Speaker: NA
Text: whenever it has been sought.

Speaker: Mr MCEWEN
Text: Le t me approach the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter from that stand-point. The

Speaker: NA
Text: formula is to eliminate wheat sold for

Text: stock feed so that we must strike an

Text: average by taking the wheat gristed for

Speaker: NA
Text: flour for human consumption in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, and wheat used by power alcohol

Speaker: NA
Text: distilleries, and breakfast food manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: turers, and for export. Unfortunately,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister has contradicted himself

Speaker: NA
Text: since then. I happened to look at a

Speaker: NA
Text: reply to a question, which I can only

Speaker: NA
Text: describe as having been surreptitiously

Speaker: NA
Text: lodged. The question had been addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Commerce and Agri-

Speaker: NA
Text: culture by the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Grey ( Mr Russell). The Minister indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated that he would reply to it later.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the 8th March last, a reply was given

Speaker: NA
Text: in a manner unprecedented during my

Speaker: NA
Text: eleven years' experience in this chamber.

Speaker: NA
Text: A typewritten answer was handed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Clerk of the House. I t was couched in

Speaker: NA
Text: argumentative terms, and in the form

Speaker: NA
Text: of a speech. I f I had not secured, the

Speaker: NA
Text: answer, as I was entitled to do, I would

Speaker: NA
Text: not now probably have been aware of this

Speaker: NA
Text: latest contradiction by the Minister. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman stated that last July,

Speaker: NA
Text: he informed delegates that i t was the

Speaker: NA
Text: intention of the Government to adjust

Speaker: NA
Text: the pool payments so that wheat sold for

Speaker: NA
Text: stock feed would be brought up to the

Speaker: NA
Text: average realizations of wheat sold for

Speaker: NA
Text: human consumption. Only two minutes

Speaker: NA
Text: ago the Minister declared that that was

Speaker: NA
Text: not the policy. He said that-the inten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is to bring the concessional price

Speaker: NA
Text: up to the average of wheat sold for human

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption, to power alcohol distilleries

Speaker: NA
Text: and breakfast food manufacturers, and

Speaker: NA
Text: for export. I desire to get at the truh.

Speaker: Mr SCULLY
Text: I tried to correct a mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: statement which the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: has continually made, that the conces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sional sales would be taken into considera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in striking the average.

Speaker: Mr MCEWEN
Text: I do not desire to

Speaker: NA
Text: take fine points about the Minister accus-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing me of making a mistake. I have read

Speaker: NA
Text: his reply to a motion which I submitted

Speaker: NA
Text: on the 14th September. His remarks

Speaker: NA
Text: appear in Hansard. After full considera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, he announced that the price of stock

Speaker: NA
Text: feed would be increased so as to bring it

Speaker: NA
Text: up to the return from the pools concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those words are clear. Yet, when I quoted

Speaker: NA
Text: them as the foundation for making cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain calculations, the Minister accused me

Speaker: NA
Text: of misrepresenting him. [Extension of

Speaker: NA
Text: time granted.] The Government is en-

Speaker: NA
Text: titled to make its own decision on thiB

Text: matter, and no doubt will do so if i t is

Speaker: NA
Text: not " pushed around" too much. But

Text: the wheat-growers, the public, and the

Text: taxpayers are entitled to an authoritative

Text: statement, not a series of contradictory

Speaker: NA
Text: statements by the Minister and the chair-

Speaker: NA
Text: man of the Australian Wheat Board,

Speaker: NA
Text: culminating in the latest contradiction in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister's reply to a question asked

Text: by the honorable member for Grey. As I

Text: stated, that reply was handed to the Clerk

Text: of the House in a manner which was cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly not in conformity with procedure

Text: laid down in the Standing Orders. The

Speaker: NA
Text: statement commenced, " With the indul-

Speaker: NA
Text: gence of the House". I n the circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances mentioned the indulgence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House could not be obtained. What

Speaker: NA
Text: we desire to know, and this involves some

Speaker: NA
Text: millions of pounds to the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: and the wheat-growers, is: On what

Speaker: NA
Text: formula are the calculations to be based,

Speaker: NA
Text: to make an additional payment to the

Speaker: NA
Text: No. 6 and No. 7 pools on account of tht

Speaker: NA
Text: concessional wheat prices? I ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister to make a clear statement.

Text: Th e position has been

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly stated repeatedly, and I am not

Text: prepared to make a further statement.

Text: I defy a genius to

Speaker: NA
Text: work out, from the series of statements

Text: made by the Minister, exactly what the

Text: position is.

Text: "Barker)

Text: may address to him without notice, and

Text: my right to ask him, questions. I shall

Text: defer that until the right honorable gentle-

Text: man is here to answer my interrogations.

Text: Prime Minister comes into the chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall have something to say to him.

Speaker: NA
Text: According to my information, certain

Speaker: NA
Text: departmental committees are now deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mining the fate of the Northern Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory for a generation to come. I t appears

Speaker: NA
Text: to me that every one has a finger in this

Speaker: NA
Text: pie, with the exception of the residents of

Speaker: NA
Text: that area. One of the most amazing docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments that I have received came from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the Interior (Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Collings) quite recently. I n it, he said

Speaker: NA
Text: that he would not take any notice what-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever of the Northern Territory Develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment League, which had been formed

Speaker: NA
Text: to handle affairs of interest to

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of that territory, but that i f

Speaker: NA
Text: individual members oared to write to him

Speaker: NA
Text: iji their private capacity he would con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider anything that might be put up.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a little too bad. There are cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain very important features of develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in the Northern Territory which

Speaker: NA
Text: will have to be undertaken in the near

Speaker: NA
Text: future. They concern the development

Speaker: NA
Text: of stock routes, the making of roads, the

Speaker: NA
Text: opening of ports, the question as to

Speaker: NA
Text: whether or not a railway line shall go

Speaker: NA
Text: through and, if so, in what direction, the

Speaker: NA
Text: conservation of water, the establishment

Speaker: NA
Text: of certain irrigation areas, the encourage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of mining, and quite a few other

Speaker: NA
Text: matters. The least which the people can

Speaker: NA
Text: expect from the Government is that those

Speaker: NA
Text: who are on the spot and have spent a

Speaker: NA
Text: prood part of their lives on these jobs shall

Speaker: NA
Text: have the opportunity of seeing the depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental heads who are supposed to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce the milennium in the territory, and

Speaker: NA
Text: shall at least he accorded the courtesy of

Speaker: NA
Text: being allowed to put their views before

Speaker: NA
Text: the people who are determining their

Speaker: NA
Text: future. They have no representation of

Speaker: NA
Text: their own. The only representative they

Speaker: NA
Text: have is a member of this House, and he is

Speaker: NA
Text: not able to speak for them at present.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the time being, I propose to put their

Speaker: NA
Text: case to the Government. I f I am not able

Speaker: NA
Text: to see for myself .some of the things which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government proposes to do, and to

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate them to the people who matter,

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall have no recourse except to submit

Speaker: NA
Text: a substantive motion which will produce

Speaker: NA
Text: a debate on the future of the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory and what the Government pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: poses to do about it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.
