Text: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS.

Speaker: NA
Text: The folloufing answers to questions

Speaker: NA
Text: were circulated:-

Speaker: NA
Text: SANE DEMOCRACY LEAGUE.

Speaker: Mr MOUNTJOY
Text: the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General, upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Has he seen the photostat of a letter which

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared in a Sydney newspaper recently

Speaker: NA
Text: indicating that Lieutenant-Colonel Powell had

Speaker: NA
Text: successfully canvassed a donation from Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mercial Steels Limited for the Sane Democracy

Speaker: NA
Text: League ?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Is this the Lieutenant-'Colonel Powell who

Speaker: NA
Text: held an executive post in military intelligence,

Speaker: NA
Text: and, if so, by whose authority did a military

Speaker: NA
Text: officer act as canvasser for a political organizaceived

Speaker: NA
Text: tion T

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Is i t a fact that the Sane Democracy

Speaker: NA
Text: League is subsidized by big monopolies like

Speaker: NA
Text: the Colonial Sugar Refining Company Limited

Speaker: NA
Text: for definite political purposes, such as attack-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Federal and State Labour Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments and the trade unions?

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. Is i t a fact that the secretary of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sane Democracy League, Mr A. de R. Barclay,

Speaker: NA
Text: has had tens of thousands of pounds available

Speaker: NA
Text: for this .political propaganda, which should

Speaker: NA
Text: be diverted to tho war effort?

Speaker: NA
Text: fi. Does Mr Barclay receive now, or has

Speaker: NA
Text: he received in the past, any subsidies from

Speaker: NA
Text: investigation or security organizations under

Speaker: NA
Text: the control of the Attorney-General or the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the Army?

Speaker: NA
Text: fi. W i l l he ascertain whether the same Mr .

Speaker: NA
Text: A. do R. Barclay held an interest in what

Speaker: NA
Text: was known as a select house of assignation

Speaker: NA
Text: at 34 Orown-street, Sydney?

Speaker: NA
Text: 7. W'ill he carry out an investigation to

Speaker: NA
Text: discover whether a Mrs Ryan, who was

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with Mr A. de R. Barclay in

Speaker: NA
Text: this Crown-street business, later opened a

Speaker: NA
Text: similar business at King's Cross, and whether

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr A. de R. Barclay has drawn any re-

Speaker: NA
Text: muneration from this business?

Speaker: NA
Text: 8. Will he have a thorough investigation

Speaker: NA
Text: made of the whole ramifications of the Sane

Speaker: NA
Text: Democracy League, including its contacts with

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the military forces, its sources

Speaker: NA
Text: of subsidies, its constitution, and the methods

Speaker: NA
Text: of electing officers?

Speaker: Dr EVATT
Text: through Mr Beasley) -

Speaker: NA
Text: T h e answers to the honorable member's

Speaker: NA
Text: questions are as f o l l o w s : -

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2 to 8. The Attorney-General has no present

Speaker: NA
Text: information as to these matters, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: matters are being referred to the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Army and the Security Service so

Speaker: NA
Text: that the information may be obtained.

Speaker: NA
Text: MB. FRANK GOLDBERG.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General, upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Is i t a fact, as stated, that Mr Frank

Speaker: NA
Text: Goldberg has produced in the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: » letter of recommendation signed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General ?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. I f so, is i t customary for the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: to give this type of letter to Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: travelling abroad?

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. W i l l he table a copy of the letter in

Speaker: NA
Text: the House?

Speaker: Dr EVATT
Text: through Mr Beasley) -

Speaker: NA
Text: The answers to the honorable member's

Speaker: NA
Text: questions are as follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Following upon action taken by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Information, Mr Goldberg re-

Speaker: NA
Text: from myself, as Minister for External

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs, the courtesy of a letter of intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction identifying him and stating that

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities accorded him while abroad would

Speaker: NA
Text: be appreciated. Whether he produced this

Speaker: NA
Text: document in the United States is not known,

Speaker: NA
Text: but i t is believed that the document was not

Speaker: NA
Text: used.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. There is no custom in this respect, as

Speaker: NA
Text: each application is considered on its merits'

Speaker: NA
Text: according to inquiries made and advice re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived by the Department of External Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: from a,ppropriate quarters, including any otheT

Speaker: NA
Text: department of State which may be concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. ' No copy of the letter is now available,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the letter of introduction given was

Speaker: NA
Text: framed in accordance with tlie advice received

Speaker: NA
Text: from the appropriate department-i n this case,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Information.

Speaker: NA
Text: MOTION PICTURE INDUSTRY : PRICES

Speaker: NA
Text: CONTROL.

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: O n Friday, the 23rd

Speaker: NA
Text: February, 1945, the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Moreton ( Mr Francis) and the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Griffith ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Conelan) raised certain questions relat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to the Prices Commissioner's ruling

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding the film "iSong of Berna-

Speaker: NA
Text: dette " and a complaint of the Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land Motion Picture Exhibitors Associa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion relating thereto.

Speaker: NA
Text: ' I have now received advice from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Trade and Customs (Sena-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor Keane) on the subject. Ordinarily,

Speaker: NA
Text: the hire rate for films is determined by

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiation between the distributor and

Speaker: NA
Text: exhibitor, the determination being based

Speaker: NA
Text: generally on box-office receipts. Since

Speaker: NA
Text: it is not possible to forecast the popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larity of a film, it is not possible, to fix

Speaker: NA
Text: specific hire rates in advance. I n the

Speaker: NA
Text: case of " Song of Bernadette ", approval

Speaker: NA
Text: was given to a basis for negotiation

Speaker: NA
Text: and both distributors and exhibitors were

Speaker: NA
Text: advised of this arrangement, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: under the scheme no exhibitor was

Speaker: NA
Text: deprived of his right to apply to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prices Commissioner for adjudication.

Speaker: NA
Text: These arrangements were in line with

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestions made by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Exhibitors Advisory Committee, which

Speaker: NA
Text: embraces the Queensland Motion Picture

Speaker: NA
Text: Exhibitors Association. I t is still open

Speaker: NA
Text: to any exhibitor who does not agree to

Speaker: NA
Text: terms suggested by the distributors to

Speaker: NA
Text: submit f u l l details to the Prices Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner i n order to have the hire of

Speaker: NA
Text: the film specifically fixed.

Speaker: NA
Text: AUSTRALIA NARMY : MUNITIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: INSPECTORS.

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: O n the 1st March,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1.945, the Minister for Munitions ( M

Speaker: NA
Text: Makin) referred to the following ques- (tZ) Italy?

Speaker: NA
Text: tions by the honorable memiber for

Speaker: NA
Text: Balaclava ( Mr White) :-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. What are the names and ranks of comtralia ?

Speaker: NA
Text: missioned officers in the Department of Army

Speaker: NA
Text: Inspection (munitions) and when were their

Speaker: NA
Text: present ranks gained?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. How many of tlie above are classifiedsettling

Speaker: NA
Text: " A.I.F." " A " class and have not yet seen retirement?

Speaker: NA
Text: active service?

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. How many officers who

Speaker: NA
Text: are engaged in inspection work?

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. What qualifications have any recently

Speaker: NA
Text: promoted officers for the technical

Speaker: NA
Text: held by them?

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. How many fit civilians of military age

Speaker: NA
Text: are employed in the above department?

Speaker: NA
Text: fi. Are there no partly disabled or over-age

Speaker: NA
Text: officers and soldiers who could

Speaker: NA
Text: of most of the present fit officers and civilians

Speaker: NA
Text: after a little experience?

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister fo r Munitions advised

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member that he had reissues

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred these questions to me for answer,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the following replies are now f u r - Canberra.

Speaker: NA
Text: nished :-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. The names and ranks of these _ com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioned officers have been communicated

Speaker: NA
Text: direct to the honorable memiber.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Of the 23 Australian Imperial Force

Speaker: NA
Text: " A l " class officers who have not seen active

Speaker: NA
Text: service eight are engaged on artillery

Speaker: NA
Text: and experimental duties, three are Radar

Speaker: NA
Text: scientists, two are controllers with special

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial qualifications.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Thirty-nine officers " A " class are en-

Speaker: NA
Text: gaged in inspection work, .plus 36 who

Speaker: NA
Text: over age. Of the 39, 19 are posted to

Speaker: NA
Text: Artillery Proof and Experimental Ranges,

Speaker: NA
Text: where a high proportion of young and active

Speaker: NA
Text: officers is essential.

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. All officers 'have the requisite qualificabe

Speaker: NA
Text: tions for the work they are required

Speaker: NA
Text: perform.

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. One hundred and thirty^four of a total

Speaker: NA
Text: staff of 2,738. A proportion of young

Speaker: NA
Text: active inspection staff is essential for special

Speaker: NA
Text: duties.

Speaker: NA
Text: fi. Inspection Division has experienced

Speaker: NA
Text: utmost difficulty in obtaining personnel

Speaker: NA
Text: the necessary qualifications from either within

Speaker: NA
Text: or without the Army. Consideration will be

Speaker: NA
Text: given to partly disabled or over-age applicants

Speaker: NA
Text: with the necessary trade and technical

Speaker: NA
Text: cations.

Speaker: NA
Text: AUSTRALIA N REPRESENTATION ABROAD..

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr BEASLEY on the 2nd March the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Fawkner ( Mr .

Speaker: NA
Text: H o l t ) asked the Minister for External

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs the following questions:-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. What representatives, if any, of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Governinent are there at the present

Speaker: NA
Text: time in each of the following countries: (a)

Speaker: NA
Text: r . France, (6) Belgium, (c) Holland, and.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. What organization, if any, is there operat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in these countries to stimulate, and deal;

Speaker: NA
Text: with inquiries regarding migration to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Is it a fact that inquiries have been,

Speaker: NA
Text: received by the Office of our High Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner in India from servicemen desirous of

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia upon their discharge or

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. What facilities exist for dealing with-

Speaker: NA
Text: are " A " class such inquiries?

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. Is it a fact that the Government of South-

Speaker: NA
Text: Africa maintains an organization in India t»-

Speaker: NA
Text: promote the migration to South Africa of such

Speaker: NA
Text: .positions servicemen ?

Speaker: NA
Text: The first question has already been,

Speaker: NA
Text: answered by the Minister for External

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs. The answers to the other ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: do the work tions are as follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. None at present.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Yes.

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. The High Commissioner's Office in Delhi

Speaker: NA
Text: information made available from Can-

Speaker: NA
Text: berra from time to time. Inquiries are also

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt with by the Department of the Interior.

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. No information is available here.

Speaker: NA
Text: PRISONERS OF WAR : QUESTIONNAIRES TO

Speaker: NA
Text: RELATIVES.

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: O n the 7th March the

Speaker: NA
Text: proof honorable member fo r Moreton ( Mr .

Speaker: NA
Text: Francis) referred to an article which had

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared i n Smith's Weekly on the 3rd

Speaker: NA
Text: March, stating that questionnaires were

Speaker: NA
Text: are still being sent to the relatives of

Speaker: NA
Text: the prisoners-of-war, and asked whether i t

Speaker: NA
Text: was a fact that I had stated some weeks

Speaker: NA
Text: ago that these questionnaires would not

Speaker: NA
Text: issued and, further, whether I would

Speaker: NA
Text: to now direct that the practice should be

Speaker: NA
Text: discontinued.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n reply I advise the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: and that on the 27th January last a press

Speaker: NA
Text: statement was issued by me on this sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: the ject, stating that the questionnaire to

Speaker: NA
Text: with relatives of prisoners-of-war should be

Speaker: NA
Text: completed i n the interests of the soldier,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I then made i t clear that the ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: qualifitionnaire was being forwarded by the

Speaker: NA
Text: department to non-dependent allottees

Speaker: NA
Text: only of prisoners-of-war. I t is now re-

Speaker: NA
Text: iterated that the action that has been

Speaker: NA
Text: taken is entirely in the soldiers' interests,

Speaker: NA
Text: and not, as has been stated in this House

Speaker: NA
Text: and elsewhere, with a view to saving

Speaker: NA
Text: money at the expense of the soldier

Speaker: NA
Text: prisoner-of-war and his relatives. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is completely sympathetic

Speaker: NA
Text: both to the prisoners-of-war and their

Speaker: NA
Text: relatives, and has not the slightest wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: impose any hardship or effect any

Speaker: NA
Text: monetary saving at their expense.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, in view of the experience

Speaker: NA
Text: gained both in the last war and the

Speaker: NA
Text: present war, when many cases occurred

Speaker: NA
Text: in which non-dependent allottees did not

Speaker: NA
Text: apply the allotment moneys received by

Speaker: NA
Text: them as the soldier had intended, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: considered advisable that in the case of

Speaker: NA
Text: prisoners-of-war who had been in the

Speaker: NA
Text: hands of the enemy for a lengthy period

Speaker: NA
Text: and wei-e thus not in a position to ascer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain in what manner the allotment that

Speaker: NA
Text: they had made to a non-dependant was

Speaker: NA
Text: being utilized, questionnaires should be

Speaker: NA
Text: despatched to non-dependent allottees. At

Speaker: NA
Text: the time the questionnaire was despatched

Speaker: NA
Text: it was accompanied by the following

Speaker: NA
Text: memorandum:-

Speaker: NA
Text: The enclosed questionnaire is being

Speaker: NA
Text: warded for completion by all allottees of

Speaker: NA
Text: soldiers wlio are prisoners of war, and who

Speaker: NA
Text: not in receipt of dependants allowance, and

Speaker: NA
Text: who, therefore, as far as the department

Speaker: NA
Text: aware, are not dependent upon the soldiers

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: The soldier is unfortunately not in

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to satisfy himself that the allotment is

Speaker: NA
Text: being applied to any purpose for which

Speaker: NA
Text: have intended at tlie time of making the allot-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. The circumstances may also have

Speaker: NA
Text: changed to such an extent that if the soldier

Speaker: NA
Text: were available to be consulted he might re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quest cancellation or reduction of the allot-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I t is therefore the desire of

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to protect the interests of the soldier in

Speaker: NA
Text: his absence.

Speaker: NA
Text: The information that has been obtained

Speaker: NA
Text: as a result, of the despatch of this ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionnaire indicates to me that its despatch

Speaker: NA
Text: was justified. I n the majority of cases,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, there has been no cause to make

Speaker: NA
Text: any change in the allotment; but where

Speaker: NA
Text: an allotment has been cancelled as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the information which has been

Speaker: NA
Text: disclosed, the amount of allotment so can-

Speaker: NA
Text: celled is being credited to the soldier and

Speaker: NA
Text: will be drawn by him on his return to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. I t is thus in the soldiers'

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in such cases that the allotment

Speaker: NA
Text: should have been cancelled and that the

Speaker: NA
Text: questionnaire should have been de-

Speaker: NA
Text: spatched. Exception has also been taken

Speaker: NA
Text: both in this House and elsewhere to the

Speaker: NA
Text: despatch of a similar form of question-

Speaker: NA
Text: naire to the non-dependent allottees of

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the forces who are reported

Speaker: NA
Text: as "missing" as a result of active opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. The regulations provide that, in

Speaker: NA
Text: such cases, an allotment to a non-

Speaker: NA
Text: dependant will cease after a certain

Speaker: NA
Text: period from the date on which the soldier

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned is reported to be missing. "When

Speaker: NA
Text: it is disclosed as a result of the replies to

Speaker: NA
Text: the questionnaire that hardship would

Speaker: NA
Text: arise by the suspension of the allotment,

Speaker: NA
Text: payment is continued at a rate commen-

Speaker: NA
Text: surate with the circumstances. I t is,

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore, in the interests of non-

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent allottees that the questionnaire

Speaker: NA
Text: received by them should be completed. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: it is not completed the allotment will

Speaker: NA
Text: automatically cease after a certain period.

Speaker: NA
Text: Cases have occurred in which, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: result of answers to the questions, pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of dependants' allowance has been

Speaker: NA
Text: authorized in addition to the allotment.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the circumstances outlined above, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is not proposed to issue directions that

Speaker: NA
Text: forthe questionnaire to which exception has

Speaker: NA
Text: been taken should be discontinued. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: are should be appreciated by all concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: is that the questionnaire is not despatched

Speaker: NA
Text: in any circumstances to allottees who

Speaker: NA
Text: are dependent on the member and are in

Speaker: NA
Text: a posireceipt of dependants' allowance in

Speaker: NA
Text: he may addition to the allotment.

Speaker: NA
Text: SUPERPHOSPHATE .

Speaker: Mr SCULLY
Text: O n the Sth March, the

Speaker: NA
Text: the departhonorable member for Bass ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Barnard) asked me a question, without

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, concerning the requirements of

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania in regard to superphosphate.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have now looked into the matter, and

Speaker: NA
Text: can inform the honorable member that it

Speaker: NA
Text: is known that all pastures in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: normally requiring superphosphate are

Speaker: NA
Text: showing the effects of phosphate shortage.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the last two years, it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: possible to make some improvement in

Speaker: NA
Text: the condition of irrigated and dairying

Speaker: NA
Text: pastures by means Of increased dressings

Speaker: NA
Text: of superphosphate, but the overall supply

Speaker: NA
Text: position has not yet improved sufficiently

Speaker: NA

Text: PENICILLIN.

Speaker: Mr CHAMBERS
Text: the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: representing the Minister for Health,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. I n view of the fact that penicillin is

Speaker: NA
Text: very expensive drug and that the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient supplies in a serious case of sepsis

Speaker: NA
Text: might easily cost £10, w i l l the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: give earnest consideration to supply i t free

Speaker: NA
Text: to maternity and public hospitals?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Is there any likelihood of a substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction being made in tlie cost of penicillin

Speaker: NA
Text: at an early date?

Speaker: Mr HOLLOWAY
Text: Th e Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health has supplied the following

Speaker: NA
Text: answers:-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. The Commonwealth Serum Laboratories,

Speaker: NA
Text: at whicli penicillin is manufactured, is a

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Government establishment

Speaker: NA
Text: working on a strictly business basis. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Government cannot undertake

Speaker: NA
Text: to supply any of the manufactured products

Speaker: NA
Text: on a free basis to any institution. The main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tenance of maternity and public hospitals is a

Speaker: NA
Text: function of State Governments, the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Government having no responsibility i n

Speaker: NA
Text: that field.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. There is a probability that the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: penicillin to the public w i l l be reduced as soon

Speaker: NA
Text: as the appropriate stage in large scale manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facture is reached.

Text: CoAL-AirNiNG INDUSTRY: GRANT TO

Text: MINERS.

Text: the Minister

Text: representing the Minister for Supply and

Text: Shipping, upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: previous war years was due, in the main,,

Text: district, and not because there had been less

Text: to the community?

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: on other fields?

Speaker: NA
Text: Supply and Shipping has supplied the-

Speaker: NA
Text: f ollowing answers:-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth Coal Commissioner has-

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended that employees in the western

Speaker: NA
Text: district should have recognition given to the-

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that production in 1944 was a record for

Speaker: NA
Text: any year since the beginning of the war, but

Speaker: NA
Text: neither the amount involved nor the form -

Speaker: NA
Text: of recognition has yet been settled. Answers-

Speaker: NA
Text: a to the specific questions asked by the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member, are as follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Yes, but 3,191 men were employed in.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1944, so that the output per man employed was.

Speaker: NA
Text: substantially better i n the latest year.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. The increase over previous war yours is

Speaker: NA
Text: due to lower production losses resulting from

Speaker: NA
Text: stoppages, and also because of increased pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction from open-cut mines.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. No.
